    11.4 â€“ Figure 11.4-1: Ventricular Rhythm vs Hyperkalemia?

    11.5 â€“ Figure 11.5-1: Ischemia vs Hyperkalemia?

    11.6 â€“ Figure 11.6-1: Hyperkalemia vs Normal Variant?

    11.7 â€“ HYPOKALEMIA: ECG Manifestations/Clinical Features

    11.8 â€“ HYPOMAGNESEMIA: Clinical Features/ ECG Signs

    11.9 â€“ U Waves: Definition/Clinical Significance

    11.10 â€“ Figure 11.10-1: Electrolyte Disturbance or Ischemia?

    12.0 â€“ Acute Pericarditis

    12.1 â€“ Acute Pericarditis: How to Make the Diagnosis?

    12.2 â€“ ECG FINDINGS of Acute Pericarditis

    12.3 â€“ Stage I of Acute Pericarditis

    12.4 â€“ PR Depression: How Helpful a Sign is this?

    12.5 â€“ What is Spodickâ€™s Sign?

    12.6 â€“* Differential* Diagnosis: Acute MI vs Early Repolarization?

    12.7 â€“* Acute* Myocarditis/Endocarditis: ECG Changes?

    12.8 â€“ FIGURE 12.8-1: Acute MI or Pericarditis?

    12.9 â€“ FIGURE 12.9-1: Pericarditis or Early Repolarization?

    13.0 â€“ Computerized ECG Interpretations

    13.1 â€“ Computerized Systems: Pros & Cons

    13.3 â€“ FIGURE 13.3-1: Do You Agree with the Computer?

    14.2 â€“ Electrical Alternans: KEY Clinical Points

    14.4 â€“ FIGURE 14.4-1: Alternans in a Patient with Lung Cancer?

    Section 00.4 â€“ About ECG-2014-ePub

    Electrocardiography is not difficult. At least it is not difficult to obtain a basic understanding of the art â€” and apply this understanding to interpreting the majority of 12-lead ECGs and arrhythmias that you will encounter. The most difficult part of electrocardiography is learning (and then remembering) the various criteria used to diagnose complex ECG findings such as chamber enlargement and bundle branch block.

    • Practically speaking â€” **there is much less to learn (and memorize) than most people think. Herein lies the secret of the ECG *Pocket *Brain: it facilitates understanding of basic ECG concepts and lightens the “memory load” â€” by providing ready recall of those KEY facts and figures needed for successful 12-lead interpretation.
    • We have ***completely ***revised and updated this 6th Edition (2014) of our book. We have more than doubled our content â€” enhanced our explanations â€” and have greatly improved the quality of our figures. This book now stands as an independent concise text on key aspects of ECG interpretation.
    • Development of this ePub takes ECG-2014-PB (Expanded) to a higher level. Nothing beats the instant access of a well organized electronic file.

    Â 

    Our goal is to provide key information fast. Near-instant access is now possible with this electronic ePub. We suggest you begin your review of ECG-2014-ePub by an overview of our CONTENTS at the front of this ePub.

    • There are immediate links to each subsection in our Contents.
    • Instant search and localization is facilitated by our new numbering system. For example â€” typing in 05.0 in the Search bar instantly brings up all places in this ePub where reference to Section 05.0 on Bundle Branch Block is found.

    Â 

    NOTE-1: This ePub book begins in Section 01.0 with Review of Basics. We have intentionally placed our ECG Crib** Sheet** in Section 00.6 before Section 01.0 â€” so that it will be easy to find.

    • For readers who are less experienced in systematic ECG interpretation â€” We suggest you refer to the ECG Crib Sheet often. Doing so will facilitate ready recall of the 6 KEY parameters (of Rate-Rhythm-Intervals-Axis-Hypertrophy-QRST Changes).
    • HINT: Making a bookmark â€” Searching for, â€œ00.6â€ â€” or simply scrolling to the front of this ePub are easy ways to rapidly access the ECG Crib Sheet.
    • Please CHECK OUT our ECG Crib Sheet!

    Â 

    NOTE-2: We have placed review of the 6 Essential** Lists** in Section 00.7. This also appears at the front of this ePub (before Section 01.0) for ready access.

    • You will want to refer to these 6 Lists often until you know them by heart. With minimal practice â€” they will be easy to remember!
    • HINT: Making a bookmark â€” Searching for, â€œ00.7â€ â€” or simply scrolling toward the front of this ePub (just after the ECG Crib Sheet) are easy ways to rapidly access the 6 Essential Lists.

    Â 

    ***The choice is YOURS ***â€” to either read through this ePub from beginning-to-end or to read selectively depending on whatever topic you are looking up.

    • Please WRITE Me! = ekgpress@mac.com. I want to know your impressions so that I can improve on what I have written.
    • I sincerely hope you enjoy this ePub and find it valuable for increasing your comfort and abilities in ECG interpretation.

    Section 00.6 â€“ ECG Crib Sheet

    00.6.1 â€“ The ECG Crib** Sheet:** How BEST to Use It

    This ePub book begins in Section 01.0 with Review of Basics. We intentionally place this ECG Crib** Sheet** before Section 01.0 â€” so that it will be easy to access.

    • For readers who are less experienced in systematic ECG interpretation â€” We suggest you refer often to this ECG Crib Sheet. This will facilitate ready** recall** of the 6 KEY parameters in the Systematic Approach (= Rate-Rhythm-Intervals-Axis-Hypertrophy-QRST Changes).
    • With regular use â€” Youâ€™ll quickly learn the information contained within this ECG Crib Sheet. In case there is something you forget â€” the Crib Sheet is always here for a quick refresher.
    • HINT: Making a bookmark â€” Searching for, â€œ00.6â€ â€” or simply scrolling to the front of this ePub are easy ways to rapidly access the ECG Crib Sheet.
    • NOTE: All parameters in our Systematic Approach to ECG interpretation are discussed in detail throughout the pages of this ePub. We begin with Section 01.0 on Review of Basics â€” and continue through to Section 14.0. We simply want you to know that this ECG Crib Sheet (Section 00.6) and Section 00.7 that follows (which reviews the 6 Essential Lists) â€” are located at the very front of this ePub in order to facilitate your ready access to this material.

    Â 

    00.6.2 â€“ The Systematic** Approach:** Rate & Rhythm

    • The first 2 parameters in the Systematic Approach are Rate and Rhythm. They are discussed in detail in Section 02.0.

    Â 

    RATE â€” If the rhythm is regular â€” rate can easily be determined by the â€œRule of 300â€. Divide 300 by the number of boxes in R-R Interval (Section 02.2).

    • IF the rhythm is regular and rapid â€” rate can be accurately estimated by the every-other-beat method (Section 02.31) â€” in which you figure out the rate for every-other-beat (which is half the rate); and then double this number.

    Â 

    RHYTHM â€” First ensure that the patient is hemodynamically stable. Then assess the 5 KEY components for rhythm. These are conveniently remembered by the phrase: ***Watch your P’s & Q’s â€” and the ***3 R’s (Section 02.1).

    • Are there P waves? If so â€” Are P waves upright in lead II?
    • P waves should always be upright in lead II IF there is sinus rhythm (unless there is lead reversal or dextrocardia).
    • Is the QRS complex wide or narrow?
    • What is the Rate?
    • Is the rhythm Regular?
    • Are P waves Related (ie, “married” with fixed PR interval) to the QRS? If P waves are â€œmarriedâ€ â€” then they are being conducted to the ventricles.

    Â 

    00.6.3 â€“ Parameter #3: Intervals

    INTERVALS â€” Look at intervals at an early point in the process!

    • The PR Interval â€” is prolonged IF >0.20-0.21 second (if clearly more than a LARGE box in duration) â€” Section 04.0.
    • The QRS Complex â€” is wide IF >0.10 sec. (*if more than HALF a large *box in duration) â€” Section 05.0.
    • The QT Interval â€” is *prolonged *IF clearly more than half the R-R interval (provided that heart rate is not more than 100 beats/minute) â€” Section 06.0. If the QT interval is prolonged â€” Think of *â€œDrugs-Lytes-CNSâ€ *(= List #3) as the possible cause(s) of QT prolongation (Section 06.2).

    Â 

    KEY Clinical Point: â€” IF the rhythm is sinus but the QRS is wide â€” then STOP before going further. Figure out WHY the QRS is wide â€” be this due to RBBB, LBBB, IVCD, WPW (Section 05.2). Criteria for infarction, ischemia, and chamber enlargement will all be different IF there is a conduction defect. This is the reason for determining early on the cause of QRS widening.

    00.6.4 â€“ Parameter #4: Axis

    • Axis is discussed in detail in Section 07.0.

    Â 

    AXIS â€”* Determine the axis quadrant by looking at *lead I (at 0 degrees) and lead aVF (at +90 degrees):

    • The axis is ***normal ***â€” IF the net QRS deflection is positive in leads I and aVF (this defines the axis to be between 0 degrees to +90 degrees).
    • There is RAD â€”*** ***IF the net QRS deflection is negative in I but positive in aVF (Think RVH, LPHB or normal variant as the common causes for RAD).
    • There is LAD â€” IF the net QRS is positive in I but negative in aVF. There is pathologic LAD = LAHB (Left Anterior HemiBlock)** â€” IF the net QRS deflection is more negative than positive in lead II (Section 07.13).
    • The axis is ***indeterminate â€” ***IF the net QRS deflection is negative in leads I and aVF (Think RVH, COPD, obesity as the common causes of an indeterminate axis).

    Â 

    00.6.5 â€“ Parameter #5: Chamber Enlargement****

    • Chamber Enlargement is discussed in detail in Section 08.0.

    Â 

    HYPERTROPHY (Chamber Enlargement):

    • The “magic numbers” for LVH are 35 (sum of the deepest S wave in V1,V2**** â€” ***plus *â€” the tallest R wave in V5,V6 â€” in a patient at least 35 years of age) â€” and 12 (for R wave amplitude in lead aVL) â€” Section 08.1. True chamber enlargement is much more likely IF “strain” also present!
    • There is RAA (P Pulmonale) â€”**** IF P waves are prominent (â‰¥2.5 mm tall) and peaked (ie, “uncomfortable to sit on”) in the pulmonary leads (II, III, and aVF) â€” Section 08.19.
    • There is LAA (P Mitrale) â€” IF P waves are notched (“m”-shaped) in mitral leads (I, II, or aVL) â€” or if the P wave in V1 has a deep terminal negative component â€” Section 08.20.
    • Consider pulmonary** disease** â€” IF there is RAA, RAD (or indeterminate axis), incomplete RBBB (or rSrâ€™ pattern in lead V1), low voltage, or persistent precordial S waves â€” Section 08.24.
    • Consider RVH â€” IF there is also a tall R wave in V1 and/or right ventricular “strain” â€” Section 08.24.
    • Criteria for LVH/RVH are different when there is BBB (Sections 05.31 and 05.32).
    • Consider acute pulmonary** embolus** â€” IF the ECG shows signs of acute right heart strain (Section 08.34).

    Â 

    00.6.6 â€“ Parameter #6: ***Infarct ***(= Q-R-S-T Changes)

    • Assessment of QRST Changes is discussed in detail in Section 09.0.

    Â 

    INFARCT (*= ***Q-R-S-T changes) â€” Look at all 12 leads on the ECG to assess for QRST Changes.

    • Lead aVR will usually be globally** negative** under normal circumstances (negative P wave, QRS and T wave). We therefore expect to see a Q wave and T wave inversion in lead aVR as part of a normal ECG.
    • The finding of an upright P, QRS and T wave in lead aVR should suggest the possibility of lead misplacement (especially if lead I manifests global negativity) â€” Section 03.10.
    • For the more experienced interpreter â€” We suggest review of Sections 09.31-through-09.39, which highlight situations for which attention to lead aVR may provide important additional information.

    Â 

    NOTE: Localization of the Basic** Lead Groups** is shown in Figure 00.6.6-1. Lead localization is discussed in detail in Section 09.4.

    Figure 00.6.6-1: Basic Lead Groups.

    Assessment of Q-R-S-T Changes:

    • Q Waves â€”**** Small and normal* ****septal **q waves are commonly seen in one or more of the lateral leads (I,aVL,V4,*V5,V6).
    • Moderate or large-sized Q waves may be normal â€”**** IF**** they occur as an isolated finding in one or more of the following leads: leads III, aVF, aVL, and/or V1. Figure 00.6.6-2 suggests that thinking of a reverse Z (as in Zorro) â€”** may help recall which leads may normally manifest a large isolated Q wave (Section 09.12).

    Â 

    Figure 00.6.6-2: Reverse Z memory aid (Q waves/T inversion).

    • R Wave Progression â€”**** Does transition occur as it normally should between leads V2-to-V4? (Figure 00.6.6-3 â€”**** Section 09.5).
    • Is there a* ****Tall R ***in Lead V1? = List #6 (Section 10.47).
    • Normally* the QRS is predominantly negative in right-sided lead V1. Is there an ****rSrâ€™ ***pattern in lead V1? (which could be a normal variant or incomplete RBBB) â€” Section 05.18.

    Â 

    Figure 00.6.6-3: Precordial lead placement. Normal R wave progression.

    • ST Segments â€”**** Judge ST segment deviation (elevation or depression)**** with respect to the PR segment baseline (Section 09.25). Much more than the amount of ST segment deviation â€” Focus on shape (“smiley” or “frowny*â€*).
    • T Waves â€”**** May normally be inverted in leads III, aVF, aVL and/or V1. Note that these are the same leads that may normally manifest isolated Q waves (Figure 00.6.6-2).
    • Remember that criteria for ischemia/infarction are different when there is BBB (Sections 05.24-through-05.29).

    Â 

    00.6.7 â€“ Suggested** Approach:** Systematic ECG Interpretation****

    As we discuss in Section 01.0 â€” Use the elements in Sections 00.6.2 through 00.6.6 as a guide for descriptive** analysis**; then formulate your clinical impression. Whenever possible â€” *WRITE *OUT (or at least think out) your findings. Above all, even when time is short â€” BE systematic!

    Section 00.7 â€“ The 6 Essential Lists

    00.7.1 â€“ The 6 Lists: What They Are â€¦

    We have developed 6 ***Essential ***â€œListsâ€ to remember for optimal ECG and arrhythmia interpretation. The purpose of a â€œListâ€ â€” is that it readily recalls the most common/important causes to remember for the particular entity. For example â€” as soon as you recognize that the QT interval is prolonged â€” *Think â€œDrugs-Lytes-CNSâ€ as possible causes *(= LIST #3).

    • We intentionally limit the number (and length) of our lists so as *not *to overwhelm. Use of these 6 Lists will prove *invaluable *to you in saving time and improving the accuracy of your interpretation.
    • You will want to refer to these 6 Lists often until you know them by heart. With minimal practice â€” they will be easy to remember!

    Â 

    For clarity (and easy reference) â€” we reproduce the 6 Lists here. Youâ€™ll find them again intermingled with relevant content throughout this electronic file.

    • HINT: Making a bookmark â€” Searching for, â€œ00.7â€ â€” or simply scrolling to the front of this ePub are convenient ways to instantly access the 6 Essential Lists (The 6 Lists are found just after the ECG Crib Sheet).

    Â 

    00.7.2 â€“ LIST #1: The Common** Causes of a** ***Regular ***WCT:

    • LIST #1 is discussed in detail in Section 02.47.
    • KEY Point: The 1st thing to do in assessment of any tachycardia â€” is to ensure hemodynamic** stability**. IF the patient is unstable â€” immediately cardiovert! But IF the patient in WCT (Wide-Complex Tachycardia) is stable â€” you have at least a *moment *of time to contemplate management.
    • Always assume a regular WCT rhythm is VT until** proven otherwise** (Figure 00.7.2-1). This is true regardless of whether the patient is hypotensive or alert with a systolic BP>160mmHg. Some patients may be stable and alert despite remaining in VT for hours (or even days)!
    • The reason we list VT as the first** 8 causes** in LIST #1 (Figure 00.7.2-1) is twofold: i) VT is the worst thing the WCT could be; and ii) Statistically â€” at least 80-90% of cases of WCT of uncertain etiology will turn out to be VT.

    Â 

    Figure 00.7.2-1: LIST #1 = Causes of a Monomorphic Regular WCT. Always assume VT until proven otherwise.

    00.7.3 â€“ LIST #2: Common Causes of a ***Regular ***SVT:

    • LIST #2 is discussed in detail in Section 02.52.
    • We define the term, â€œSVTâ€ â€” as a rapid rhythm (rate >100/minute) in which the QRS complex is narrow (not more than 0.10 second) in all 12 leads. The 3 entities included in LIST #2 (Figure 00.7.3-1) make up over 90% of the causes of a regular** SVT** seen by primary care or emergency providers.

    Â 

    Awareness of the usual rate** ranges** for these 3 common causes of SVT may help with distinction between them:

    • Sinus Tachycardia â€” *rarely *exceeds 160/minute in adults (children may have sinus tachycardia at much faster rates).
    • ***Untreated **Atrial Flutter â€” usually conducts with 2:1 ratio. Since the atrial rate of untreated atrial flutter is almost always close to 300/minute (250-350/minute is the range) â€” *this means that the ventricular response to AFlutter will usually be between 140-to-160/minute.
    • As a result â€” IF a regular SVT in an adult is faster than 160-170/minute â€” it is most likely to be PSVT (= AVNRT = AtrioVentricular Nodal Reentry Tachycardia).
    • On the other hand â€”* *A regular SVT rhythm at a rate under 160-170/minute could be any of the 3 entities on LIST #2 (Fig. 00.7.3-1).
    • NOTE: A vagal maneuver or use of Adenosine* (= chemical Valsalva*) â€” may help in making a definitive diagnosis.

    Â 

    Figure 00.7.3-1: LIST #2 = Causes of a Regular SVT.

    00.7.4 â€“ LIST #3: Common Causes of QT Prolongation:

    • LIST #3 is discussed in detail in Section 06.2.
    • Be aware that in addition to the 3 entities in LIST #3 (Figure 00.7.4-1) â€” ischemia/MI/BBB may all lengthen the QT. That said â€” IF the only ECG abnormality on the tracing is a *long *QT â€” *Think *â€œDrugs-Lytes-CNSâ€ as the likely cause. Then â€” correlate clinically.
    • NOTE: Many combinations of drugs may contribute to lengthening the QT interval. These potential drug-drug interactions extend beyond the scope of this ECG-ePub and are not reflected in List #3. Suffice it to say that risk of QT prolongation (and risk of Torsades) is generally minimal â€” IF an otherwise healthy adult takes a single new drug for a limited period of time. Risk goes up when several agents are taken â€” especially if the drugs utilize the p450 system for metabolism and the patient has other underlying medical problems that may predispose to Torsades. BOTTOM Line: Consider the possibility of Drugs (or drug-drug interactions) â€” as one of the main clinical causes of QT prolongation.

    Â 

    Figure 00.7.4-1: LIST #3 = Causes of a Prolonged QT.

    00.7.5 â€“ LIST #4: Common Causes of ST Segment Depression:

    • LIST #4 is discussed in detail in Section 09.26.
    • There are over 50 causes of ST depression. Many of these causes are noncardiac â€” related to factors such as hyperventilation, temperature extremes, severe medical illness. The entities in LIST #4 (Figure 00.7.5-1) â€” are simply the ones we feel it most important to remember.
    • A similar list of entities as shown in List #4 may produce T wave inversion.

    Â 

    Figure 00.7.5-1: LIST #4 = Causes of ST Depression.

    00.7.6 â€“ LIST #5: Causes of Anterior** ST Depression with** ***Inferior ***MI:

    • LIST #5 is discussed in detail in Section 10.42.
    • Use of** LIST #5** (Figure 00.7.6-1) is limited to the setting of acute inferior** STEMI**. The purpose of List #5 is to remind us of the 3 common** causes** of anterior** ST depression** in this situation.
    • Helpful General Rule: The more ST depression that is seen on the ECG â€” the more likely the MI is both acute and large.
    • Clinically â€” we may not be able to determine with certainty *which *of the 3 entities in List #5 is/are operative. This does not matter! What counts is awareness of a more extensive MI (that is more likely to benefit from acute intervention) â€” when significant anterior ST depression is seen in conjunction with acute inferior infarction.

    Â 

    Figure 00.7.6-1: LIST #5 = Causes of Anterior ST Depression in the Setting of Acute Inferior MI.

    00.7.7 â€“ LIST #6: Common Causes of a ***Tall ***R in Lead V1:

    • LIST #6 is discussed in detail in Section 10.47.
    • Normally the QRS is predominantly *negative *(a *QS *or rS complex) in right-sided lead V1. As a result, the finding of even a *relatively *tall R wave in lead V1 (that equals or exceeds S wave amplitude in this lead) â€” should prompt consideration of the 6 entities on LIST #6 (Figure 00.7.7-1).
    • Determining which of the 6 entities in List #6 is present â€” is decided by assessing associated ECG findings. A normal variant (Cause #6) should be considered only after the first 5 causes have been ruled out.
    • Not all patients need an Echo. On occasion, however â€” an Echo may be needed to rule out structural heart disease (especially if hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a consideration).

    Â 

    Figure 00.7.7-1: LIST #6 = Causes of a Tall R Wave in Lead V1.

    Section 01.0 â€“ Review of Basics

    01.1 â€“ Systematic** Approach to 12-Lead ECG Interpretation**

    The KEY to interpretation of any ECG is to utilize a Systematic Approach. The approach we suggest for interpreting each 12-lead ECG you encounter entails sequential* *systematic assessment of the following parameters:

    • Rate
    • Rhythm
    • Intervals **(***PR/QRS/QT *)
    • Axis
    • Hypertrophy
    • Infarct **(**QRST changes )

    Â 

    We outline KEY elements to assess for each of the above parameters on our ECG Crib Sheet (See Section 00.6). Discussion here is limited to the following:

    • The purpose of having (and regularly using) a sequential systematic approach is simple: It provides you with an easy-to-remember mental checklist that prevents you from overlooking potentially important findings.
    • Additional benefits include increased accuracy, improved organization, and surprisingly â€” increased speed in completing your interpretation. With regular use â€” applying the system soon becomes automatic!**

    Â 

    01.2 â€“ The 2 Steps to Systematic** Interpretation**

    The process of 12-lead ECG interpretation should be thought of as consisting of two** major steps**. The secret to successful interpretation depends on keeping these 2 steps separate in your mind:

    • Step #1 = Descriptive Analysis**** â€” is accomplished first: Simply describe what is seen on the tracing (as per the checklist review on the ECG Crib Sheet in Section 00.6). Ideally â€” *WRITE OUT *your findings (or at least THINK out your findings if you do not have time to write them out).
    • Step #2 = The Clinical Impression**** â€” should only come after Step #1 has been completed. Those specific findings identified in descriptive analysis should now be interpreted in light of the clinical context (ie, as defined by the patient’s age, presenting complaint, and additional relevant clinical history).

    Â 

    01.3 â€“ WHY** 2** Separate** Steps for Interpretation?**

    Review of the*** ***ECG shown in Figure 01.3-1 provides insight as to why there is need for 2 separate steps to interpretation.

    Figure 01.3-1: How would you interpret this 12-lead ECG?

    Answer to Figure 01.3-1: We interpret the 12-lead ECG shown above by the 2-Step Systematic Approach:

    Step #1**** (Descriptive** Analysis**):

    • Rate and Rhythm â€” Sinus arrhythmia at a rate of between 60-70 beats/minute.
    • Intervals (PR/QRS/QT) â€” are normal.
    • Axis â€” There is RAD (Right Axis Deviation) with a mean QRS axis of ~ +100 degrees.
    • Hypertrophy â€” None.
    • Q-R-S-T changes â€” Small Q waves**** in inferolateral leads; R wave progression is normal (transition occurs between leads V3-4); Assessment of ST-T wave changes reveals fairly deep symmetric** T wave inversion** in anterior** precordial leads** (*arrows in *Fig. 01.3-1).

    Â 

    Step #2**** (Clinical** Impression**) â€” It depends! That is â€” How we would interpret the ECG in Figure 01.3-1 will vary greatly depending on the age and clinical history of the patient.

    • Symmetric T wave inversion as seen in the anterior leads (V1,V2,V3) of Fig. 01.3-1 is common in pediatric patients. In an otherwise healthy child (with no heart murmur) â€” this finding represents a benign normal variant (referred to as a Juvenile** T Wave Pattern**).
    • BUT â€” the same ECG (with identical T wave inversion) would have to be interpreted very* differently IF the patient in question was an older adult with chest pain (in which case ischemia would be suggested). And, if new-onset dyspnea was the primary concern from the history â€” acute pulmonary* embolism** would also have to be considered (Section 08.34).
    • KEY Clinical Point: ***Descriptive **Analysis *is the same in both cases (= symmetric T wave inversion in V1-to-V3) â€” but the Clinical Impression is very different!

    Â 

    Bottom Line: â€” Keep Steps #1 and 2 separate in your mind. Always do Descriptive Analysis first! Then â€” decide on your Clinical Impression of the findings identified in light of the clinical situation (age of patient; clinical history).

    02.0 â€“ Rate & Rhythm

    02.1 â€“ Assessing** the 5 Parameters of Rhythm**

    The most important clinical point (and the real KEY to rhythm interpretation) â€” is to utilize a Systematic Approach. The system we favor is based on assessing the rhythm for the following 5 parameters:

    • P waves?
    • QRS width ?
    • Regular rhythm ?
    • Related **(**P waves related to QRS ? )
    • Rate **(**heart rate ? )

    Â 

    Memory Aid (to remember the 5 Parameters):* *

    • “Watch your P’s and Q’s â€” and* the 3 R’s”* â€¦

    Â 

    NOTE: It does not matter in what sequence you look at these 5 parameters for rhythm â€” as long as you always check each of them every time you look at an ECG or rhythm strip! We often begin with that parameter that is easiest to assess (be this presence of P waves, QRS width or regularity).

    • First â€” Ensure that the patient is hemodynamically stable (precise rhythm diagnosis is of secondary importance if the patient is acutely decompensating and about to code). Always look at the patient first â€” before beginning to study the rhythm.
    • IF there is normal sinus rhythm â€” then P waves should be present and clearly upright in lead II (See Section 02.3).
    • In adults, the QRS is defined as ***narrow ***â€” IF it is â‰¤0.10 second = not more than HALF a large box in duration (Figure 02.1-1).

    Â 

    Figure 02.1-1: Is the QRS wide? Normally in adults â€” the QRS should not be more than half a large box in duration (= not more than 0.10 second).

    • Regularity â€” Look to see IF the rhythm is regular?
    • Determine if P waves are ”Related" to QRS complexes (ie, conducting) â€” Look in front of each QRS to see IF there is a P wave with a**** fixed** PR** interval.
    • Rate â€” is most easily calculated by the Rule of 300 (Section 02.2).

    Â 

    02.2 â€“ Calculating** Rate:** The Rule of 300

    Provided that the rhythm is regular â€” the Rule of 300 states that heart rate can be estimated IF you divide 300 by the number of large boxes** in the R-R interval.**** The rule is derived as follows:****

    • With the ECG machine set at the standard recording speed of 25 mm/second â€” the time required to record each little box on ECG grid paper is 0.04 second (Figure 02.2-1). Vertically â€” each little box is 1 mm in amplitude (a measurement we will use often in assessing for chamber enlargement).
    • As seen in Figure 02.2-1 â€” the time required to record each large box on ECG grid paper is 0.20 second. That**** is**** â€”**** there are 5 little** boxes** in each large** box**, and 5 X 0.04 second = 0.20 second ( = 1/5th of a second**)**.

    Â 

    Figure 02.2-1:* Deriving* the â€œRule of 300â€ (See text).

    Thus, the time required to record** 5** large** boxes** will be one full second (0.20 X 5 = 1.0 sec). IF a QRS complex occurs each large box (as in Figure 02.2-1) â€” then the R-R interval will be 0.20 second â€” and the rate of the rhythm is 300 beats/minute (ie, 5 beats occur each second X 60 seconds/minute =** a rate of 300/minute).

    • IF the R-R interval is 2 large boxes â€” then the rate will be half as fast (ie, 300 Ã· 2 = 150 beats/minute).
    • IF the R-R is 3 boxes, the rate = 100/minute (300/3).
    • IF the R-R is 4 boxes, the rate = 75/min (300/4) â€¦

    Â 

    NOTE: â€” Use the every-other-beat** method** when the rhythm is regular and the rate is fast (See Section 02.31).

    02.3 â€“ How to Define Sinus Rhythm?

    By definition (under normal circumstances, assuming the heart lies in the left side of the thorax) â€” the P wave should always be upright in standard lead II when the mechanism of the rhythm is sinus. This is because the overall direction of the electrical depolarization wavefront as it travels from the SA node toward the AV node and the ventricles is oriented toward standard lead II, which lies at +60 degrees in the frontal plane (Panel A* in *Figure 02.3-1).

    • The only 2 exceptions to the above stated rule (ie, when the rhythm may still be sinus despite a negative P wave in lead II) are: i) if there is dextrocardia; or ii) if there is lead misplacement.

    Â 

    Figure 02.3-1:* *IF the rhythm is sinus â€” then the P wave should always be upright in lead II (Panel A). The only exception is IF there is dextrocardia or lead misplacement. Therefore â€” Panel B is not a sinus rhythm (See text).

    In contrast to the situation with sinus rhythm â€” the P wave will not be positive (upright) in lead II when the electrical impulse originates from the AV node (Panel B* in *Figure 02.3-1). Instead â€” spread of atrial activation is now directed away from lead II.

    • Therefore, with junctional beats or junctional (AV nodal) rhythm â€” a negative** P wave** may be seen to precede the QRS complex in lead II (Panel B in Fig. 02.3-1).
    • Alternatively (with AV nodal rhythm) â€” a negative P wave may follow the QRS or no P wave at all is seen in lead II.

    Â 

    02.4 â€“ FIGURE 02.4-1: Is the Rhythm Sinus?

    Interpret the 3 rhythm strips shown in Figure 02.4-1.

    • How can you tell at a glance IF the rhythm is sinus? (Assume no dextrocardia and no lead misplacement).

    Â 

    Figure 02.4-1:* How to tell* IF the rhythm is sinus?

    Answer to Figure 02.4-1: The very **1st thing we do when assessing any cardiac rhythm or 12-lead ECG is to look for a lead II rhythm strip. It takes no more than 2 brief seconds to look in front of each QRS in lead II.

    • Panel A (in Figure 02.4-1)**** â€” Regular upright P waves precede each QRS with fixed PR interval in this lead II. Therefore â€” there is NSR (Normal Sinus Rhythm). The QRS is narrow (not more than half a large box) â€” and the ventricular rhythm is regular with an R-R interval just under 4 large boxes in duration. IF the R-R interval was precisely 4 large boxes in duration â€” then by the Rule of 300 the rate would be 300/4 = 75/minute (Section 02.2). Since the R-R interval is slightly less than 4 large boxes in duration â€” the rate must be slightly faster than 75/minute, or about 78/minute.
    • Panel B (in Figure 02.4-1)**** â€” does not represent sinus rhythm. It canâ€™t (provided there is no dextrocardia or lead misplacement) â€” since the QRS in lead II is not preceded by an upright P wave. Whether the rhythm in Panel B represents AV nodal or low atrial rhythm is less important. The KEY point â€” is that the rhythm is not sinus!
    • Otherwise â€” the QRS is narrow and the rhythm is regular with an R-R interval of 4 large boxes in duration. Therefore â€” the rate = 300/4 = 75/minute. The negative P waves in this lead II are conducting â€” because the PR interval preceding each QRS is fixed!
    • Panel C (in Figure 02.4-1)**** â€” is not a sinus rhythm (since no P wave at all is seen). The QRS is narrow and the rhythm is regular with an R-R interval of 6 large boxes. Therefore, the rate = 300/6 = 50/minute. This is an AV nodal** rhythm** (See Sections 02.32-to 02.34).

    Â 

    02.5 â€“ ***Sinus Mechanism ***Rhythms/Arrhythmias

    Once the mechanism of the rhythm is defined as â€œsinusâ€ â€” the rate (and regularity) of the rhythm determine our terminology. There are 4 principal sinus mechanism rhythms (Figure 02.5-1):

    • NSR (Normal Sinus Rhythm) â€” regular rhythm with a rate between 60-99/minute in an adult (Panel A in Figure 02.5-1). Norms for rate differ in children (Section 02.6).
    • Sinus Bradycardia â€” regular sinus rhythm at a rate *below *60/minute (Panel B). The rate here is 50/minute.
    • Sinus Tachycardia â€” sinus rhythm at a rate of 100/minute or faster in an adult (Panel C in Fig. 02.5-1).
    • Sinus Arrhythmia â€” an irregular rhythm despite the presence of a sinus mechanism (Figure 02.7-1 â€” Section 02.7).

    Â 

    Figure 02.5-1:* *Sinus mechanism rhythms (See text).

    02.6 â€“ Norms for Children: Different than Adults

    Normal limits for heart rate are different in children. While we primarily concern ourselves with the adult ECG in this book â€” it is nevertheless helpful to be aware of some differences between pediatric and adult findings.

    • Rate limits are different in children â€” with â€œnormsâ€ depending on the age of the child. Much more important than specific â€œcut-offâ€ points for each age category â€” is appreciation of the general concept that slightly faster rates (say ~110/minute) may be normal for a crying but otherwise healthy young child. By the same token â€” a rate within the â€œseemingly normalâ€ range of 65/minute might be relatively slow for an active young child. Clinical context is everything!
    • Upper limits for PR and QRS interval duration are also different (shorter) in the smaller pediatric heart (Section 04.3).
    • Similarly â€”*** â€œEscapeâ€***** rate ranges** differ in children. Whereas the normal AV nodal escape** rate** in an adult is between 40-to-60/minute â€” it is between 50-80/minute in a young child. Therefore, the AV nodal rhythm at 75/minute seen below in Figure 02.6-1 would be slightly fast IF the patient was an adult â€” but is clearly within the normal AV nodal escape rate range IF the patient is a child (See also Sections 02.32-to-02.34 on AV nodal rhythms).

    Â 

    Figure 02.6-1:* *AV nodal rhythm at 75/minute (See text).

    02.7 â€“ Sinus Arrhythmia

    Sinus Arrhythmia is a common normal** variant** in infants and young children. At times, variability in sinus rate may be marked â€” in which case one might initially think some other arrhythmia is present.

    • Sinus Arrhythmia â€” is confirmed by the finding of identical-appearing P waves that are upright in lead II with fixed PR interval (Figure 02.7-1). In contrast â€” other phenomena (wandering atrial pacemaker; sinus rhythm with PACs) will manifest changes in P wave morphology and/or in the PR interval. The P waves will be different!

    Â 

    Figure 02.7-1:* *Sinus Arrhythmia. Despite irregularity in the rhythm â€” sinus mechanism is present as defined by regularly-occurring upright P waves with fixed PR interval preceding each QRS complex in this lead II rhythm strip (See text).

    • Sinus arrhythmia often exhibits respiratory** variation**. This is especially true in healthy young children â€” for whom some variation in sinus regularity is the norm rather than the exception. Sinus â€œarrhythmiaâ€ is a normal cardiac rhythm in this setting.
    • Some degree of sinus variability (ie, sinus arrhythmia) may persist in young and even older adults. This is not necessarily abnormal. Clinical correlation is key.

    Â 

    Beyond-the-Core: The technical definition of sinus â€œarrhythmiaâ€ â€” is that sinus-initiated R-R intervals vary by at least 0.08-0.12 second (2-3 little boxes). This definition is clearly satisfied in Figure 02.7-1. That said, most of the time â€” the presence of sinus â€œarrhythmiaâ€ (vs sinus rhythm) is of little-to-no clinical significance.

    • An exception to the statement that sinus arrhythmia is benign occurs in older patients with SSS (Sick Sinus Syndrome). Among the many manifestations of SSS (which include sinus pauses, sinus arrest, tachy- as well as bradyarrhythmias) â€” sinus bradycardia with** sinus arrhythmia** is the most common. The usual course of SSS is prolonged over years (if not decades). Many patients who go on to develop full-fledged symptoms (with need for a permanent pacemaker) manifest no more than sinus bradycardia/sinus arrhythmia for a period of many years. Therefore â€” the finding of an inappropriately slow and variable sinus rhythm in an older patient with symptoms of fatigue, worsening heart failure and/or syncope/presyncope is cause for potential concern. IF not due to rate-slowing drugs, ischemia or hypothyroidism â€” Consider SSS as the probable cause.

    Â 

    02.8 â€“ FIGURE 02.8-1: What Happens to the P in Lead II?

    Although specifics of the rhythm diagnosis in Figure 02.8-1 are advanced â€” the concept of routinely seeking out a long** lead II** rhythm strip each time you interpret a 12-lead ECG is fundamental! Always begin with this step.

    Figure 02.8-1:* What happens* to the P wave in this lead II rhythm strip? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 02.8-1: Use the Ps, Qs & 3R Approach to assess the rhythm. As noted Section 02.1 â€” it does not matter in what sequence you look at the 5 parameters (as long as you check them all each time you assess an ECG):

    • The overall rhythm in Figure 02.8-1 is not regular.
    • The QRS complex is narrow.
    • Each QRS is preceded by a P wave â€” BUT the shape of these P waves is not the same. The rhythm begins with a taller peaked P wave with fixed PR interval preceding beats #1,2,3; and #7,8. A 2nd P wave shape (of smaller amplitude and notched) â€” is then seen to precede beats #4,5,6. Thus, the underlying rhythm in Figure 02.8-1 is sinus arrhythmia â€” with transient change to another atrial focus for beats #4,5,6 â€” followed by resumption of the original sinus focus at the end of the tracing.

    Â 

    Key** Points about Figure 02.8-1:** In our experience â€” the most common error in 12-lead ECG interpretation is failure to recognize when normal sinus rhythm is not present. The solution is easy:

    • Ideally â€” there will be a simultaneously recorded long** lead II** rhythm strip. IF so â€” Begin by:** i)** assessing IF the rhythm is regular; and ii) Looking to see IF P wave morphology stays the same throughout the rhythm strip.
    • It suffices to recognize that the underlying rhythm in Figure 02.8-1 is sinus with a change in P wave morphology. It is easy to see this as long as you consciously look at P wave shape before each QRS.
    • It is clearly more difficult without a long lead rhythm strip. How would you* assess the rhythm* in Figure 02.9-1?

    Â 

    02.9 â€“ FIGURE 02.9-1: When there is NO long Lead II Rhythm Strip â€¦

    The reality is â€” that you will not always have access to a long lead rhythm strip. This was the case for the 12-lead ECG previously shown in Figure 01.3-1 (Section 01.3). We reproduce that 12-lead tracing below in Figure 02.9-1:

    • How would you assess the rhythm in Figure 02.9-1?
    • How many total** beats** are there on this 12-lead ECG?

    Â 

    Figure 02.9-1:* *12-lead ECG previously shown in Figure 01.3-1. How many total beats are there on this tracing? What is the rhythm? Unfortunately â€” there is no long lead II rhythm strip (See text).

    Answer to Figure 02.9-1: The problem is that only 3 beats are seen in lead II of this ECG (arrows) before the leads switch to simultaneous recording of leads aVR/aVL/aVF. In addition â€” the R-R interval for these 3 beats that are seen in lead II is not the same (ie, the R-R interval between beats #1-2 is longer than the R-R between beats #2-3). That said, we can still diagnose the mechanism as sinus â€” because a similarly-shaped upright P wave with fixed PR interval precedes each of these 3 beats in lead II (red arrows in Figure 02.9-1).

    • There are 9 total** beats** on this tracing. With simultaneous 3-channel recordings â€” we get â€œ3 looksâ€ at each beat (vertical time line in leads I â€“ II â€“ III ). The QRS is narrow. Note irregularity of the R-R interval for beats #1-thru-9. Thus â€” the rhythm is sinus arrhythmia.

    Â 

    02.10 â€“ ***Advanced ***POINT: What is a Wandering Pacemaker?

    Occasionally â€” the site of the atrial pacemaker may shift (wander) away from its usual site of origin in the SA (Sino-Atrial) Node. In most cases â€” wandering** atrial pacemaker** is a benign normal variant that occurs in patients without underlying heart disease. It may result from variations in vagal tone (that slow SA nodal discharge and allow other atrial sites to temporarily emerge) â€” or there may be no obvious cause (Figure 02.10-1).

    • ECG recognition of wandering pacer requires a long enough rhythm strip to appreciate gradual change over a period of beats from one P wave morphology to another. While possible that the rhythm in Figure 02.8-1 could reflect a wandering pacemaker â€” this rhythm strip is simply not long enough to tell.

    Â 

    Figure 02.10-1:* *Wandering pacemaker. Initially the P wave in lead II is an upright sinus complex (1st red arrow preceding beat #4) â€” with gradual change to an isoelectric P wave (1st blue arrow preceding beat #5) â€” followed by resumption of sinus rhythm with beat #17 (2nd red arrow in bottom rhythm strip). It would be easy-to-overlook the diagnosis of wandering pacer IF one did not pay careful attention to P wave morphology!

    Bottom Line: True wandering** atrial pacemaker** is not a common diagnosis. As noted â€” it is difficult to recognize because most 12-lead ECGs (even if accompanied by a simultaneous lead II rhythm strip) will simply not be long enough to manifest gradual transition back-and-forth between SA node and two or more additional atrial sites. The point to emphasize for interpreters of any experience level â€” is the need to always look carefully at lead II when assessing for atrial activity:

    • Is an upright sinus P wave present in lead II?
    • Does P wave morphology change during the rhythm?
    • Is the underlying rhythm regular? Are there any early beats?

    Â 

    02.11 â€“ FIGURE 02.11-1: Why is this NOT Wandering Pacer?

    While not yet worrying about the specific diagnosis â€” Why is wandering pacer not present in Figure 02.11-1?

    Figure 02.11-1:* *Why is wandering pacemaker not present in either of the rhythm strips shown here?

    Answer to Figure 02.11-1: The rhythm in Panel A is MAT (See Section 02.16). There are too many different P waves that change from beat-to-beat for this to be wandering pacer. In Panel B â€” the underlying rhythm is sinus. Beats #3 and #6 are PACs; they occur early â€” and P shape is different (See Section 02.56).

    • True wandering pacemaker should manifest gradual transition from one P wave morphology to another â€” and then either on to yet another atrial pacemaker site or back to the original focus. This gradual transition was seen in Figure 02.10-1. It is definitely not seen in either Panel A or B of Figure 02.11-1.

    Â 

    02.12 â€“ ***Other ***Supraventricular Rhythms

    A *supraventricular *rhythm is defined to be one in which the electrical impulse originates at or above the AV node (at or above the double dotted line in Figure 02.12-1).

    • The â€œgood newsâ€ â€” is that the number of sites from where a supraventricular impulse may arise is limited. These include: i) the SA Node; ii) from somewhere in the atria; or iii) the AV node. Awareness of this clinical reality greatly facilitates arrhythmia diagnosis because once you establish that the QRS complex in an adult is truly narrow in all 12 leads â€” you are virtually assured that the rhythm is supraventricular (>99% of the time)!
    • The exception (occurs 0.1% of the time) â€” in which a narrow QRS may arise from a ventricular site in an adult is IF the impulse originates from the His, fascicles or bundle branches.
    • The above generality does not hold true in children (the QRS is normally narrower in the smaller pediatric heart).

    Â 

    Figure 02.12-1:* *IF the QRS is truly narrow in all 12 leads â€” then for practical purposes the rhythm is supraventricular (and therefore originates from at or above the double dotted red line in this Figure). NOTE: The opposite is not true. That is â€” the etiology of a rhythm is not at all certain IF the QRS is wide (could be either ventricular or supraventricular â€” *See *Figure 02.13-1).

    Other Supraventricular Rhythms: In addition to the sinus mechanism rhythms** (Section 02.5) â€” the other principal entities in the supraventricular rhythm category include:

    • AFib (Atrial Fibrillation) â€” See Section 02.14.
    • MAT (Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia) â€” See Section 02.16.
    • AFlutter (Atrial Flutter) â€” See Section 02.18.
    • PSVT/AVNRT â€” See Section 02.29.
    • Junctional (AV nodal) rhythms â€” See Sections 02.32-to-02.34.

    Â 

    NOTE: Although there are many types of supraventricular rhythms â€” those listed above make up the great majority of rhythms that primary care and emergency providers most often will see.

    • Unless there is preexisting bundle branch block or aberrant conduction â€” the QRS will be narrow IF the rhythm is supraventricular.

    Â 

    02.13 â€“ FIGURE 02.13-1: Why is this Rhythm Supraventricular?

    Despite the slow rate and very wide QRS complex â€” WHY is the rhythm in Figure 02.13-1 supraventricular?

    Figure 02.13-1:* *Despite the wide QRS â€” Why is this rhythm supraventricular?

    Answer to Figure 02.13-1: By the Ps, Qs & 3R Approach â€” We interpret the rhythm in Figure 02.13-1 as follows:

    • Regular wide QRS rhythm at ~40/minute.
    • Upright P waves precede each QRS complex with a fixed and normal PR interval in this lead II rhythm strip. Therefore â€” the rhythm is sinus bradycardia with QRS widening as a result of preexisting BBB (Bundle Branch Block).

    Â 

    02.14 â€“ Atrial** Fibrillation**

    AFib (Atrial Fibrillation) â€” is characterized by the presence of an irregularly irregular rhythm in the absence of P waves (Figure 02.14-1). Undulations in the baseline (known as â€œfibâ€ waves) may sometimes be seen. Such â€œfib wavesâ€ are coarse in Tracing B of Fig. 02.14-1 â€” fine in Tracing C â€” and are barely detectable in Tracing A.

    • As might be imagined â€” the diagnosis of AFib is clearly more difficult when â€œfib wavesâ€ are of minimal amplitude (in which case diagnosis is based solely on recognizing an irregularly irregular rhythm in the absence of P waves).

    Â 

    Figure 02.14-1: Atrial fibrillation (See text).

    KEY Clinical Point: Far better than simply saying the rhythm is â€œAFibâ€ â€” is to clarify the ventricular response. Thus, AFib will conduct with either a rapid, controlled, or slow ventricular response:

    • AFib with a rapid ventricular response is present â€” IF the average rate is over ~120/minute (Tracing A in Fig. 02.14-1). New-onset AFib is most often rapid (unless slowed by drugs, ischemia/infarction or sick sinus syndrome).
    • AFib with a controlled ventricular response is present â€” IF the average rate of AFib is between ~70-110/minute (Tracing B in Fig. 02.14-1). An important goal of medical treatment is to attain rate control.
    • AFib with a slow ventricular response is present â€” IF the average rate is less than 50-60/minute (Tracing C). New-onset slow AFib is unusual â€” and should suggest a different set of diagnostic consideration (rate-slowing drugs; hypothyroidism; ischemia/infarction; sick sinus).

    Â 

    Clinical PEARL: When AFib is rapid â€” the irregularity in the rhythm may be subtle. As a result â€” rapid AFib may sometimes simulate PSVT. We see this toward the end of Tracing A (in Fig. 02.14-1).

    • Calipers may be needed to verify that the rhythm is in fact irregular throughout the tracing.

    Â 

    **02.15 â€“ Advanced POINT: Very Fast AFib â€” Think WPW!

    The usual rate range for **â€œrapidâ€ A Fib is between ~110-180/minute. IF ever the rate of A Fib is significantly above this (ie, >200-220/minute) â€” the patient probably has an AP (Accessory Pathway) that is *bypassing *the AV node (ie, WPW = Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome).

    • The intrinsic refractory period of the normal AV node generally does not allow conduction of more than 200-220 impulses per minute.

    Â 

    Figure 02.15-1: The QRS complex is wide. AFib is diagnosed by the irregular irregularity in the absence of P waves. The rate attains 250-300/minute in parts of the tracing. This is virtually diagnostic of WPW (See Section 05.49).

    02.16 â€“ Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia

    AFib should be distinguished from ***MAT *(Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia) **â€” in which the rhythm is also irregularly irregular, but in which definite P waves are present (arrows in Figure 02.16-1). Note that P wave morphology changes from beat-to-beat with MAT â€” which is what distinguishes MAT from wandering atrial pacemaker (See Figure 02.10-1). The name tells all about its ECG appearance: Multiple Atrial foci (P waves) are seen at a fast rate (ie, Tachycardia).

    • In our experience â€” MAT is the 2nd most commonly overlooked arrhythmia diagnosis (next to AFlutter). MAT is easy to overlook â€” because the overwhelming majority of sustained irregular SVT rhythms are AFib.
    • Clinically â€” MAT is most often seen in patients who have either: i) pulmonary disease or ii) severe multisystem problems (sepsis, shock, acidosis, electrolyte abnormalities, etc.). The best way to avoid overlooking MAT is to think of this diagnosis whenever you see an irregularly irregular rhythm in either of the above settings.
    • 12 leads are better than one. You may not always see different P wave shapes in a single monitoring lead. Get a 12-lead ECG and look for atrial activity in all 12 leads.

    Â 

    Figure 02.16-1: MAT is distinguished from AFib by the presence of multiple different-looking P waves. The importance of recognizing MAT is its different treatment (Section 02.17).

    02.17 â€“ FIGURE 02.17-1: Why is this Not AFib?

    Why is the irregularly rhythm seen in Figure 02.17-1 not AFib? HINT: This ECG was obtained from a patient with COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease).

    • Can you see atrial activity in some of the 12 leads? If so â€” in which ones?
    • Clinically â€” Why is it important to make the correct rhythm diagnosis?

    Â 

    Figure 02.17-1: What is the rhythm on this 12-lead ECG? What else do you see on this tracing that supports your rhythm diagnosis? 152

    Answer to Figure 02.17-1: The rhythm is irregularly irregular. The QRS complex is narrow. The rhythm in Fig. 02.17-1 is not AFib â€” because P waves are clearly seen in lead II. P waves are also seen in leads III and aVF â€” but not in other leads.

    • P wave morphology in lead II changes from beat to beat. This observation plus knowing this patient has COPD helps to solidify the ECG rhythm diagnosis of MAT.
    • Additional support of the diagnosis of MAT is forthcoming from recognition of several ECG findings that suggest significant pulmonary disease. These include: i) Schamrothâ€™s sign (very low QRST amplitude in lead I); ii) tall pointed P waves in lead II among the P wave morphologies seen; and iii) persistence of precordial S waves through to V5,V6 (See Section 08.33).
    • The clinical importance of recognizing MAT (and distinguishing it from AFib) â€” is that treatment of these two entities is different!*** Treatment of* MAT** â€” is best directed at correcting the underlying cause (optimizing oxygenation in this case). In contrast â€” Treatment of AFib focuses on rate control; converting the rhythm; and anticoagulation considerations.

    Â 

    KEY Clinical Point: Rather than a discrete entity â€” think of MAT as part of a spectrum. At one end â€” is sinus rhythm with occasional PACs (Tracing B in Figure 02.11-1). At the other â€” is MAT in which P wave morphology (and the PR interval) change from beat-to-beat. Along the way you may see sinus rhythm with multiple PACs (but not quite enough beat-to-beat change to diagnose â€œMATâ€).

    • Clinically â€” implications of the various arrhythmias that may be seen throughout this spectrum are similar. These are to diagnose and treat the underlying disorder as first priority (usually hypoxemia from pulmonary disease; electrolyte or acid-base disturbance; other metabolic problems).

    Â 

    02.18 â€“ Atrial Flutter

    AFlutter (Atrial Flutter) â€” is characterized by a special pattern of regular atrial activity that in adults *almost *always (and almost magically) occurs at a rate of 300/minute (250-350/minute = usual range). Atrial flutter typically manifests a sawtooth appearance that is usually best seen in the inferior leads â€” although at times, flutter waves may be subtle and only seen in a few leads (Figure 02.18-1).

    • The most common ventricular response to atrial flutter (by far!) is with 2:1 AV conduction. As a result, the ventricular rate with untreated atrial flutter will usually be close to 150/minute (ie, ~300 Ã· 2). NOTE: The atrial rate may slower IF antiarrhythmic drugs are used.
    • Less commonly with AFlutter there is 4:1 AV conduction (ventricular rate ~75/minute) â€” or a variable (= irregular)** ventricular response**.
    • **Odd ratios (ie, 1:1, 3:1, 5:1) are possible but extremely uncommon (unless the patient has WPW or is already on antiarrhythmic drugs).

    Â 

    Figure 02.18-1: Atrial Flutter with 2:1 AV conduction (Tracing A). Note how much easier it is to identify AFlutter when the AV conduction ratio is slower (as it is with 4:1 AV conduction in Tracing B). Tracing B shows the effect that a vagal maneuver might have (See Sections 02.26, 02.27).

    02.19 â€“ FIGURE 02.19-1: Easy to Overlook AFlutter â€¦

    In our experience â€” AFlutter is by far the most commonly overlooked rhythm diagnosis. It is easy to overlook â€” because flutter waves may not always be evident in the lead you are monitoring.

    • Always suspect AFlutter (until proven otherwise) â€” whenever there is a regular SVT at ~150/minute without clear sign of normal atrial activity. This is precisely what is seen in (Figure 02.19-1). The patient was stable.

    Â 

    Figure 02.19-1: There is a regular SVT (narrow QRS rhythm) at a rate of ~150/minute. Normal atrial activity is not seen (no clear upright P wave is evident in this lead II monitoring lead). IF the patient is stable â€” Look for atrial activity in other leads!

    IF the patient is hemodynamically stable and tolerating the tachycardia â€” then a look at additional leads may facilitate diagnosis:

    • A 12-lead ECG is obtained (Figure 02.19-2). Note how this helps to verify our suspicion of non-sinus atrial activity (red and blue arrows).

    Â 

    Figure 02.19-2: 12-lead ECG obtained on the patient whose initial rhythm was shown in Figure 02.19-1.

    02.20 â€“ How NOT to Overlook AFlutter (Figure 02.19-1)

    We were not initially certain of the rhythm diagnosis in Figure 02.19-1. We assessed this rhythm as a regular narrow-complex tachycardia (ie, a regular SVT) at a rate of ~150/minute without sinus P waves.

    • We saw one (if not two) negative deflections within each R-R interval in Figure 02.19-1 suggesting atrial activity.
    • Remembering the statement: â€œAFlutter until proven otherwiseâ€ for any regular SVT at ~150/minute without sinus P waves â€” We suspected this diagnosis (but were not certain).
    • Since the patient was hemodynamically stable (as they usually will be with SVT rhythms) â€” We obtained a 12-lead ECG (Figure 02.19-2). The 12-lead confirmed that the QRS was truly narrow in all leads. It also suggested regularly occurring atrial activity at rapid rate in many leads (red and blue arrows in Figure 02.19-2).

    Â 

    NOTE: There is no indication of atrial activity during the regular SVT in several leads in Fig. 02.19-2 (leads I, aVL,V6). Flutter waves are not always seen in all leads. That said â€” leads with the arrows clearly demonstrate that the deflections we see are â€œrealâ€.

    • PEARL â€” Using Calipers: Use of calipers greatly facilitates the diagnostic process. There is no easier way to identify if baseline deflections are regularly occurring or not. Using calipers enables us to diagnose AFlutter simply from the 12-lead tracing shown in Figure 02.19-2 (arrows).

    Â 

    02.21 â€“ FIGURE 02.21-1: Vagal Maneuvers to Confirm AFlutter

    Confirmation of AFlutter as the rhythm diagnosis for Figure 02.19-1 was forthcoming following application of a vagal maneuver (Figure 02.21-1).

    • Note transient slowing of the ventricular response after the large arrow (vagal maneuver) â€” revealing regular atrial activity at ~300/minute. The only rhythm that does this is atrial flutter.
    • Beyond-the-Core: Whether or not a vagal maneuver was truly needed in this case to confirm AFlutter vs sufficient comfort in this diagnosis from simply reviewing the 12-lead ECG in Figure 02.19-2 â€” would depend on the experience level, expertise and practice preferences of the treating clinician. Clinically â€” We would be less inclined to use IV adenosine once we know the rhythm is AFlutter (since adenosine wonâ€™t convert AFlutter) â€” and more inclined to treat with an AV nodal blocking agent (diltiazem, beta-blocker) while contemplating more definitive measures.

    Â 

    Figure 02.21-1: A vagal maneuver is applied (large arrow) to the rhythm initially shown in Figure 02.19-1. The vagal maneuver temporarily slows AV nodal conduction â€” thereby revealing underlying atrial activity at 300/minute (smaller red arrows). The only rhythm that does this is AFlutter.

    02.22 â€“ FIGURE 02.22-1: Some KEY Aspects about AFlutter

    Given the elusiveness of AFlutter â€” We highlight some advanced special characteristics of this rhythm by the 4 tracings shown in Figure 02.22-1:

    • How would you interpret each tracing in this Figure?
    • Which concept regarding recognition/differential diagnosis of AFlutter do you think is illustrated by each example?

    Â 

    Figure 02.22-1 (Tracings A,B,C,D): How does each tracing relate to diagnosis or misdiagnosis of AFlutter?

    ANSWER to Tracing A (in Figure 02.22-1):

    • As noted in Section 02.18 â€” there may be a variable ventricular response to AFlutter (Tracing A). Despite irregular irregularity that would otherwise suggest AFib â€” the diagnosis of AFlutter is secure in Tracing A from the precisely regular sawtooth pattern of atrial activity seen here at a rate just over 300/minute.

    Â 

    02.23 â€“ TRACING B: AFlutter with 3:1 AV Conduction

    Figure 02.23-1: What is unusual about the example of AFlutter shown in Tracing B?

    Answer to Tracing B:

    • The rhythm in** Tracing B** (*initially seen as B in *Fig. 02.22-1) â€” is another example of AFlutter, this time with 3:1 AV conduction. As noted in Section 02.18 â€” odd conduction ratios are extremely uncommon in AFlutter. That said â€” they can be seen on occasion. The diagnosis of AFlutter is secure in Tracing B from recognition of precisely regular atrial activity (arrows) at a rate of ~300/minute. Nothing else does this. We count 3 flutter waves within each R-R interval.

    Â 

    **02.24 â€“ TRACING C: *AFib-Flutter ***

    Figure 02.24-1: Is the rhythm in Tracing C AFib or AFlutter?

    Answer to Tracing C:

    • The rhythm in** Tracing C** (*initially seen as C in *Fig. 02.22-1) â€” shows a slow, irregularly irregular rhythm with narrow QRS and underlying atrial activity. Initially the rhythm looks like AFlutter â€” but toward the end of the tracing baseline undulations look more like AFib. Although often referred to as â€œAFib-Flutterâ€ â€” the important clinical point is that the rhythm behaves as AFib. Although technically this rhythm is best classified as very slow AFib â€” We would also accept interpretation as AFib-Flutter as a descriptive term that perhaps most accurately conveys the ECG picture in Tracing C.

    Â 

    02.25 â€“ TRACING D: AFlutter vs Artifact

    Figure 02.25-1: Is atrial activity in Tracing D real? What do you suspect the rhythm is? How might you confirm this?

    Answer to Tracing D:

    • The rhythm in** Tracing D** (initially seen as D in Fig. 02.22-1) â€” is not AFlutter. Instead â€” the numerous small undulations that populate the baseline represent artifact. We know the rhythm in Figure 02.25-1 is not AFlutter because: i)** We can see regular underlying P waves (*arrows in *Figure 02.25-2); ii) These P waves are unaffected by the baseline artifact: iii) the artifact undulations are too fast and irregular to be AFlutter; and iv) We looked at the patient (who manifested an obvious resting tremor).

    Â 

    Figure 02.25-2:* Arrows* highlight sinus P waves in Tracing D. These sinus P waves are superimposed on baseline artifactual undulations.

    02.26 â€“ Use of VAGAL Maneuvers (Carotid Massage, Valsalva)

    Vagal maneuvers are commonly used to facilitate ECG diagnosis â€” and/or to treat certain cardiac arrhythmias. Vagal maneuvers work by producing a transient increase in parasympathetic tone â€” thus temporarily slowing conduction through the AV node. This was seen in Figure Figure 02.21-1 â€” in which the vagal maneuver facilitated ECG diagnosis of AFlutter.

    • Carotid Sinus Massage (CSM) â€” Always perform under constant ECG monitoring. Use the right carotid first. Never press on both carotids at the same time. Remember that the carotid sinus is located high in the neck at the angle of the jaw! (*green arrow in *Figure 02.26-1).

    Â 

    Figure 02.26-1: Carotid massage (See text).

    Additional points to consider about CSM include:

    • Warn patient that the maneuver will be uncomfortable (as very firm pressure is needed for success). Apply enough pressure to indent a tennis ball.
    • Rub for *no more *than 3-5 seconds at a time.
    • IF no response â€” may repeat CSM on the left side.
    • Don’t do CSM if patient has a carotid bruit (as you may dislodge a carotid plaque).
    • Always monitor the patient on ECG! Mark the time you start carotid massage â€” and the time you stop (which provides hard copy of what occurred). ECG changes with CSM may be quite subtle (which is another reason to get a hard copy rhythm strip recording during the time CSM is done).

    Â 

    ***Valsalva ****â€” *Have patient supine. Forcibly exhale (bear down) against a closed glottis (as if trying to go to the bathroom) for up to 15 seconds at a time. If properly performed â€” may be even more effective than CSM!

    **02.27 â€“ FIGURE 02.27-1: *Clinical Response to Vagal Maneuvers ***

    Know the response you are looking for before beginning (Figure 02.27-1).

    • At times â€” reapplication of a vagal maneuver after administration of an AV nodal blocking drug (ie, diltiazem; a Î²â€“blocker) may work, whereas it didnâ€™t work before the drug was given.
    • A similar response as is described in Figure 02.27-1 would be expected with â€œchemicalâ€ valsalva (from diagnostic/therapeutic use of Adenosine).

    Â 

    Figure 02.27-1:* What to expect* from CSM/Valsalva.

    **02.28 â€“ *Using *ADENOSINE = *â€œChemicalâ€ Valsava ***

    Adenosine is an extremely useful drug for treatment of SVT. It will rapidly convert most PSVT â€” and it usually produces transient slowing of other SVT rhythms which may be diagnostic (as it is in Figure 02.28-1).

    • Adenosine may also convert 5-10% of VT (Ventricular Tachycardia) rhythms â€” especially outflow track VT that is prone to develop in younger adults without underlying heart disease. For this reason â€” current ACLS Guidelines recommend trial of Adenosine early in the course of treating either narrow or wide tachycardias of uncertain etiology.

    Â 

    Figure 02.28-1: Administration of Adenosine (â€œchemicalâ€ valsalva) â€” was diagnostic of SVT etiology in this patient (arrows reveal underlying AFlutter at ~300/minute). But in so doing â€” a period of over 10 seconds ensued without a QRS complex. Marked bradycardia like this is not uncommon following Adenosine. Bradycardia almost always resolves within 30-60 seconds (due to the drugâ€™s ultra-short half-life). Other transient side effects of Adenosine may include chest pressure; flushing; bronchospasm; metallic taste; a feeling of â€œimpending doomâ€. (Be sure to tell the patient these effects are short-lived!).

    NOTE: Fortunately â€” Using Adenosine early in the treatment of a regular WCT (Wide-Complex Tachycardia) of uncertain etiology is unlikely to be harmful (given the ultra-short half-life of the drug). The â€œgood newsâ€ â€” is that doing so may convert many SVT rhythms â€” it will be diagnostic in others â€” and it may even convert a small percentage of VT rhythms.

    • Beyond-the-Core: Adenosine is unlikely to work for VT with wide QRS in a patient with ischemic heart disease. As a result â€” we generally favor omitting it from the treatment protocol of such patients.
    • Be aware that conversion of a regular WCT to sinus rhythm following use of Adenosine does not prove a supraventricular etiology (since the drug may convert a small percentage of VT rhythms).

    Â 

    **02.29 â€“ PSVT/AVNRT **

    PSVT (Paroxysmal SupraVentricular Tachycardia) â€” is a regular supraventricular tachycardia that most often occurs at a rate between 150-to-240/minute (Figure 02.29-1). Atrial activity is usually not evident â€” although subtle notching or a negative deflection (representing retrograde atrial activity) may sometimes be seen at the tail end of the QRS.

    Figure 02.29-1: PSVT (regular SVT without sinus P waves at ~200/minute). Rate is calculated by the every-other-beat method (See Section 02.31).

    Mechanistically â€” PSVT is a reentry tachycardia that involves at least some portion of the AV node (Figure 02.29-2). This accounts for the other name for this rhythm = AVNRT (AV Nodal Reentry Tachycardia).

    • PSVT is often initiated by a PAC (*which arrives early at the AV Node *â€” at a time when conditions are â€œjust rightâ€ to allow the reentry circuit to be set up). Once set up â€” the impulse continues to circulate *within *the AV Node (Figure 02-29-2) â€” until the reentry pathway is either interrupted (ie, by AV nodal blocking drugs or a vagal maneuver) â€” or until it stops spontaneously.
    • Of note, each time the impulse circulates around the AV Node â€” it conducts a QRS down to the ventricles and also conducts retrograde back up to the atria (Fig. 02.29-2).

    Â 

    Figure 02.29-2: PSVT. Schematic illustration of reentry involving a portion of the AV Node. Each time the impulse circulates around the AV node â€” it conducts a QRS down to the ventricles and also conducts retrograde back up to the atria.

    **02.30 â€“ FIGURE 02.30-1: *Retrograde Conduction with PSVT ***

    Most of the time, atrial activity will not be seen during PSVT â€” because the retrograde P wave will be hidden within the simultaneously occurring QRS complex.

    • Beyond-the-Core: On occasion â€” you will see notching in the terminal portion of the QRS complex during PSVT (Figure 02.30-1). When present â€” this retrograde atrial activity indicates a reentry mechanism is operative as the mechanism of the SVT. Clinically â€” reentry SVT rhythms are more likely to respond to vagal maneuvers and/or use of Adenosine.
    • Beyond-the-Core: Confirmation that notching in the terminal portion of the QRS complex truly represents retrograde atrial activity from a reentry SVT â€” can be forthcoming by obtaining a post-conversion 12-lead ECG. Once sinus rhythm has resumed â€” this notching in the terminal portion of the QRS should no longer be seen.

    Â 

    Figure 02.30-1: PSVT. Subtle notching is seen in the terminal portion of the QRS in several (but not all) leads (arrows). Identification of such retrograde atrial activity during a regular SVT rhythm indicates a reentry mechanism is operative.

    02.31 â€“ The â€œEvery-other-Beatâ€ Method (for fast rates)

    Accurate determination of heart rate is essential for assessment of the various SVTs (SupraVentricular Tachycardias). When the rhythm is regular and the rate is fast â€” calculating rate is most easily accomplished using the **“Every-other-Beat” Method (Figure 02.31-1):

    • The R-R interval of every-other-beat for the PSVT rhythm in Figure 02.31-1 is precisely 3 large boxes in duration.
    • Therefore â€” half the rate will be 100/minute (300 divided by 3).
    • This means that the actual rate in Figure 02.31-1 must be twice this amount (= 100/minute X 2 = 200/minute).

    Â 

    Figure 02.31-1: PSVT (*previously shown in *Figure 02.29-1). Heart rate is estimated by the every-other-beat method. Since the R-R interval of every-other-beat is 3 large boxes in duration â€” half the rate = 100/minute (300/3). The actual rate is therefore twice this amount = 200/minute.

    02.32 â€“ Junctional Rhythms**

    Junctional (or AV Nodal) rhythms â€” are regular supraventricular rhythms in which atrial activity reflects an AV Nodal site of origin (Figure 02.32-1). As opposed to NSR (Normal Sinus Rhythm) â€” in which conduction begins in the SA Node and travels downward (*left panel in *Figure 02.32-1) â€” electrical activity begins in the AV Node with junctional beats or rhythm (right panel) â€” and is conducted *backward *(ie, retrograde) or away from Lead II. As a result, when a P wave is seen in lead II with junctional beats or junctional rhythm â€” it will be negative (since electrical activity is traveling away from standard lead II in its path back to the atria).

    Fig. 02.32-1: Anatomic site of origin for sinus rhythm (left) vs AV Nodal beats or AV Nodal (junctional) rhythm (right). As shown in the inserts â€” the P wave in lead II will be upright with sinus rhythm (left insert) but negative when a P wave is seen with junctional rhythm (right insert).

    02.33 â€“ Junctional Rhythms: P Wave Appearance in Lead II**

    The 3 possible scenarios for P wave appearance with junctional rhythms is best illustrated by laddergram (Figure 02.33-1). Relative speed of conduction backward (to depolarize the atria) â€” compared to forward speed of conduction (to depolarize the ventricles) will determine IF the P wave in lead II is:

    • Negative before the QRS (Panel B of Figure 02.33-1) â€” as would occur if it takes less time to conduct back to atria than forward to ventricles.
    • Negative after the QRS (Panel D) â€” as would occur if it takes more time to conduct back to atria.
    • Absent completely â€” as would occur IF it takes approximately equal time to conduct back to atria as down to ventricles (such that the retrograde P wave is hidden within the QRS â€” as seen in Panel C).

    Â 

    Fig. 02.33-1: Laddergram of the 3 possibilities for P wave appearance in lead II with junctional beats or junctional rhythm. Panel A illustrates the normal forward conduction of sinus rhythm. The impulse originates in the SA Node *â€” travels through the atria â€” slows down a bit as it passes through the AV Node â€” *and is then transmitted down through the conduction system to the ventricles. NOTE: With junctional beats (or junctional rhythm) â€” the impulse originates from the AV Node. It then travels back (retrograde) to the atria and down to the ventricles. As a result *â€” *the P wave in lead II may be negative appearing either before (Panel B) or after (Panel D) the QRS â€“ or â€“ no P wave at all may be seen (Panel C). Clinically â€” Situation C is most common, whereas it is rare to see a P wave after the QRS (situation D).

    02.34 â€“ Junctional Rhythms: Escape vs Accelerated**

    There are 3 basic â€œtypesâ€ of junctional rhythms *â€” *with the type determined by the rate of the rhythm (Figure 02.34-1):

    • AV Nodal Escape Rhythm â€” when the junctional rate in an adult is between 40-60/minute (*See Rhythm X in *Figure 02.34-1). An AV Nodal â€œescapeâ€ rhythm arises because the SA Node is either delayed or fails in its pacemaking function NOTE: â€” This is not necessarily a pathologic rhythm!
    • Accelerated Junctional Rhythm â€” when the junctional rate speeds up to between 61-99/minute (Tracing Y) â€” at which point it takes over the pacemaking function from the SA Node.
    • **Junctional *Tachycardia ***â€” when the rate *exceeds *100/minute (Tracing Z).

    Â 

    Figure 02.34-1: Junctional rhythms. NOTE: Although we show no P wave in X and a negative P wave (before and after the QRS) in Y, Z â€” it is rate that determines the â€œtypeâ€ of rhythm.

    **Clinical Notes: Junctional Rhythms ***â€” *The KEY to assessing the clinical significance of a junctional rhythm is appreciation of the setting in which it occurs:

    • Junctional â€œescapeâ€** (40-60/minute) â€” may be seen on occasion in otherwise healthy young adults without clinical consequence.
    • The same is true in children (and adolescents) â€” for whom the normal escape rate is a bit faster (50-80/minute).
    • In contrast â€” **accelerated junctional rhythms (in which the AV Node speeds up) â€” typically occur in a limited number of clinical situations (acute MI; post-operative state; congenital heart disease; shock; digoxin toxicity). Recognition should prompt concern. The rhythm usually resolves by treating the underlying condition.
    • PEARL: â€” Regardless of the serum digoxin level â€” *Think *Dig Toxicity until proven otherwise whenever you see an accelerated junctional rhythm (albeit this is less common nowadays given current reduced use of digoxin).
    • Final Note: Clinical implications of accelerated vs junctional tachycardia are the same (the only difference is whether the rate is over or under 100/minute).

    Â 

    02.35 â€“ Low Atrial vs Junctional Rhythm?**

    Beyond-the-Core: Technically *â€” *a rhythm with a negative P wave preceding each QRS complex with fixed PR interval could be coming from a low atrial site instead of from the AV Node (Figure 02.35-1):

    • Beats originating from either the AV Node (Point X in Panel A of Fig. 02.35-1) or from a **low atrial site (Point Y in Panel B) *â€” *will both be perceived as moving away from lead II as they conduct back to depolarize the atria. As a result â€” a negative P wave may precede the QRS complex in either case.
    • Practically speaking â€” it does not matter whether a beat or rhythm is of junctional or low atrial origin, because clinical implications are similar in each case.

    Â 

    Figure 02.35-1: The presence of a negative P wave before the QRS may also be seen with low atrial as well as junctional beats or rhythm. Atrial depolarization moves away from lead II (red arrows) when impulse origin is from either the AV node (X) â€” or from a site low in the atria (Y).

    02.36 â€“ VENTRICULAR (= wide QRS) Rhythms

    With the exception of the chaotic variability of VFib (Ventricular Fibrillation) â€” the sustained ventricular rhythms are most often regular (or at least fairly regular) rhythms that originate from a site in the ventricles.

    • The QRS complex is wide â€” because the ventricular origin of these rhythms is outside the conduction system. The QRS looks very different than sinus beats.
    • Ventricular rhythms may arise either as â€œescapeâ€ rhythms (if supraventricular pacemakers fail) â€” or as usurping rhythms (when the ventricular focus accelerates and takes over the pacemaking function from the preexisting supraventricular pacemaker).
    • P waves with ventricular rhythms may be: i) absent; ii) unrelated to the QRS complex; â€” or iii) retrograde.

    Â 

    **Types of Ventricular Rhythms: ***â€” *There are 3 basic â€œtypesâ€ of ventricular rhythms *â€” *with the type determined by the rate of the rhythm:

    • Slow IVR (IdioVentricular Rhythm) â€” Section 02.37.
    • AIVR (Accelerated IdioVentricular Rhythm) â€” Section 02.38.
    • VT (Ventricular Tachycardia) â€” Section 02.39.

    Â 

    02.37 â€“ Slow IdioVentricular Escape Rhythm

    The term*** slow* IVR** is used to describe a regular (or at least somewhat regular) ventricular rhythm (wide QRS; no conducting P waves) â€” when the ventricular rate is between 20-40/minute. This is the usual rate range of an intrinsic ventricular escape focus. As a result â€” slow IVR is often referred to as an IdioVentricular â€œescapeâ€ Rhythm (Figure 02.37-1):

    Figure 02.37-1:* Slow* IVR. The ventricular rhythm is regular at a rate of ~38/minute (the R-R interval = 8 large boxes; 300/8 ~38/minute). The QRS is wide. No P waves are seen.

    • Clinical Note: â€” The occurrence of slow IVR is often an ominous finding that is commonly seen during the course of cardiac arrest. It may also arise as a ventricular escape rhythm in a patient with complete AV block.

    Â 

    02.38 â€“ AIVR

    AIVR (Accelerated IdioVentricular* R*hythm)** â€” is said to be present when the rate of the ventricular rhythm is more than 40/minute â€” but **does not exceed 110-120/minute (Figure 02.38-1):

    • AIVR (also called â€œslowâ€ VTach) â€” is a relatively common escape rhythm that may be seen in patients with acute MI and/or during reperfusion therapy. It may also occur as a rhythm of cardiac arrest. No treatment is needed IF the patient is asymptomatic (as this rhythm typically resolves on its own). Do not give antiarrhythmic drugs (the drugs may abolish the only escape rhythm the patient has).

    Â 

    Figure 02.38-1: AIVR. The ventricular rhythm is regular at a rate of 75/minute (300/4). This is faster than slow idioventricular escape â€” but slower than VT. Otherwise â€” the QRS is wide; there are no P waves.

    02.39 â€“ Ventricular Tachycardia

    VT (Ventricular Tachycardia)** â€” is said to be present when the rate of the ventricular rhythm exceeds 120-130/minute (Figure 02.39-1):

    • By definition â€” VT is always a â€œusurpingâ€ rhythm, in that the ventricular focus accelerates and takes over pacemaking from the preexisting supraventricular pacemaker. Prompt (if not immediate) treatment is essential.

    Â 

    Figure 02.39-1: VT. The ventricular rhythm is regular at a rate of ~150/minute (300/2). The QRS is wide; No P waves.

    **NOTE: ***â€” *There exists a â€œgray zoneâ€ â€” in which the ventricular rhythm occurs at a rate between 110-to130/minute. This falls in between the rate range for â€œfastâ€ VT (Section 02.39) and the rate range for â€œslowâ€ VT (Section 02.38).

    02.40 â€“ ESCAPE Rhythms: ECG Recognition**

    IF for whatever reason sinus (or other atrial rhythm) fails â€” an escape rhythm will hopefully arise from either: i) the AV Node; or ii) the Ventricles (Figure 02.40-1).

    • The rate range for the various **â€œescapeâ€ pacemakers is easy to remember â€” because it steps down sequentially from the lower limit of 60/minute for sinus rhythm (Figure 02.40-1). ** **

    Â 

    Figure 02.40-1:* Escape* rhythms. AV Nodal Escape (Rhythm A) â€” is recognized by the presence of a narrow QRS rhythm; rate between 40-60/minute. Ventricular Escape (Rhythm B) â€” is recognized by the presence of a wide QRS rhythm; rate between 20-40/minute.

    02.41 â€“ PRACTICE TRACINGS: What is the Rhythm?

    Interpret the following 5 arrhythmias (Sections 02.42-thru-02.46). All rhythm strips are obtained from Lead II. The patient was hemodynamically stable in each case. Our answers follow after each tracing.

    • Hint â€” Use the Pâ€™s/Qâ€™s and 3R *systematic *approach for interpreting each rhythm (Section 02.1).

    Â
