That said â€” the ultra-short half-life of Adenosine is much less likely to be deleterious compared to other AV nodal blocking drugs if it is inadvertently given.
    • Drugs of Choice: The 3 drugs that have most commonly been recommended for antiarrhythmic treatment of hemodynamically stable very rapid AFib (or AFlutter) with WPW are** i)** Procainamide; ii) Amiodarone; and iii) Ibutilide. There are pros and cons for use of each of these agents that extent beyond the scope of this ePub on ECG interpretation. Each drug has its advocates. All in theory reduce forward transmission of impulses down the accessory pathway. KEY Point: IF at any time during the treatment process the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable â€” then cardiovert!

    Â 

    05.50 â€“ Atrial Flutter with WPW

    When AFlutter occurs in a patient with WPW â€” the tachyarrhythmia is also antidromic (*first down the AP *â€” and then back up the normal pathway = as in Panel B *of *Figure 05.47-1).

    • As with AFib â€” the QRS is wide in AFlutter with WPW. There may be 1:1 AV conduction of atrial impulses (so that the ventricular response may be 250-300/minute)!
    • Very fast AFlutter with WPW is seen even less often than AFib (but clinical manifestations and treatment are similar).

    Â 

    05.51 â€“ PSVT with WPW: When the QRS is Wide

    In rare instances â€” PSVT may be antidromic (ie, travel first down the AP â€” and then back up the normal pathway = as occurs in Panel B *of *Figure 05.47-1).

    • In these rare instances â€” the QRS will be wide and the PSVT rhythm may be indistinguishable from VT.
    • It may only be after conversion to sinus rhythm that â€œtelltaleâ€ delta waves of WPW can be identified. Fortunately â€” the vast majority (~95%) of PSVT episodes with WPW are orthodromic (with narrow QRS). Synchronized cardioversion will be the usual treatment of choice for episodes of a regular WCT (Wide-Complex Tachycardia) in which one suspects antidromic PSVT in a patient with WPW as the etiology.

    Â 

    05.52 â€“ FIGURE 05.52-1: VT or WPW? What to Do?

    We complete our discussion of arrhythmias in the patient with WPW by the 12-lead ECG shown in Figure 05.52-1 â€” obtained from a hemodynamically stable young adult who presented to the ED (Emergency Department) with new-onset palpitations.

    • What is the rhythm? What does this patient have?
    • How should the patient be treated?
    • Which drugs should not be given?

    Â 

    Figure 05.52-1: 12-lead ECG from a young adult with palpitations. What is the rhythm? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 05.52-1: The rhythm in this hemodynamically stable young adult is an irregularly irregular WCT (Wide-Complex Tachycardia). No P waves are seen in any of the 12 leads of this tracing. This defines the rhythm as AFib. That said â€” the ventricular response is exceedingly rapid (attaining a rate of nearly 300/minute in some parts of the tracing). In addition â€” there is marked variability in rate of the ventricular response (seen best in leads aVF and V3).

    • This 12-lead ECG is virtually diagnostic of **very rapid AFib in a patient who has WPW. VT (Ventricular Tachycardia) may at times be slightly irregular â€” but it should not be as irregularly irregular as seen here throughout the tracing.
    • The rapidity of the rate (nearly 300/minute in certain parts of the tracing) â€” suggests AP conduction until proven otherwise (Section 05.49). Treatment considerations are as described in Section 05.49 (IV Amiodarone, Procainamide or Ibutilide if the patient remains stable â€” with immediate cardioversion at the first sign of instability).
    • The patient should be referred to an EP cardiologist after resolution of the acute tachycardia for consideration of an ablative procedure that may be curative.

    Â 

    06.0 â€“ QT Interval / Torsades de Pointes

    06.1 â€“ How to Measure the QT

    The QT interval â€” is the period that extends from the beginning of ventricular depolarization â€” until the end of ventricular repolarization (Figure 06.1-1). For practical purposes, the QT is ***prolonged *â€” IF it clearly measures more than half the R-R interval. The principal exception to this rule is when the heart rate is rapid (>90-100 /minute) â€” in which case it becomes more difficult to measure the QT and determine its clinical significance.

    • To Measure the QT â€” Select a lead where you can clearly see the end of the T wave. Select that lead in which the QT appears to be longest.
    • NOTE: If there is no â€œqâ€ wave in the QRS complex â€” Measure from the beginning of the R wave (Figure 06.1-1).

    Â 

    Figure 06.1-1: Provided that heart rate is not overly fast (ie, 90-100/minute) â€” the QT is normal if it is not more than half the R-R interval. There are 3 possibilities: i) Left Panel â€” The QT is clearly normal; ii) Middle â€” The QT is â€œborderlineâ€, as it is approximately half the R-R interval (or at most, slightly more than half the R-R interval); or iii) Right â€” The QT is clearly prolonged.

    06.2 â€“ LIST #3: Causes of QT Prolongation

    Clinically â€” We want to know IF the QT is normal or long. This is usually easy to tell by the **â€œeyeballâ€ method **(ie, Is the QT more than half the R-R interval?) â€” provided that the heart rate is not excessively fast (>90-100/minute).

    • Practically speaking â€” one only cares IF the QT interval is normal, borderline, or long. Patients with a long QT interval are at increased risk of developing the potentially life-threatening arrhythmia Torsades de Pointes (Section 06.6).
    • Beyond-the-Core:** Hypercalcemia** produces QT shortening. That said â€” Hypercalcemia is difficult to recognize on ECG, and is usually only seen with very high serum calcium values (of >12 mg/dL).

    Â 

    Causes of a Long QT:

    The common causes of a long QT interval can be divided into 3 categories: i) Drugs; ii) Electrolyte disorders; and iii) CNS catastrophes. We consolidate this information in our **LIST #3 **(Figure 06.2-1):

    • KEY Point: The NOTE at the bottom of List #3 reminds us that other conditions (ie, ischemia/infarction/BBB) â€” may also prolong the QT. Clinically â€” We pay less attention to the QT interval when the ECG picture is dominated by other findings. But IF the only thing wrong (beyond nonspecific changes) is a *long *QT â€” Think â€œDrugs/Lytes/CNSâ€ as the cause!

    Â 

    Figure 06.2-1: List #3 = Common Causes of a Long QT Interval.

    **06.3 â€“ A Closer Look at LIST #3: *Drugs â€“ Lytes â€“ CNS ***

    We expand on the causes of QT prolongation in LIST #3 (Figure 06.2-1) â€” by emphasizing the following points:

    • DRUGS â€” An ever increasing number of drugs (in addition to those in List #3) may either affect the QT interval directly â€” *and/or *â€” produce p450 system drug interactions that increase Torsades risk if taken together with other QT-lengthening drugs. Clinically â€” it is usually not a problem in an otherwise healthy adult to take any single drug that may affect the QT. But â€” the amount of QT prolongation (and the risk of Torsades) may be additive IF more than one QT-lengthening drug is taken â€” especially if circumstances or other condition predisposing to Torsades is present (Section 06.4).
    • LYTES â€” 3 electrolyte disorders should be kept in mind when assessing a patient with QT prolongation: i) Hypokalemia â€” is characterized by ST flattening/depression; development of U waves; and QT lengthening (Section 11.7); ii) Hypomagnesemia â€” produces identical ECG and clinical effects as hypokalemia (Section 11.8); and iii) Hypocalcemia â€” which if other electrolytes are normal, tends to produce a normal T wave after a prolonged QT interval (Section 11.1).
    • NOTE: Rather than â€œQTâ€ lengthening â€” it is really the â€œQUâ€ interval that is prolonged with hypokalemia *and/or *hypomagnesemia (as T and U waves tend to fuse as the U wave becomes bigger with more profound electrolyte depletion).
    • CNS catastrophes (ie, coma, stroke, trauma, seizure, bleed) â€” are known to produce some of the most bizarre ST-T wave abnormalities (and some of the longest QT intervals). Resultant ST segment elevation that may be seen with CNS catastrophes can at times mimic the changes of *acute *MI. The reason for ST-T wave abnormalities with CNS disorders is uncertain â€” but is thought to relate to disturbance of autonomic tone.

    Â 

    06.4 â€“ Conditions Predisposing to a Long QT/Torsades**

    Be aware of circumstances that increase the risk of QT prolongation and therefore of developing Torsades de Pointes. These include:

    • Female sex (women are more predisposed to Torsades!).
    • Electrolyte disorders (low K+/low Mg++).
    • Bradycardia (usually 50/minute) â€” since a long preceding R-R interval (as seen with bradycardia) sets up prolongation of the QT interval for the following beat.
    • Structural heart disease (heart failure; marked LVH; cardiomyopathy; ischemia; prior infarction).
    • Significant renal or hepatic dysfunction.
    • Baseline QT prolongation â€” if the QTc is >450 msec. (*especially if >500 msec. *â€” Section 06.5).

    Â 

    06.5 â€“ The QTc: Corrected QT Interval

    Up to now â€” We have focused on the â€œeyeball methodâ€ for determining IF the QT interval is normal or long:

    • IF the QT is less than half the R-R â€” then the QT is normal.
    • But IF the QT is more than half the R-R â€” the QT is long (Figure 06.1-1).

    Â 

    In either case, more precise determination of the QT interval is usually not necessary â€” since for practical purposes, the main thing we are concerned with is whether the QT is normal or long. That said â€” at times it will be important to more precisely determine the QT. This is especially true when it is not readily apparent from inspection whether the QT interval is normal or long.

    • Tables exist for precise determination of the QT based on the age, sex and heart rate. Accounting for difference in heart rate results in a QTc â€” where the â€œlittle câ€ indicates correction of the QT for heart rate.
    • Beyond-the-Core: The formula for determining QTc = the QT that you measure â€” divided by the square root of the R-R interval. The â€œgood newsâ€ is that at a heart rate of 60/minute â€” the R-R interval = 5 large boxes (= 1.0 second) â€” and the square root of one is one! This means that at a rate of 60/minute â€” the QTc is the QT interval that you measure.
    • KEY Point: The computerized interpretation will accurately calculate the QTc for you! In general â€” the upper normal for the QTc is** ~450msec**. More than this suggests QT prolongation. Definite concern about QT prolongation increases once the QTc exceeds 480 msec (*especially *if >500 msec)!

    Â 

    **06.6 â€“ Torsades: *WHY Care about QT Prolongation? ***

    Why Care about the QT interval? The answer is to hopefully prevent the rhythm seen in Figure 06.6-1. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was ongoing at the time this tracing was obtained.

    Figure 06.6-1: Irregular WCT rhythm obtained during cardiopulmonary resuscitation. What is the rhythm? What to do next? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 06.6-1: After 2 sinus beats â€” the rhythm dramatically changes. This is polymorphic VT â€” as defined by constantly varying QRS morphology throughout the rest of the tracing.

    • Torsades de Pointes â€” is defined as polymorphic VT that occurs in association with a prolonged QT interval on baseline ECG. The very rapid irregular WCT seen in Figure 06.6-1 manifests the shifting QRS polarity around the baseline (â€œtwistingâ€ of the points) that is characteristic of Torsades.
    • NOTE: There appears to be a prolonged QT interval for the first 2 sinus beats in Figure 06.6-1 (ie, the QT looks to be more than half the R-R interval) â€” in which case the rhythm would be Torsades. That said â€” it is difficult to be certain where the T wave (and therefore the â€œQTâ€ interval) ends in this tracing. Clinically â€” It will simply not always be possible to assess QT duration during polymorphic VT.
    • Clinical Reality â€” When we either do not have access to a prior baseline 12-lead ECG on the patient or cannot accurately assess the QT interval from the rhythm strip â€” we will be unable to distinguish whether the rhythm is PMVT (PolyMorphic Ventricular Tachycardia) â€” or â€œTorsadesâ€ (which is simply PMVT with baseline QT prolongation).

    Â 

    Treatment of Figure 06.6-1: Regardless of whether this irregular WCT rhythm is PMVT or Torsades â€” initial treatment measures are the same: i) Defibrillation if the rhythm persists; ii) Magnesium Sulfate (1-2 gm IV â€” which often needs to be repeated up to 4-8 gm); and iii) Try to find and fix the underlying cause of PMVT/Torsades. Potential additional measures for resistant cases (ie, overdrive pacing, isoproterenol) extend beyond the scope of this ePUb on ECG diagnosis.

    • Beyond-the-Core: There are some differences in etiology and response to treatment between Torsades vs PMVT without QT prolongation that are worthy of mention. While IV Magnesium Sulfate is the drug of choice for both disorders â€” PMVT tends to respond less well to this treatment than when there is Torsades with QT prolongation. Rather than being drug or electrolyte induced â€” PMVT with a normal QT more often has an ischemic etiology (occasionally due to Brugada Syndrome). Efforts addressed at treating acute ischemia may therefore be helpful. IV Amiodarone and/or Î²-blockers may reduce recurrence and should be considered if IV Magnesium is ineffective.

    Â 

    **06.7 â€“ FIGURE 06.7-1: *Torsades vs PMVT vs Something Else? ***

    Would you treat both of the rhythms in Figure 06.7-1 with defibrillation and IV Magnesium?

    • What additional information is essential for answering this question?

    Â 

    Figure 06.7-1: Torsades vs PMVT vs something else? (See text). HINT: Timelines for determining heart rate are shown by the square boxes in each tracing (corresponding to a large box on ECG grid paper in each case).

    Answer to Figure 06.7-1: At first glance, it appears that both of these rhythm strips represent PMVT/Torsades.Â  While superficially they do â€” the devil is in the details (in this case the rate of the rhythm).Â 

    • Note in Rhythm A of Fig. 06.7-1 â€”** **that there are at certain points in the tracing two vertical deflections for each large box. This corresponds to a rate of ~500-to-600/minute, or too fast for Torsades. This is artifact. We do not see any normal beats on this tracing â€” but instead just see very straight line, excessively fast deflections suggestive of artifact.
    • The rate in Rhythm B is also fast â€” but much closer to ~300/minute (~1 complex per each large box) â€” which clearly falls within the appropriate rate range for PMVT/Torsades. The rhythm begins and ends by a few normal (narrow) sinus beats. Given the rapid rate â€” it is difficult to determine if the QT is or is not prolonged. Therefore, we can not be certain if Rhythm B is PMVT or technically qualifies as â€œTorsadesâ€. As emphasized in Section 06.6 â€” initial treatment measures are the same regardless of whether or not there is baseline QT prolongation.

    Â 

    **KEY Point: â€” Awareness of clinical context is an essential component of clinical ECG interpretation. The diagnostic dilemma of whether Rhythm A in Figure 06.7-1 is â€œrealâ€ might be easily resolved IF we knew that the patient was alert and hemodynamically stable (which would confirm artifact). Loose lead connections, tremor, scratching, shivering, and seizure activity are but a few of the possible causes of artifact-related deflections that might simulate a tachyarrhythmia.

    **06.8 â€“ FIGURE 06.8-1: *Is the QT Long? ***

    Comment on the QT interval for the 12-lead ECG shown in Figure 06.8-1. What clinical conditions are likely to account for findings on this ECG?

    Figure 06.8-1: Is the QT interval prolonged? If so â€” What is the likely cause(s)?

    Answer to Figure 06.8-1: The rhythm is sinus tachycardia at a rate just over 100/minute. The PR interval and QRS duration are both normal. However â€” the QT interval is long:

    • As emphasized in Section 06.1 â€” the QT interval should be measured in a lead where you can clearly see the end of the T wave and in which the QT appears to be longest. As a result â€” a lead such as aVL should not be used, since the end of the T wave is not well defined in this lead (red question mark in Fig. 06.8-1).
    • On the other hand â€” it is much easier to determine the limits of the T wave in other leads. This is especially true for** lead V2** â€” in which the QT interval is obviously more than half the R-R interval. NOTE: Although the â€œeyeball methodâ€ for assessing QT interval duration is admittedly less accurate when heart rate exceeds 90-100/minute (Section 06.2) â€” QT duration in Figure 06.8-1 is so much more than half the R-R interval, that the QT is undoubtedly prolonged despite the fact that the heart rate is relatively rapid.
    • Regarding assessment of the rest of the ECG in Figure 06.8-1 â€” the most remarkable finding is deep, symmetric T wave inversion in most precordial leads.

    Â 

    IMPRESSION: Sinus tachycardia â€” marked QT prolongation â€” and diffuse symmetric T wave inversion. In addition to ischemia (which is suggested by this symmetric T wave inversion) â€” Think â€œDrugs/Lytes/CNSâ€ as the categories of entities to consider in your differential diagnosis for the markedly prolonged QT interval seen here (LIST #3 in Figure 06.2-1). Clinical correlation is needed to comment further on the most likely causes.

    • Beyond-the-Core: The reason we say the QT interval is markedly prolonged â€” is that the QT literally makes up more than 2/3 of the R-R interval (See insert of leads V2,V3 in Figure 06.8-1). Thus despite the relatively rapid rate and the possibility of ischemia â€” strong consideration should be given to drug-induced QT prolongation â€” severe hypokalemia/hypomagnesemia â€” and/or CNS catastrophe as contributing causes (List #3).

    Â 

    **06.9 â€“ FIGURE 06.9-1: *Is the QT Long? ***

    We conclude this segment on assessment of the QT interval with one more 12-lead tracing (Figure 06.9-1). The rhythm is sinus tachycardia at a rate of ~150/minute. There is diffuse ST segment depression. Comment on the QT interval.

    Figure 06.9-1: Sinus tachycardia at ~150/minute. There is diffuse ST depression. Comment on the QT interval (See text).

    Answer to Figure 06.9-1: As stated â€” there is sinus tachycardia and diffuse ST segment depression. Clearly â€” a heart rate of ~150/minute is too fast to accurately apply the â€œeyeball methodâ€ for QT assessment. That said â€” a look at multiple leads in Figure 06.9-1 â€” suggests that the QT interval makes up as much as ~80% (if not more) of the R-R interval.

    • While numerical determination of a QTc is not realistic for the ECG in Figure 06.9-1 (because the rate is too fast) â€” we strongly suspect the QT is significantly prolonged. Clinically â€” We again consider â€œDrugs/Lytes/CNSâ€ as possible contributing causes.

    Â 

    **06.10 â€“ QTc Addendum: *Using/Calculating the QTc ***

    Beyond-the-Core: As emphasized in Section 06.5 â€” the computerized interpretation will automatically generate a QTc value for you that takes into account the patientâ€™s baseline heart rate. The computer-calculated QTc is usually quite accurate. As a result â€” a perfectly appropriate approach is to first estimate QT interval duration yourself by the â€œeyeball methodâ€ (the QT should not be more than half the R-R interval) â€” and, to then check this out with the QTc value provided by the computer:

    • The upper normal limit for the QTc is** ~450msec**. QTc values greater than this suggest QT prolongation.
    • Clinically â€” concern about QT prolongation increases once the QTc exceeds 480 msec (*especially *if >500 msec)!

    Â 

    An advantage of incorporating the computer-calculated QTc value â€” is that doing so facilitates serial comparison of QT duration in a given patient. For example â€” slight prolongation of the QTc from a baseline of 430 msec to 445 msec in a patient started on Sotalol (an antiarrhythmic agent known to significantly increase QT duration when used in higher doses) would not necessarily mandate stopping the drug or even lowering the dose. However, continued progressive QT prolongation (say, from 430 msec â€” to 445 msec â€” to 470 msec) *â€” *would clearly require reassessment of the treatment regimen.

    06.11 â€“ BEYOND-the-Core: Estimating the QTc Yourself

    For those providers with a desire to quickly estimate the QTc on their own without need to use the computer-calculated value â€” We propose the following:

    • The formula for determining QTc = the QT that you measure â€” divided by the square root of the R-R interval. The â€œgood newsâ€ is that at a heart rate of 60/minute â€” the R-R interval = 5 large boxes (= 1.0 second) â€” and the square root of one is one! This means that at a rate of 60/minute â€” the QTc is the QT interval that you measure.
    • At heart rates faster than 60/minute â€” the QTc will be more than the QT that you measure (because QTc varies inversely with the square root of the R-R interval â€” and the R-R interval for rates faster than 60/minute is less than one).
    • Determining the square root for any R-R interval other than an R-R interval of exactly 1.0 second is complex. *This is why a computer is needed *for precise QTc calculation. That said â€” We have devised a simple correction factor that can be used to rapidly approximate QTc duration.

    Â 

    Use of Our Proposed Correction Factor for QTc Estimation:

    Determine the heart rate. Measure the QT interval in a lead where you can clearly see the end of the T wave and in which the QT interval appears to be longest. Then multiply the QT interval you measure by the correction factor corresponding to your estimation of heart rate:

    • Multiply by 1.0 for a heart rate of ~60/minute.
    • Multiply by 1.1 for a heart rate of ~75/minute.
    • Multiply by 1.2 for a heart rate of ~85/minute.
    • Multiply by 1.3 for a heart rate of ~100/minute.

    Â 

    Applying the QTc Correction Factor:

    Letâ€™s assume that the QT interval you measure is 0.40 second (= precisely 2 large boxes in duration). IF the heart rate was ~60/minute â€” then the QTc = the QT you measure = 0.40 second.

    • IF on the other hand, the heart rate was 75/minute â€” then we can estimate the QTc by multiplying the QT we measure (= 0.40 second) by the correction factor of 1.1 = ~0.44 second.
    • IF instead the heart rate was ~85/minute â€” then the QTc would be 0.40 X 1.2 = ~0.48 second.
    • IF instead the heart rate was ~100/minute â€” then the QTc would be 0.40 X 1.3 = ~0.52 second.
    • Accuracy for QTc estimation decreases with rates substantially faster than 100/minute â€” so we do not offer additional correction factors beyond this rate.
    • Practically speaking â€” there is no need to correct the QT for rate when there is bradycardia (since change in the QTc is relatively small at rates below 60/minute).

    Â 

    **06.12 â€“ FIGURE 06.12-1: *Approximate the QTc ***

    The 12-lead ECG in Figure 06.12-1 shows normal sinus rhythm at a rate just over 75/minute (since the R-R interval is just under 4 large boxes in duration).

    • Assess the QT by the â€œeyeball methodâ€. Is the QT interval likely to be normal or prolonged?
    • Estimate the QTc by applying the appropriate correction factor from Section 06.11 that corresponds to a heart rate just over 75/minute.

    Â 

    Figure 06.12-1: Sinus rhythm at a rate just over 75/minute. Assess the QT interval. Approximate the QTc (See text).

    Answer to Figure 06.12-1: As stated â€” there is sinus rhythm at a rate just over 75/minute.

    • We select lead V2 to measure the QT â€” because we can clearly see the end of the T wave in this lead. Alternatively We could have measured the QT in a number of other leads (ie, leads II, V3,V4,V5).
    • By the â€œeyeball methodâ€ â€” the QT appears to be normal (since the QT is not more than half the R-R interval).
    • As shown in Figure 06.12-1 â€” We measure the QT to be ~0.38 second (just a bit less than 2 large boxes in duration).
    • Given the heart rate close to 75/minute â€” We use a correction factor of 1.1. Multiplying 0.38 X 1.1 is approximately 0.42 second = the QTc. Since 420 msec is clearly less than normal upper limit of 450 msec (Section 06.10) â€” we know that the QTc is normal even without referring to the computer-calculated value.

    Â 

    **06.13 â€“ FIGURE 06.13-1: *Approximate the QTc ***

    The 12-lead ECG in Figure 06.13-1 shows sinus tachycardia at a rate of ~100/minute (since the R-R interval is ~3 large boxes in duration). The QRS complex is narrow.

    • Assess the QT by the â€œeyeball methodâ€. Is the QT interval likely to be normal or prolonged?
    • Estimate the QTc by applying the appropriate correction factor from Section 06.11 that corresponds to a heart rate of ~100/minute.

    Â 

    Figure 06.13-1: Sinus tachycardia at ~100/minute. Assess the QT interval. Approximate the QTc (See text).

    Answer to Figure 06.13-1: As stated â€” there is sinus tachycardia at a rate of ~100/minute. The QRS complex is narrow â€” so any QT widening that may be seen is not the result of bundle branch block or other conduction defect.

    • We again select lead V2 to assess the QT. By the â€œeyeball methodâ€ â€” the QT appears to be markedly prolonged. Although heart rate is faster than is optimal for QT assessment â€” the QT takes up more than 2/3 of the R-R interval. There is therefore no doubt that the QT is prolonged.
    • As shown in Figure 06.13-1 â€” We measure the QT to be ~0.48 second (easily more than 2 large boxes in duration).
    • Given the heart rate = 100/minute â€” We use a correction factor of 1.3. Multiplying 0.48 X 1.3 comes to a QTc of over 600 msec! Therefore â€” we know that the QTc is dangerously prolonged without having to refer to the computer-calculated value.

    Â 

    BOTTOM Line: This QTc Addendum (Sections 06.10-thru-06.13) is written solely for those wanting additional insight into clinical use of more precise QTc determination, including a user-friendly method for rapid estimation of the QTc on your own without need to refer to the computer-calculated value. We emphasize that this is advanced material.

    • Most of the time â€” it suffices to simply use the â€œeyeball methodâ€ covered in Sections 06.1 and 06.2 for QT assessment.
    • Awareness that computerized interpretations automatically provided you with a fairly accurate QTc value corrected for heart rate helps take QT interval assessment one step further. The normal upper limit for QT duration is ~450 msec. QTc values greater than this amount indicate QT prolongation. Clinical concern about QT prolongation increases with QTc intervals that exceed 480-500 msec. Serial QTc assessment may provide additional insight when progressive increase in QT duration is subtle.
    • For those who want more â€” Try out our proposed method for rapid QTc estimation in Section 06.11.

    Â 

    07.0 â€“ Determining Axis / Hemiblocks

    07.1 â€“ Overview: Limb Lead Location

    The mean QRS Axis may be defined as the average direction of the heartâ€™s electrical activity. A standard ECG is recorded by viewing the heart’s electrical activity from 12 leads. Each lead records the heart’s electrical potential from its own particular vantage point (Figure 07.1-1).

    • As discussed in detail in Sections 03.1-thru-03.5 â€” the three standard limb leads are I, II, and III. Because electrical derivation of these leads is based on the premise of Einthoven’s equilateral triangle â€” each of these leads is separated from each other by 60Â°, starting with lead I (*at *0Â°) â€” followed by lead II (*at *+60Â°) and lead III (*60Â° further away at *+120Â°).
    • The augmented limb leads are each separated from each other by 120Â° â€” and as such form a “Mercedes-Benz” triangle (*dotted lines in *Figure 07.1-1) â€” beginning with vertical lead aVF (*at *+90Â°) â€” lateral lead aVL (*at *-30Â°) â€” and distant lead aVR (*which we can usually ignore in axis determination â€” *and need not recall its degree location).

    Â 

    Figure 07.1-1: Limb lead location for calculation of axis.

    Clinical Reality: Although axis determination is essential for diagnosis of the hemiblocks (Section 07.9) and may contribute to diagnosing RVH; pulmonary embolus; dextrocardia; and lead misplacement â€” most of the time, calculation of axis provides only *limited *clinical information.

    07.2 â€“ AXIS: The Quadrant Approach

    Mean QRS axis is calculated in the frontal plane. The 2 KEY leads that are used for axis determination are lead I and lead aVF:

    • Think of Lead I â€” as the *“starting” *point. As such, it is easy to remember that this *horizontal *lead is oriented toward 0Â° (Figure 07.2-1).
    • Lead aVF â€” is oriented perpendicular to lead I (ie, looking straight up from the Feet). Lead aVF is therefore 90Â° away from lead I (*or at *+90Â°).

    Â 

    Figure 07.2-1: Axis quadrants. A normal axis is defined by the borders of leads I and aVF (ie, *a normal axis lies between *0-to-90Â°**).

    KEY Point: It is easiest to define axis by Quadrants:

    • A normal axis (See Figure 07.2-1) â€” is defined as lying *within *the limits of lead I (*at *0Â°) and lead aVF (*at *+90Â°).
    • LAD (Left Axis Deviation) â€” lies between -1Â° to -90Â°.
    • RAD (Right Axis Deviation) â€” lies between +91Â° to +180Â°.
    • An indeterminate axis lies between +180Â° and +270Â° (*or between -90Â° and *-180Â°). This quadrant is the furthest away from the heart â€” and is often referred to as the â€œnorthwest quadrantâ€ â€“ or â€“ â€œNo-manâ€™s landâ€.

    Â 

    Clinical Note: Although by the **Quadrant Approach we describe an axis of +95Â° as â€œRADâ€ and an axis of -10Â° as â€œLADâ€ â€” we emphasize that this minimal amount of axis deviation is not of clinical consequence. It is rarely important to be more precise than within 20-to-30Â° of the actual axis.

    07.3 â€“ AXIS: The Concept of Net QRS Deflection

    Determination of the mean axis quadrant can be made *at a glance â€” *by inspection (and comparison) of the net QRS deflection in lead I vs lead aVF. To determine the â€œnetâ€ QRS deflection in any given lead â€” Mentally subtract negative deflections from positive ones (Figure 07.3-1). It is â€œnet areaâ€ that counts. For example:

    • Panel A (in Figure 07.3-1) *â€” *is all positive.
    • Panel B *â€” *is predominantly positive (compared to the R wave, the s wave is small).
    • Panel C â€” is predominantly positive (with a small q wave and a small s wave â€” but a tall R wave).
    • Panel D *â€” *is positive (albeit with no more than a small R wave).

    Â 

    NOTE: The reason we use both small-case and large-case letters in describing Q, R and S wave deflections *â€” *is to convey relative size. While we are not aware of any official distinction between small- vs *large-case â€” *We favor use of 3 mm (3 little boxes) as our defining characteristic:

    • Q, R, and S waves all manifest an amplitude of at least 3 mm.
    • The amplitude of q, r and s waves is 3 mm or less. We generally use a small-case designation for 3 mm deflections that are narrow vs large-case designation for a 3 mm deflection that is wider. Thus, we describe the complex in Panel C of Fig. 07.3-1 as a qRs deflection.

    Â 

    Figure 07.3-1: Illustration of how to assess â€œnetâ€ QRS deflection. Each of the examples shown here manifest a net positive deflection (See text).

    07.4 â€“ FIGURE 07.4-1: How to Rapidly Determine Axis Quadrant

    We can determine the quadrant in which the axis lies within seconds by 2 simple steps: Step #1: Assess the net QRS deflection in leads I and aVF; and Step #2: Use the Table in Figure 07.4-1:

    Figure 07.4-1: Rapid determination of the axis quadrant based on the net QRS deflection in leads I and aVF. For example â€” IF net QRS deflection is positive in both leads I and aVF â€” then the axis is normal (between 0-to-90Â°).

    07.5 â€“ AXIS: Refining the Quadrant Approach

    Using the Table in Figure 07.4-1 allows near instant determination of the axis quadrant. We can refine our estimate for axis by considering the following:

    • IF the net QRS deflection in lead I (at 0Â°) is about the same as that for** lead aVF** (at +90Â°) â€” then the axis should lie midway between these leads (= close to +45Â° ).
    • Instead â€” IF the net QRS deflection in lead I is positive but clearly exceeds the net deflection in lead aVF â€” then the mean QRS axis lies closer to lead I (ie, between 0Â° and +40Â°).
    • In contrast â€” the axis lies closer to lead aVF (between +50Â° and +90Â°) â€” IF the net QRS deflection in lead aVF is greater than it is in lead I.
    • The axis is perpendicular to (ie, 90Â° away* from*) a lead where the QRS complex is isoelectric (equal parts positive and negative to the QRS).
    • All you are doing is approximating. Axis calculation need not be exact â€” as long as your estimate is within 20-to-30Â° of the actual axis. As a result â€” we often provide an axis range for our answer (ie, *The axis lies between +40Â° to *+50Â°).
    • Realize that you can further refine your estimate of axis by looking at net QRS deflection in other limb leads. That said â€” this is usually not clinically needed, as will soon be apparent in review of the axis examples that follow.
    • Final Note: The computerized interpretation is usually quite accurate for determination of heart rate, intervals and axis. IF you prefer â€” you can almost always depend on the axis calculated by the computer.

    Â 

    07.6 â€“ FIGURE 07.6-1: What is the Axis?

    Based on the net QRS deflection in leads I and aVF â€” Estimate the mean QRS axis in Panels A and B of Figure 07.6-1.

    • In which of the 4 Quadrants does the axis lie? (Feel free to refer back to Sections 07.4 and 07.5 in formulating your answer).

    Â 

    Figure 07.6-1: Estimate the axis for Panels A and B. In which of the 4 quadrants does the axis lie?

    Answer to Figure 07.6-1: We can tell at a glance that the axis is normal (*between *0-to-90Â°) in both A and B â€” because the net QRS deflection in both leads I and aVF is positive in each case. Use of a quadrant diagram allows us to refine our estimate for axis (Figure 07.6-2):

    • Panel A (in Figure 07.6-1) â€” We estimate the axis at between** +30-40Â°**. The net deflection for both I and aVF is positive. The R wave in lead I is clearly taller than it is in lead aVF. As a result â€” the axis must lie closer to lead I (*or between *0-to-45Â°). We illustrate this in Panel A of Figure 07.6-2.
    • Panel B (in Figure 07.6-1) â€” We estimate the axis at between** +60-75Â°**. The net QRS deflection is decidedly more positive in aVF (Panel B in Fig. 07.6-2).

    Â 

    **Figure 07.6-2: **Quadrant diagram illustrating axis location (black arrows) for Panels A and B from Fig. 07.6-1.

    07.7 â€“ FIGURE 07.7-1: What is the Axis?

    Estimate the mean QRS axis in Panels C and D of Figure 07.7-1:

    Figure 07.7-1: Estimate the axis for Panels C and D. In which of the 4 quadrants does the axis lie?

    Answer to Figure 07.7-1: We can tell at a glance that the axis is normal for C (positive deflection in I and aVF) â€” but not normal in D (negative deflection in one of these leads). Use of a quadrant diagram allows a closer look (Figure 07.7-2):

    • Panel C (in Figure 07.7-1) â€” We estimate the axis at between** +10-20Â°**. Relative positivity of the net deflection in lead I compared to aVF is even more marked than it was for Panel A in Figure 07.6-1. The axis in Panel C must therefore lie very close to lead I (as shown in Panel C of the quadrant diagram in Figure 07.7-2).
    • Panel D (in Figure 07.7-1) â€” There is at least slight LAD (Left Axis Deviation) â€” since net QRS deflection is negative in lead aVF. As we will see momentarily in discussion of hemiblocks (Section 07.9) â€” use of lead II will be needed to determine if the amount of LAD is more or less than -30Â°. We illustrate slight leftward axis for Panel D in the corresponding quadrant diagram shown in Figure 07.7-2.

    Â 

    **Figure 07.7-2: **Quadrant diagram illustrating axis location (black arrows) for Panels C and D from Fig. 07.7-1.

    07.8 â€“ FIGURE 07.8-1: What is the Axis?

    Estimate the mean QRS axis in Panels E and F of Figure 07.8-1:

    Figure 07.8-1: Estimate the axis for Panels E and F. In which of the 4 quadrants does the axis lie?

    Answer to Figure 07.8-1: We can tell at a glance that the axis is not normal for E or F â€” because net QRS deflection is not positive in both leads I and aVF. Use of a quadrant diagram allows a closer look (Figure 07.8-2):

    • Panel E (in Figure 07.8-1) â€” There is RAD (Right Axis Deviation) â€” since* net* QRS amplitude in lead I is clearly negative (the S in lead I is deeper than the R wave is tall). We estimate mean QRS axis to be between +100-to-110Â°. We illustrate this in Panel E of the Figure 07.8-2 quadrant diagram. Clinical NOTE: It is sometimes difficult to accurately determine the specific number of degrees with right axis deviation. That said â€” it is not overly important whether the axis is +105Â°, or for that matter +120Â°. What counts clinically â€” is that there is definite RAD.
    • Panel F (in Figure 07.8-1) â€” The axis is indeterminate â€” since the net QRS deflection is negative in both leads I and aVF. Clinically â€” it no longer matters how many degrees the axis is. All that counts is that axis location is in the upper right (indeterminate) quadrant (Panel F in the Figure 07.8-2 quadrant diagram). PEARL: â€” The most common clinical conditions associated with an indeterminate axis are: i) RVH; ii) COPD; and iii) Large body habitus.

    Â 

    **Figure 07.8-2: **Quadrant diagram illustrating axis location (black arrows) for Panels E and F from Fig. 07.8-1.

    07.9 â€“ Hemiblocks: LAHB and LPHB

    07.10 â€“ Hemiblocks: Anatomic Considerations

    As seen below in Figure 07.10-1 â€” after the electrical impulse arrives at the AV Node â€” it travels down the Bundle of HIS. From there, the ventricular conduction system divides into the slender Right Bundle Branch â€” and â€” the much thicker **Common Left Bundle Branch.

    • The *Common *Left Bundle Branch divides into 2 parts: the ***Anterior ***and **Posterior Hemifascicles. Development of a â€œhemiblockâ€ â€” simply entails a defect in conduction over one of these hemifascicles.
    • Note in Figure 07.10-1 â€” that the **posterior hemifascicle is anatomically much thicker than the anterior hemifascicle. This is one reason why LPHB is uncommon. The other reason is a richer (dual) blood supply compared to the anterior hemifascicle. As a result â€” it is rare to see LPHB as an isolated defect in a patient without significant heart disease. Most patients with LPHB have bifascicular block (RBBB/LPHB â€” See Sections 07.20, 07.21).

    Â 

    Figure 07.10-1: The ventricular conduction system. Note how much thicker the left posterior hemifascicle is compared to the anterior hemifascicle and the right bundle branch.

    KEY Clinical Point: The anatomic diagram in Figure 07.10-1 is simplified. In reality â€” there are millions of fibers in the ventricular conduction system with many potential anatomic variants on the arrangement shown. That said, most of the time â€” conduction fibers to the left ventricle are arranged in two large groups (hemifascicles) â€” one of which is situated slightly in front (anterior) of the other.

    • The benefit of accepting the arrangement in Figure 07.10-1 as the general anatomic model, is that it greatly simplifies diagnosis of the hemiblocks!

    Â 

    **07.11 â€“ Advanced Concept: LSFB (a 3rd type of Fascicular Block)

    Beyond-the-Core: In a significant percentage of patients â€” a 3rd (septal) hemifascicle appears to exist (not shown in Fig. 07.10-1). The collection of fibers that make up this septal hemifascicle is thinner, more variable in distribution than are fibers in the anterior and posterior hemifascicles, and generally manifests a shorter refractory period. As its name implies â€” fibers from the septal hemifascicle contribute to early activation of a portion of the ventricular septum in certain patients.

    • As a result â€” a 3rd type of partial LBBB conduction block (in addition to LAHB and LPHB) may occur = LSFB (Left Septal Fascicular Block).
    • LSFB is not commonly recognized on ECG. This is because of several reasons: i) the existence of this 3rd hemifascicle is not well appreciated; ii) LSFB is uncommon; and iii) ECG manifestations of LSFB when it does occur are often masked by simultaneous occurrence of other conduction defects. Practically speaking â€” Do NOT be concerned about recognizing LSFB unless you are a student of advanced arrhythmia interpretation.
    • BOTTOM Line: Our reason for mentioning the existence in some patients of a septal hemifascicle and therefore a potential 3rd type of fascicular block is twofold: i) to shed light on the otherwise unexplained coming-and-going of septal q waves (or of the initial small r wave in V1,V2) that is sometimes seen in some challenging arrhythmias (may be due to intermittent LSFB aberrant conduction); and ii) to emphasize that the anatomic arrangement presented in Figure 07.10-1 is a simplification. This simplification works well for understanding the general anatomic pattern of the ventricular conduction system â€” and it allows rapid diagnosis of the hemiblocks (Section 07.12).

    Â 

    07.12 â€“ Hemiblocks: An Approach to Rapid ECG Diagnosis

    Agreement among experts is lacking regarding diagnostic criteria for hemiblock. Some experts specify a certain number of degrees in axis deviation â€” whereas others favor QRS morphology change rather than axis criteria. Fortunately â€” ECG diagnosis of hemiblocks can be simplified into an equally accurate yet user-friendly approach that allows classification in less than 5 seconds. This approach is based on the following concepts:

    • There are 2 hemiblocks that we need to concern ourselves with: anterior and posterior*. *Life is simpler (and no less accurate in the overwhelming majority of cases) if we do not initially concern ourself about the infrequent, difficult-to-diagnose 3rd type of conduction deflect = LSFB (Section 07.11).
    • Of the 2 types of hemiblock that we do need to concern ourselves with â€” Left Posterior HemiB*lock *(LPHB) â€” is rare! As already emphasized (Section 07.10) â€” the reason LPHB is so uncommon is that the posterior hemifascicle is much thicker anatomically and it has a dual blood supply (from the left and right coronary arteries); the anterior hemifascicle does not.
    • Even experts often do not agree on the ECG diagnosis of LPHB. As a result â€” You are probably none the worse if you never diagnose LPHB. On those uncommon occasions when LPHB does occur â€” it will almost always be seen in association with RBBB (See Section 07.21 and 07.25).
    • In contrast â€” diagnosis of **LAHB (L**eft Anterior Hemi-Block) â€” is far more common (>98% of hemiblocks in our experience). ECG diagnosis of LAHB becomes easy â€” IF you accept as your criterion for diagnosis recognition of a pathologic left axis (Section 07.13).

    Â 

    **07.13 â€“ LAHB: ECG Diagnosis = â€œpathologicâ€ LAD

    Expert electrocardiographers do not agree on how to define LAHB. Some define it by the number of degrees (*be this requiring a leftward axis more negative than -30Â°, -45Â°, or *-60Â°). Others maintain that rather than axis â€” it is QRS morphology in the limb leads that defines LAHB. Life is â€œsimplerâ€ (and equally accurate) â€” IF you **equate pathologic LAD = LAHB. Consider the following:

    • Some LAD (ie, -10Â° to -20Â°) â€” is common and not necessarily abnormal.
    • We define a pathologic LAD â€” as a left axis more negative than -30Â°. It is easy to tell IF pathologic LAD is present. ***You only need to look at lead II ***(Figure 07.13-1):

    Â 

    Figure 07.13-1: Diagnosis is simplified by defining LAHB as a â€œpathologicâ€ left axis (= a net deflection in lead II that is more negative than positive).

    KEY Summarizing Point: For practical purposes â€” We equate the ECG diagnosis of LAHB with the finding of pathologic LAD (*which we define as a mean QRS axis more negative than *-30Â°).

    • Assuming lead I is positive (as it almost always is) â€” then the amount of LAD is â€œpathologicâ€ â€” IF the **net deflection in Lead II is negative (*See Lead II Appearance in the lower right portion of *Figure 07.13-1).

    Â 

    **07.14 â€“ FIGURE 07.14-1: Is there LAD? IF so â€” Is there LAHB?

    Apply the quadrant approach to determine the axis for the 12-lead ECG shown in Figure 07.14-1:

    • Is there LAD? If so â€” Is there also LAHB?
    • Which lead should be used to determine if LAHB is or is not present in Figure 07.14-1?

    Â 

    Figure 07.14-1: Estimate the axis. Is there LAD? If so â€” Is there also LAHB? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 07.14-1: It is easy to determine the axis for the 12-lead ECG shown in Fig. 07.14-1 by use of the quadrant approach:

    • The net QRS deflection in lead aVF is negative. It is positive in lead I.
    • By the Table in Figure 07.4-1 â€” LAD is therefore present. The situation is similar to the example illustrated by Panel D in Section 07.7, which we reproduce below in Figure 07.14-2.
    • Once established that there is LAD â€” We determine IF the amount of LAD is â€œpathologicâ€ by looking at lead II.
    • Pathologic LAD is clearly present in Figure 07.14-1 â€” since the net QRS deflection in lead II is decidedly more negative than positive. Therefore â€” there is LAHB in Figure 07.14-1. We estimate the mean QRS axis in this tracing to be at least -40Â°.

    Â 

    Figure 07.14-2: We reproduce Panel D from Section 07.7. The situation is similar to that shown in Figure 07.14-1. There is LAD â€” because the net QRS deflection is positive in lead I and negative in lead aVF. We would need to see lead II in order to determine IF the amount of LAD was â€œpathologicâ€ (ie, more negative than -40Â°).

    07.15 â€“ SUMMARY: ECG Diagnosis of LAHB in 3 Seconds

    Panels G and H in Figure 07.15-1 summarize how to tell within seconds IF there is LAHB:

    • Panel G â€” By the quadrant approach, the more-negative-than-positive deflection in lead aVF defines there to be LAD. However the lead II deflection is not more negative than positive. Therefore the axis is not more negative than -30Â° in Panel G, which means there is LAD but not LAHB. In fact â€” the isoelectric appearance in lead II means that the axis is virtually perpendicular to (90Â° away from) lead II â€” or precisely at -30Â°.
    • Panel H â€” The once again more-negative-than-positive deflection in lead aVF defines there to be LAD. This time the lead II deflection is more negative than positive. Therefore the LAD is sufficiently leftward to qualify as LAHB. We estimate the mean QRS axis to be at least -40Â°.

    Â 

    Figure 07.15-1: Panels G and H both show LAD. There is LAHB in H but not in G (because net QRS deflection is negative in lead II for H, but not in G).

    07.16 â€“ Bifascicular Block

    07.17 â€“ Definition/Types of Bifascicular Block

    The term â€œbifascicularâ€ block â€” implies that more than a single major branch of the ventricular conduction system is not functioning. The defect in conduction may be transient or permanent. Practically speaking â€” there are 2 Types of **Bifascicular Block:

    • RBBB/LAHB = RBBB *plus *LAHB.
    • RBBB/LPHB = RBBB *plus *LPHB.

    Â 

    Clinical Note:** Semantically â€” **complete LBBB is also a type of â€œbifascicularâ€ block â€” since there is implication of failed conduction (by definition) in both anterior and posterior hemifascicles when there is LBBB. That said â€” We generally do not think of LBBB as â€œbifascicularâ€ block. This leaves us with the 2 types of hemiblock cited above (RBBB + either LAHB or LPHB).

    07.18 â€“ RBBB/LAHB: ECG Recognition

    By far â€” the most common form of bifascicular block is the combination of RBBB/LAHB. The schematic tracing in Figure 07.18-1 shows the typical ECG appearance of this conduction defect. Note the underlying rhythm is sinus (upright P wave in lead II) and the QRS looks to be wide. We focus attention on the 3 key leads for diagnosing BBB (leads I,V1,V6 â€” Section 05.2) â€” plus on lead II.

    • RBBB â€” is recognized by its characteristic appearance in the 3 key leads (rSRâ€™ with taller right rabbit ear in V1; wide terminal S wave in leads I,V6).
    • That there also is LAHB â€” is seen from the negative net deflection in lead II (Section 07.13).

    Â 

    Figure 07.18-1: RBBB/LAHB.** RBBB** â€” is diagnosed by the rSRâ€™ in lead V1 with wide, terminal S waves in I,V6. LAHB â€” is diagnosed by the decidedly *more-negative-than-positive *deflection in lead II (See text).

    07.19 â€“ The Meaning of â€œAxisâ€ when there is RBBB

    The concept of â€œaxisâ€ in the setting of RBBB is problematic. Calculation of axis is based on the average direction of the heartâ€™s electrical activity in the frontal plane. In the presence of RBBB â€” electrical activity first goes left-to-right (as the septum is depolarized) â€” then right-to-left (as the left ventricle is depolarized) â€” and then left-to-right* again* as the blocked right ventricle is finally activated via slow myocardial conduction through nonspecialized fibers. So in the setting of RBBB â€” the â€œaverage directionâ€ of the heartâ€™s electrical activity does not reflect the actual zig-zag path of the depolarization impulse.

    • Bottom Line: â€” Donâ€™t worry about â€œaxisâ€ when RBBB is present!
    • All we care about when there is RBBB â€” is which of these 3 possible settings is operative: i) RBBB and nothing else; ii) RBBB plus** LAHB**; or iii) RBBB plus** LPHB**.
    • The ECG picture of RBBB/LAHB is easy to recognize. In addition to RBBB â€” We can tell at a glance IF LAHB is also present by a look at lead II to see IF the net QRS deflection is predominantly negative (Figure 07.18-1).

    Â 

    07.20 â€“ Clinical Implications of Bifascicular Block

    The clinical significance of virtually any conduction system defect depends on the setting in which it occurs. **Isolated RBBB may sometimes occur in otherwise healthy individuals without underlying heart disease â€” in which case RBBB is unlikely to have any adverse prognostic implications (Section 05.5). In contrast â€” a **new finding of RBBB in the setting of acute evolving MI implies ongoing conduction system damage (suggesting a larger infarct size and possible need for a pacemaker).

    • **Bifascicular block â€” clearly implies a more important conduction defect than *isolated *RBBB. That said â€” IF the patient is otherwise *asymptomatic, *then bifascicular block from RBBB/LAHB may *not *necessarily convey any adverse prognostic implications. Combined RBBB/LAHB is seen surprisingly often as an incidental finding in an otherwise asymptomatic older individual.
    • On the other hand â€” IF *new *RBBB/LAHB develops in the setting of acute coronary syndrome â€” the extent of damage is probably large (and the patient may soon need a pacemaker). Clinical context is everything!
    • The other form of bifascicular block =** RBBB/LPHB** â€” is much less common. As previously stated (Section 07.10) â€” the reason LPHB is so uncommon relates to its anatomy (much thicker fascicle) and dual blood supply. As a result, IF RBBB/LPHB does occur â€” it implies a more extensive conduction system defect (with potentially more severe prognostic implications).

    Â 

    07.21 â€“ RBBB/LPHB: ECG Recognition

    The uncommon form of bifascicular block â€” is the combination of RBBB/LPHB. The schematic tracing in Figure 07.21-1 shows the typical ECG appearance of this conduction defect. Note the underlying rhythm is sinus (upright P wave in lead II) and the QRS looks to be wide. We focus attention on the 3 key leads for diagnosing BBB (leads I,V1,V6 â€” Section 05.2) â€” plus on lead II.

    • RBBB â€” is recognized by its characteristic appearance in the 3 key leads (rSRâ€™ with taller right rabbit ear in V1; wide terminal S wave in leads I,V6).
    • That there also is LPHB â€” is seen from the presence in lead I of a deep straight initial descent of the S wave in this lead. In support of the diagnosis of RBBB/LPHB â€” is the presence of a qR pattern in lead II with a relatively tall R wave in this lead.
    • NOTE: Leads II, III and aVF all typically manifest a similar ECG appearance when there is RBBB plus LPHB (ie,* a qR pattern with relatively tall R wave*). That said â€” We can simplify the process of recognizing RBBB/LPHB by focusing attention on QRS appearance in the 3 key leads (I,V1,V6) â€” plus on lead II â€” as is done in Figure 07.21-1.

    Â 

    Figure 07.21-1: RBBB/LPHB.** RBBB** â€” is diagnosed by the rSRâ€™ in lead V1 with wide, terminal S waves in I,V6. LPHB â€” is diagnosed by the very steep initial descent of the S wave in lead I. In addition â€” Note the qR pattern in lead II with relatively tall R wave (See text).

    07.22 â€“ RBBB/LPHB: Finer Points on ECG Recognition

    The experts often do not agree on the diagnosis of bifascicular block from RBBB/LPHB. The KEY to recognizing this form of bifascicular block is that once complete RBBB is identified â€” Focus attention on S wave descent in lead I.

    • As emphasized in Section 05.4 â€” a wide terminal S wave in lateral leads I,V6 is part of the expected QRS morphology seen with complete RBBB (Panel A in Figure 07.22-1). That said â€” the initial (straight portion) of the S wave in lead I is not nearly as steep with isolated RBBB â€” as it is when LPHB is also present (red arrow in Panel B of Fig. 07.22-1).

    Â 

    Figure 07.22-1: RBBB by itself (Panel A) â€” compared to bifascicular block when there is RBBB plus LPHB (Panel B). Note the very steep initial descent of the S wave (red arrow) in lead I when LPHB is also present (See text).

    Beyond-the-Core: Because the posterior hemifascicle lies not only posterior, but also inferior and rightward (in 3 dimensions) with respect to the anterior hemifascicle â€” the *blocked *portion of the QRS deflection in lead I is directed inferior and to the right. This is the reason for the steep negative S wave descent in lead I and the predominant positive R wave in leads II, III, and aVF (Panel B in Fig. 07.22-1).

    • Typically â€” there will also be a slender initial r wave in lead I and a small narrow q wave in the inferior leads (II,III,aVF) when there is RBBB/LPHB. This is because the initial direction of left ventricular depolarization with RBBB/LPHB is toward that part of the LV supplied by the intact left anterior hemifascicle. Given the relative leftward and superior orientation of the left anterior hemifascicle (compared to the relative rightward and inferior orientation of the posterior hemifascicle) â€” initial electrical activity with RBBB/LPHB tends to produce a small r in lead I and a small q in inferior leads (Panel B in Figure 07.22-1). That said â€” these subtle ECG features might be altered if in addition to RBBB/LPHB there has been prior scarring or infarction.
    • Bottom Line: â€” Remember that bifascicular block from RBBB/LPHB is uncommon in clinical practice. ECG diagnosis is often challenging and encompasses an advanced subject area about which cardiologists do not always agree. You are probably none the worse if you never diagnose this entity. Our goal is merely to highlight the ECG features we find helpful for recognizing RBBB/LPHB when it is present. Realize that once you do identify this form of bifascicular block â€” it is almost certain that your patient has extensive underlying heart disease.

    Â 

    07.23 â€“ FIGURE 07.23-1: Is there Bifascicular Block?

    Assess the ECG in Figure 07.23-1 for the presence of conduction defects.

    • Is there bifascicular block?

    Â 

    Figure 07.23-1: Sinus rhythm with RBBB/LPHB (See text).

    Answer to Figure 07.23-1: The rhythm is sinus. The QRS complex is wide.

    • RBBB â€” is recognized by its characteristic appearance in the 3 key leads (rSRâ€™ with taller right rabbit ear in V1; wide terminal S wave in leads I,V6).
    • In addition, there is LPHB â€” as diagnosed by the presence in lead I of a deep straight initial descent of the S wave in this lead. In support of the diagnosis of RBBB/LPHB â€” is the presence of a qR pattern in leads II,III,aVF with a relatively tall R wave in these leads (especially in lead III). Thus, there is bifascicular block (RBBB/LPHB).

    Â 

    07.24 â€“ FIGURE 07.24-1: Is there Bi- or Tri-Fascicular Block?

    Assess the ECG in Figure 07.24-1 for the presence of conduction defects.

    • Is there bifascicular block?
    • What is â€œtrifascicularâ€ block?

    Â 

    Figure 07.24-1: Sinus rhythm with RBBB/LAHB. Is there trifascicular block? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 07.24-1: The rhythm is sinus (upright P wave in lead II, as shown by the red arrow). The PR interval is prolonged (clearly more than a large box in duration) â€” so there is 1st degree AV block (Section 02.70).

    • The QRS complex is wide. Blowup inserts from the 3 key leads (I,V1,V6) â€” confirm RBBB (rSRâ€™ in V1; wide terminal S waves in leads I and V6). NOTE: Even though the S wave in lead I is not deep â€” it is relatively wide, and this satisfies criteria for RBBB (Section 05.4).
    • LPHB is clearly not present in Figure 07.24-1 â€” because the S in lead I is small without a steep descent.
    • On the other hand â€” LAHB is present, because the QRS deflection in lead II is predominantly negative (Section 07.18). Therefore â€” there is bifascicular block (RBBB/LAHB).

    Â 

    Beyond-the-Core: The term, â€œtrifascicularâ€ block implies impaired conduction in all 3 of the major conduction fascicles: i) the right bundle branch; ii) the left anterior hemifascicle; and iii) the left posterior hemifascicle.

    • Clinically â€” Diagnosis of *trifascicular *block is usually not possible from the surface ECG. We simply cannot tell IF PR interval prolongation in a patient with bifascicular block (as in Figure 07.24-1) is due to AV nodal disease or disease in the remaining conducting fascicle. Therefore â€” We would interpret this ECG as showing bifascicular block (RBBB/LAHB) plus 1st degree AV block.

    Â 

    07.25 â€“ FIGURE 07.25-1: Isolated LPHB vs Right Axis Deviation?

    We conclude our discussion on hemiblocks and bifascicular block with the 12-lead ECG shown in Figure 07.25-1 â€” obtained from an otherwise healthy young adult male seen in the office for an insurance physical. The rhythm is sinus (probable sinus arrhythmia) â€” and the QRS complex does not appear to be prolonged.

    • RAD (Right Axis Deviation) is clearly present â€” as determined by a predominantly negative QRS in lead I with an upright QRS in lead aVF.
    • Does this patient have LPHB?

    Â 

    Figure 07.25-1: 12-lead ECG obtained from an otherwise healthy 30-year-old man. There is RAD. Does the patient have LPHB? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 07.25-1: Although there is marked RAD â€” We would not interpret this tracing as showing LPHB because: i) LPHB is rarely seen as an isolated conduction defect; and** ii)** The patient is an otherwise healthy 30-year-old man â€” which is a distinctly unusual setting for LPHB to occur.

    • We would interpret this ECG as showing sinus arrhythmia; RAD; and peaked T waves with some J-point ST elevation that is most suggestive of an early repolarization pattern.
    • Given the considerable amount of RAD seen here â€” the possibility of RVH (Right Ventricular Hypertrophy) should be contemplated. Assuming no murmur was heard on auscultation â€” the decision of whether or not to obtain an Echo could be made clinically.
    • Perhaps if new RAD to this degree was seen in a patient with ongoing acute infarction â€” the cause might be LPHB (as occurs in Figure 10.43-1). However, given the setting described here â€” this is highly unlikely.
    • On occasion â€” otherwise healthy adolescents and young adults may present with RAD not due to RVH or other underlying structural heart disease. We suspect this is the situation here.

    Â 

    08.0 â€“ LVH: Chamber Enlargement

    The unfortunate clinical reality is that the ECG is just not very accurate as a diagnostic tool for determining chamber enlargement. Even in the best of hands â€” the sensitivity of ECG for detecting ***LVH *does not exceed 60% (although specificity may approach 90 to 95% when certain criteria are met). Diagnostic accuracy for determining RVH (Right Ventricular Hypertrophy) and atrial enlargement is even less â€¦ (See Sections 08.14-through-08.22; and 08.23-through-08.33).

    • Echocardiography is far superior to the ECG for diagnosing enlargement of any cardiac chamber.
    • Therefore â€” IF you truly need to know â€” Get an Echo!

    Â 

    08.1 â€“ ECG Diagnosis of LVH: Simplified Criteria

    There are *more than *50 sets of criteria in the literature for ECG diagnosis of LVH. None are optimal. The simplified criteria for LVH we favor as providing what we feel is the best balance between sensitivity and specificity are shown in Figure 08.1-1.

    Figure 08.1-1: Simplified ECG criteria for LVH (See text).

    KEY Points: The â€œbeautyâ€ of Figure 08.1-1 is that these simplified criteria only require recall of 2 numbers = â€œ35â€ and â€œ12â€. In our experience â€” these 2 criteria almost always allow diagnosis whenever it is possible by ECG to determine that there is LVH.

    • Only one voltage criterion (ie, 35 or 12) â€” needs to be satisfied for ECG diagnosis of LVH.
    • Note that voltage criteria for LVH may not be valid for younger patients. This is because younger adults (in their 20â€™s) often manifest increased QRS amplitude without true chamber enlargement. We suggest not using the voltage criteria in Figure 08.1-1 for patients less than 35 years old.
    • The accuracy (specificity) for the ECG diagnosis of LVH can be greatly increased â€” IF in addition to satisfying one or more voltage criteria, ST-T wave changes of “LV strain” are also present (Section 08.9).
    • The Clinical History helps in assessing for LVH. For example, it is important to appreciate even before looking at the ECG itself â€” that the chance of true chamber enlargement is greatly increased IF the tracing is obtained from a middle-aged, African-American man with longterm hypertension. KEY POINT: A history of **underlying heart disease (heart failure, hypertension, cardiomyopathy, valvular disease, coronary artery disease) â€” clearly increases the likelihood of LVH in any given patient.

    Â 

    08.2 â€“ LVH: Physiologic Rationale for Voltage Criteria

    The physiologic rationale for derivation of virtually all voltage criteria for LVH is simple. We illustrate this concept in Figure 08.2-1:

    • Normal LV (Left Ventricle) activation is directed away from right-sided leads (ie, V1,V2) â€” and toward left-sided leads (aVL; V5,V6). As a result â€” leads V1,V2 normally manifest a predominant S wave.
    • Since the LV is situated to the left and posteriorly in the thorax â€” normal LV activation generally results in a predominant R wave in left-sided leads aVL,V5,V6 (Panel A in Fig. 08.2-1). With LVH â€” there is more LV mass (large red arrow in Panel B). As a result â€” the S wave in V1,V2 becomes deeper; and the R wave in aVL and/or V5,V6 becomes taller.

    Â 

    Figure 08.2-1: Rationale for derivation of LVH voltage criteria. There is deepening of the S wave in right-sided leads = V1,V2; and/or an increase in R wave amplitude in left-sided leads (ie, V5,V6, aVL).

    08.3 â€“ LVH: ECG Diagnosis using Lead aVL

    In Section 03 â€” We discussed localization of lead aVL in the hexaxial lead system (looking down at the heart from the left shoulder at an angle of approximately -30 degrees). We then specified anatomic landmarks used for precordial lead placement when recording an ECG (Section 03.6). Awareness of this relative position of unipolar lead aVL (looking down at the heart from the left shoulder) â€” allows us to envision how lead aVL views the heartâ€™s electrical activity from a higher perspective than precordial leads (ie, V1,V2; V5,V6) that are placed on the chest.

    • As a result â€” Use of the criterion for R wave amplitude in lead aVL â‰¥12mm is likely to be most helpful when there is a leftward axis (this aVL criterion may satisfy voltage for LVH despite sometimes minimal QRS size in V1,V2 and V5,V6).
    • Remember â€” Only 1 voltage criterion (35 or 12) is needed to satisfy â€œvoltage for LVHâ€.

    Â 

    Figure 08.3-1: LVH using Lead aVL

    We illustrate use of lead aVL for making the diagnosis of LVH by voltage in Figure 08.3-1. This ECG was obtained from an older adult with hypertension. R wave amplitude in lead aVL is clearly increased (more than 3 large boxes â€” or greater than 15 mm). However â€” there is no indication at all of voltage for LVH from assessment of QRS amplitude in the precordial leads (deepest S in V1,V2 + tallest R in V5,V6 is very much less than 35 mm).

    • Since only 1 voltage criterion is needed â€” the presence of a tall R wave in lead aVL (â‰¥12 mm) in Figure 08.3-1 satisfies voltage criteria for LVH.
    • Note there is LAD â€” as is evident from the predominantly negative QRS in lead aVF with positive QRS in lead I. This supports the premise that lead aVL tends to be most helpful as a voltage criterion for LVH in the presence of a leftward axis.

    Â 

    Figure 08.3-1: ECG obtained from an older adult with hypertension. Voltage criteria for LVH are satisfied by the tall R wave in lead aVL (â‰¥12 mm) â€” despite relatively low voltage in the precordial leads (See text).

    08.4 â€“ FIGURE 08.4-1: Is there Voltage for LVH?

    The ECG in Figure 08.4-1 was obtained from an otherwise healthy 29-year old man who was seen in the office for an â€œinsurance physicalâ€.

    • Is there LVH?
    • HINT: Feel free to review the simplified criteria for LVH in Figure 08.1-1 before answering.

    Â 

    Figure 08.4-1: ECG from a 29-year old man. Is there LVH?

    Answer to Figure 08.4-1: The ECG shows sinus arrhythmia and is essentially normal. There is no LVH â€” because this patient is less than 35 years old. Note that ST-T waves are unremarkable. There is no indication of LV â€œstrainâ€.

    • We illustrate how to assess for voltage by the blow-up of the 4 key precordial leads shown in Figure 08.4-2. As per the criteria detailed in Figure 08.1-1 â€” one adds the deepest S wave in leads V1,V2 plus the tallest R wave in V5,V6. The sum = 43 (ie, 20 + 23=43) â€” but since the patient is under 35 years of age â€” voltage for LVH is not present (Section 08.7).

    Â 

    Figure 08.4-2: Blowup of selected precordial leads from Figure 08.4-1 to illustrate how QRS amplitude is counted. The deepest S wave in V1,V2 is 20 (in lead V1) + the tallest R wave in V5, V6 (= 23 in lead V5) is >35 â€“ BUT â€“ because the patient is less than 35 years of age â€” voltage for LVH is not present.

    08.5 â€“ Standardization Mark: Is Standardization Normal?

    Most of the time â€” the ECG will be set to normal standardization. Confirmation that this is the case is easily achieved by recognition of the standardization mark at the very beginning or end of the 12-lead recording (black arrow at the onset of lead III in Figure 08.4-1).

    • Normal standardization is designated by a rectangular standardization mark that is 10 mm (=2 large boxes)** tall**.
    • On occasion â€” ECG complexes may be extremely large and extend beyond the space provided for one or more leads on the tracing. Selection of half standardization reduces waveform amplitude by half â€” with result that the entire complex in each lead will again fit on the ECG recording paper and be seen.
    • These concepts are illustrated in Figure 08.5-1 â€” in which the Top Panel is a blow-up of leads III and aVF from Figure 08.4-1.
    • IF instead, this ECG was recorded at half standardization â€” actual QRS amplitude would be twice that shown = 10 vs 5 in lead III; and 26 vs 13 in lead aVF (Lower Panel in Fig. 08.5-1).

    Â 

    Figure 08.5-1: Blowup of Figure 08.4-1 to illustrate the appearance of a normal (top) and half (bottom) standardization mark. Actual voltage is twice that shown when the ECG is recorded at half standardization.

    08.6 â€“ LVH: Additional Voltage Criteria

    No single voltage criterion will identify all patients with LVH. As a result â€” we occasionally turn to additional voltage criteria. We favor any of the following:

    • A deep S wave (â‰¥20-25 mm) in lead V1 or V2.
    • A tall R wave (*â‰¥25 mm in *V5 â€” or *â‰¥20 mm in *V6).
    • An R wave â‰¥20 in any inferior lead (II, III, or aVF).
    • Cornell Criteria â€” LVH is present IF sum of R wave in lead aVL + S wave in lead V3 is â‰¥20mm (female) or â‰¥28mm (male).

    Â 

    Bottom Line: In our experience, IF all you remember are the numbers â€˜35â€™ and â€˜12â€™ for LVH voltage criteria â€” then ~90%* of the time* when it is possible to diagnose LVH on the ECG of an adult, you will be able to do so!

    • Satisfying any of the above additional criteria should help to pick up most of the remaining ~10%.
    • Incorporating Clinical History and looking for â€œstrainâ€ or a strain *â€œequivalentâ€ *pattern (Section 08.13) â€” will further refine and increase accuracy (specificity) of your diagnosis.
    • Keep in mind that competing conditions (ie, hyperkalemia, acute infarction, conduction defects, pulmonary disease) â€” may mask ECG diagnosis of LVH.
    • IF you really need to know about chamber size â€” Get an Echo. The ECG is simply not optimally accurate.

    Â 

    08.7 â€“ LVH: Voltage Criteria for Patients Less than 35

    Young adults often have increased amplitude not due to true chamber enlargement. As a â€œballparkâ€ estimate for LVH voltage criteria when the patient is 35 years old â€” We use sum of the deepest S wave in V1,V2 + tallest R wave in V5,V6 â‰¥53. This number â€˜53â€™ can be easily remembered â€” because it is the reverse of the number â€˜35â€™.

    • Look at the selected precordial lead sequence shown in Figure 08.7-1 (previously shown in Fig. 08.4-2). Sum of the deepest S wave in V1,V2 (20) + tallest R wave in V5,V6 (23) = 43 mm.
    • We were initially told (in Section 08.4) â€” that these leads were obtained from a 29-year old man. In this case â€” voltage criteria for LVH would not be met (the patient is under 35 â€” and the voltage sum is less than 53).
    • On the other hand, IF this patient was over 35 â€” then voltage criteria for LVH would be satisfied (since the voltage sum is more than 35).

    Â 

    Figure 08.7-1: Selected precordial leads reproduced from Fig. 08.4-2. Is there voltage for LVH (See text).

    KEY Point: There is no â€œmagicâ€ per se about becoming 35 years old and suddenly satisfying voltage criteria for LVH. The age â€œcutoffâ€ is far from precise. That said, it is helpful to be aware that more often than not when a healthy adult under 35 manifests increased QRS amplitude but without ST-T wave changes of â€œstrainâ€ â€” most of the time there is not true chamber enlargement.

    08.8 â€“ FIGURE 08.8-1: Which Leads for What with LVH?

    In an attempt to expedite ECG recognition of LVH â€” We suggest use of Figure 08.8-1. This figure highlights our two favored LVH voltage criteria (Section 08.1):

    • LVH by â€œ35â€ â€” We look for deepest S wave in V1,V2 + tallest R wave in V5,V6. If â‰¥35 = LVH.
    • LVH by â€œ12â€ â€” If the R wave in lead aVL â‰¥12 = LVH.
    • We then look for LV â€œstrainâ€ or a strain â€œequivalentâ€ (Section 08.13) â€” in one (or more) of the left-sided leads = I,aVL; V4,V5,V6.
    • For LAE â€” Look at lead II (notched P wave) and/or lead V1 (deep negative component to the P in V1).
    • For RAE (not shown on this Figure) â€” Use lead II (Sections 08.19).

    Â 

    Figure 08.8-1: Chamber Enlargement: *Which leads for what? *

    **08.9 â€“ LV â€œStrainâ€: *ECG Recognition ***

    It is difficult to define â€œstrainâ€. We conceptualize the ECG picture of â€œstrainâ€ as â€” a pattern of **asymmetric ST-T depression (Figure 08.9-1). Perhaps â€œstrainâ€ simply reflects that point of anatomic ventricular enlargement at which increased demand (from chamber thickening) outstrips blood supply â€” with resultant ST-T wave repolarization changes from suboptimal perfusion. Or perhaps not. That said â€” What counts clinically is ECG recognition of a â€œstrainâ€ pattern.

    • Note how downslope of the ST segment in Figure 08.9-1 is slower with ***â€œstrainâ€ ***(*arrow in *Panel C) â€” compared to the more rapid return of the ST segment to baseline.

    Â 

    Figure 08.9-1: ST-T wave appearance of normal (A) â€” vs â€œstrainâ€ (C) or a strain â€œequivalentâ€ (B) â€” vs ischemia (D).

    **Pattern Recognition: **The concept of pattern recognition is essential to ECG diagnosis. Consider the following:

    • With ischemia (seen in Panel D of Figure 08.9-1) â€” there will often be **symmetric T wave inversion in two or more leads in a general lead area.
    • NOTE: As one traces the path in Figure 08.9-1 from a *normal *ST-T wave (seen in Panel A) â€” to the **asymmetric ST-T wave typical of LV â€œstrainâ€ (seen in Panel C) â€” one passes through an intermediate stage, where the ST-T wave flattens with beginning ST depression (Panel B). We designate this intermediate stage as a strain equivalentâ€.

    Â 

    ***Terminology: *In general, when we use the term â€œstrainâ€ â€” We are referring to LV â€œstrainâ€ that develops in response to Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH).

    • There is also RV â€œstrainâ€ â€” that typically develops in association with marked RVH or in response to acute pulmonary embolus. For now â€” *Think *LV â€œstrainâ€ when we use the unspecified designation of â€œstrainâ€ (RV â€œstrainâ€ is discussed in Sections 08.28, 08.29).

    Â 

    Which are the Leads that may show LV â€œStrainâ€?

    We expect to see LV â€œstrainâ€ in leads that look at the left ventricle. These include one (or more) of the lateral leads I,aVL; and V4,V5,V6 (highlighted by green boxes in Figure 08.8-1).

    • *Less *often â€” a typical LV â€œstrainâ€ pattern (with asymmetric ST-T wave depression) may also be seen in the inferior leads â€” especially if the patient has a relatively vertical (inferior) axis.
    • LV â€œstrainâ€ â€” is generally not seen in anterior leads (V1,V2,V3). In contrast, RV â€œstrainâ€ (as may occur with RVH or acute pulmonary embolus) â€” typically is seen in either anterior or inferior leads (See Section 08.29).

    Â 

    FIGURE 08.9-2: Which Leads Show LV â€œStrainâ€?

    The ECG in Figure 08.9-2 was obtained from a patient with longstanding hypertension. There is obvious voltage for LVH (very deep S wave in V2 + very tall R wave in V6).

    • Which of the 5 lateral leads manifest ST-T wave changes consistent with â€œstrainâ€?
    • Explain the ST-T wave depression seen in each of the inferior leads (II,III,aVF).

    Â 

    Figure 08.9-2: ECG from a patient with longstanding hypertension. Which leads show ST-T wave changes consistent with LV â€œstrainâ€? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 08.9-2: The rhythm is sinus. As stated â€” there is obvious voltage for LVH (very deep S wave in V2 + very tall R wave in V6).

    • ST-T wave changes consistent with LV â€œstrainâ€ are clearly seen in lead V6 of Figure 08.9-2. We would interpret the flat ST segment with slight T inversion in lead V5 as a â€œstrain equivalentâ€ (Section 08.13). Neither aVL nor lead V4 manifest â€œstrainâ€ (upright T wave in these leads). The nonspecific ST-T wave flattening in lead I might be a strain â€œequivalentâ€ â€” albeit minimal QRS amplitude in this lead makes this supposition less convincing.
    • NOTE: Asymmetric ST-T wave depression in each of the inferior leads (II,III,aVF) in this tracing looks typical for LV â€œstrainâ€ (closely resembles Panel C in Fig. 08.9-1). Given the relatively vertical axis (about +75 degrees) â€” it is far more likely that these inferior ST-T wave changes reflect LV â€œstrainâ€ rather than ischemia (especially if the patient is not having new or recent chest discomfort). Thus, the ECG in Fig. 08.9-2 appears to represent an example of the occasional occurrence of LV â€œstrainâ€ in inferior as well as lateral leads.

    Â 

    Beyond-the-Core: NOTE in Figure 08.9-2 â€” that the ST segment is elevated in leads V2,V3.

    • Is this likely to reflect an ACS (Acute Coronary Syndrome)?

    Â 

    Answer: As will be discussed in detail in Sections 09 and 10 â€” ST segment deviations (elevation or depression) are most often judged with respect to the preceding PR segment baseline. With this in mind â€” there unmistakably is at least 2 mm of ST elevation in leads V2,V3. That said â€” it is highly unlikely that this anterior ST elevation represents ACS because:

    • There is no mention of chest discomfort in this patient with longstanding hypertension.
    • In patients with LVH and â€œstrainâ€ â€” there will often be several mm of ST elevation in anterior leads as a mirror-image reflection of lateral precordial â€œstrainâ€. Note that IF you flipped over the ECG complex in lead V6 of Figure 08.9-2 (very tall R wave; ST-T changes of strain) â€” that the result would be identical to what is seen in leads V2,V3 (very deep S wave; mirror-image ST-T wave appearance of what was seen in V6).
    • BOTTOM Line: In addition to ST-T wave depression that may be seen in one or more of the lateral leads with LV â€œstrainâ€ â€” slight ST elevation (with mirror-image appearance to the ST-T wave in lateral leads) may also be seen in anterior leads.

    Â 

    08.10 â€“ LV â€œStrainâ€: Voltage for LVH vs True Chamber Enlargement

    The reason it is important to recognize ***â€œstrainâ€ ***â€” is that this finding greatly increases the accuracy of the ECG diagnosis of LVH.

    • The presence of *increased *voltage without â€œstrainâ€ â€” has *low *specificity (50%) for true chamber enlargement (especially if the patient is otherwise healthy and without underlying heart disease). We interpret the finding of increased voltage without ST-T wave changes of â€œstrain as â€œVoltage for LVHâ€. This designation serves to acknowledge that despite an increase in QRS amplitude â€” statistical likelihood of true chamber enlargement is low.
    • NOTE: On occasion there may be typical ST-T wave changes of LV â€œstrainâ€ â€” but without voltage for** LVH**. The ECG is simply not that sensitive for demonstrating increased QRS amplitude in patients with anatomic LV chamber enlargement. While we do not advise making a definitive ECG diagnosis of â€œLVHâ€ in the absence of voltage criteria â€” We may nevertheless suspect LVH rather than ischemia in the presence of asymmetric ST depression IF: i) the history does not sound like there is cardiac chest pain; and ii) the patient has one or more conditions predisposing to LVH. Clearly â€” Clinical correlation is needed.

    Â
