    Assess the ECG in Figure 08.10-1 for LVH. We previously encountered this tracing in Figure 08.4-1 â€” at which time we were told that it came from a 29-year old man. Despite sum of deepest S wave in V1,V2 + tallest R wave in V5,V6 being >35mm â€” the patientâ€™s age (ie, less than 35 years old) meant that voltage criteria for LVH were not fulfilled.

    • BUT â€” What IF instead of a 29-year old man, this ECG had been obtained from a 40-year old man? Would there now be voltage for LVH?
    • NOTE: ST-T waves are normal in all lateral leads in Figure 08.10-1 â€” such that there is no indication of LV â€œstrainâ€.

    Â 

    Figure 08.10-1: ECG previously seen in Fig. 08.4-1. Is there voltage for** LVH?** (See text).

    Answer to Figure 08.10-1: IF instead of being 29, the patient was 40 â€” then the ECG in Fig. 08.10-1 would meet voltage criteria for LVH. That said â€” the absence of any ST-T wave indication of â€œstrainâ€ means that the chance of true chamber enlargement is still low. This is especially true if this 40-year old man was previously healthy with normal blood pressure.

    08.11 â€“ FIGURE 08.11-1: Is there True Chamber Enlargement?

    Contrast the ECG just shown in Figure 08.10-1 â€” with the 6 precordial leads in Figure 08.11-1. These precordial leads were obtained from an older adult with longstanding hypertension.

    • Is there LVH? What is the likelihood of true chamber enlargement?

    Â 

    Figure 08.11-1: Precordial lead sequence obtained from an older adult with longstanding hypertension. What is the likelihood of true chamber enlargement?

    Answer to Figure 08.11-1: QRS amplitude is markedly increased in the 6 precordial leads shown â€” easily satisfying voltage criteria for LVH (Section 08.1). In addition â€” note ST-T wave changes consistent with LV â€œstrainâ€ in leads V4,V5,V6*. Specificity* for LVH has got to be close to 100%.

    KEY Point: Once â€œstrainâ€ and voltage** are both present â€” specificity for true chamber enlargement goes way up (to ~90% â€” and >95% if the patient has underlying heart disease). This is seen in Figure 08.11-1.

    • ECG diagnosis of LVH plus** â€œstrainâ€** is not a trivial one. The Framingham study demonstrated up to an 8-fold increased morbidity/mortality in patients with longstanding hypertension when there was evidence of LVH with â€œstrainâ€ on their office ECG tracing.

    Â 

    08.12 â€“ Can there be both LV â€œStrainâ€ and Ischemia?

    Clinically â€” both ischemia and** â€œstrainâ€** may exist at the same time. Patients with LVH from longstanding hypertension may also have coronary disease. If anything â€” such patients are at greater risk of ischemia/infarction.

    • The ECG changes of either ischemia or â€œstrainâ€ may mask the other. In some patients â€” symmetric T wave inversion may predominate. In others â€” J-point depression with asymmetric ST segment sagging may be more prominent. Distinguishing between acute ischemia vs â€œstrainâ€ may be extremely challenging (if not impossible) from review of a single ECG tracing.
    • NOTE: When history and ST-T wave appearance suggest that both LV â€œstrainâ€ and ischemia are present â€” We often write the following on our interpretation: â€œLVH and strain and/or ischemia. Suggest clinical correlationâ€. This is precisely what we would write for interpretation of the precordial lead sequence shown in Figure 08.12-1.

    Â 

    Figure 08.12-1: Precordial lead sequence obtained from an older adult with a history of coronary disease. We would write the following for our interpretation: **LVH and â€œstrainâ€ and/or ischemia (See text).

    **Figure 08.12-1: Additional Points of Interest

    • Note that standardization is normal in Fig. 08.12-1 (arrow at the end of V4 indicating the rectangular standardization mark is 2 large boxes tall as it should be).
    • Note slight variation in S wave depth in lead V2. Such slight variation is common. We sometimes adjust for it by taking an average for amplitude in a given lead.
    • Note overlap (within the red circle) of the S wave from V4 with the R wave in V5. We could have eliminated this by recording the tracing at half standardization. That said â€” most of the time we prefer normal standardization. The point to emphasize is that caution is needed in determining true R wave amplitude in lead V5 of Figure 08.12-1.

    Â 

    **KEY Points: Comparing Figs. 08.11-1 and 08.12-1:

    Our interpretation of ST-T wave appearance in Figure 08.12-1 contrasts with that from Fig. 08.11-1. The best way to highlight this contrast is by side-to-side comparison of both tracings (Panels A and B in Figure 08.12-2):

    • In both Panel A and Panel B â€” deepest S wave in V1,V2 + tallest R wave in V5,V6 easily satisfy voltage criteria for LVH.
    • In Panel A â€” ST-T wave appearance in leads V5,V6 strongly suggests LV â€œstrainâ€ (there is asymmetric ST depression with slow sagging downslope).
    • In contrast, for Panel B â€” ST segments are coved in V3-through-V6. In addition, there is 1-2 mm of J-point ST depression (below the PR segment baseline) in leads V4,V5,V6 â€” with T wave inversion that is deep and appears to be much more symmetric (especially in leads V4,V5). This appearance is more suggestive of ischemia.
    • In particular â€” lead V3 in Panel B looks ischemic (pure LV â€œstrainâ€ virtually never produces ST coving and symmetric T inversion this far anterior).
    • Lead V6 in Panel B â€” has an intermediate appearance between â€œstrainâ€ and/or ischemia. Given that this patient is â€œolderâ€ and has a history of heart disease and decidedly meets voltage criteria for LVH â€” We would interpret this tracing as, â€œLVH and â€œstrainâ€ and/or ischemia.â€ Clinical correlation and comparison with prior tracings would be needed to determine IF an acute ischemic process might be ongoing.

    Â 

    Figure 08.12-2: Comparison of the precordial lead sequence from Figure 08.11-1 (Panel A) with that from Figure 08.12-1 (Panel B). Voltage criteria for LVH are easily satisfied in each tracing. ST-T wave changes in Panel B are much more suggestive of LVH with ischemia and/or â€œstrainâ€ (See text).

    Return to Panel A in Figure 08.12-2. Note that the J-point appears to be slightly depressed in leads V4-through-V6, and that there is subtle ST coving in the depressed ST segment in V4. Thus, although the overall picture in Panel A is clearly more suggestive of LVH with â€œstrainâ€ â€” We can not exclude the possibility of some component of ischemia.

    • Clinical correlation is needed.
    • Availability of prior tracings on this patient would help to determine whether J-point depression in Panel A is new or old. In the meantime â€” Interpreting ST-T wave changes in Panel A as consistent with â€œstrain and/or ischemiaâ€ with need for clinical correlation is appropriate.

    Â 

    08.13 â€“ Strain â€œEquivalentâ€ Patterns: Clinical Implications

    As discussed in Section 08.9 â€” an intermediate â€œstrain equivalentâ€ stage exists, in which the ST-T wave is not completely â€œnormalâ€ â€” but does not yet manifest full appearance of the asymmetric sagging ST segment characteristic of â€œstrainâ€. We expand on this concept in Figure 08.13-1:

    • Clinical implications of LVH voltage plus a ***â€œstrain equivalentâ€ ***(*any of the 3 examples shown below in *Figure 08.13-1) â€” are the same as they are for the fully developed pattern of â€œstrainâ€ (=*greatly increased specificity for LVH *â€” and a worse longterm prognosis).

    Â 

    Figure 08.13-1: Examples of â€œstrain equivalentâ€ patterns (See the illustrative ECG shown below in Figure 08.13-2).

    FIGURE 08.13-2: Is there LVH with â€œStrainâ€?

    Apply the concept of recognizing an ST-T â€œstrain equivalentâ€ pattern to the precordial lead sequence shown in Figure 08.13-2, taken from a middle-aged man with hypertension.

    • Are ECG criteria for LVH satisfied? If so â€” What is the likelihood of true chamber enlargement in Fig. 08.13-2?

    Â 

    Figure 08.13-2: Precordial lead sequence from a patient with hypertension. Is there LVH? What is the likelihood of true chamber enlargement? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 08.13-2: Voltage criteria for LVH are satisfied â€” as sum of deepest S wave in V1,V2 + tallest R wave in V5,V6 is >35 (ie, 17 + 21 = 38).

    • The ST-T wave segment in lateral leads V4,V5,V6 is not normal. Instead â€” there clearly is flattening of the ST segment and T wave, with a hint of ST depression. That said â€” a fully developed pattern of LV â€œstrainâ€ is not seen.
    • Impression: The ST-T wave in leads V4,V5,V6 of Figure 08.13-2 closely resembles the 3rd â€œstrain equivalentâ€ pattern shown in the lower panel of Figure 08.13-1. In view of the history (hypertension) and more than adequate voltage for LVH â€” we would write â€œLVHâ€ (not just â€˜voltageâ€™ for LVH) on our interpretation. The likelihood of true chamber enlargement is high.

    Â 

    08.14 â€“ Atrial Enlargement

    The ECG is neither sensitive nor specific for **atrial enlargement (Echo is far more accurate). That said â€” there are times when the ECG may provide suggestive clues which clinically are very helpful (Figure 08.16-1):

    • Recognition of LAA (Left Atrial Abnormality) â€” may support the ECG diagnosis of LVH (especially in the presence of underlying BBB).
    • Recognition of RAA (Right Atrial Abnormality) in association with other ECG signs â€” may strongly **suggest RVH (and/or pulmonary hypertension). It may also suggest acute pulmonary embolus.
    • ECG signs of **multichamber enlargement (*at least LVH, LAA, RAA *â€” and possibly also RVH) â€” when seen in a patient with underlying heart disease **suggests cardiomyopathy.

    Â 

    08.15 â€“ Terminology: Enlargement vs Abnormality?

    Many clinicians use LAA/RAA â€” and LAE/RAE interchangeably. We prefer the terms, â€œLAAâ€ and â€œRAAâ€ (where the â€œAâ€ stands for Abnormality) in acknowledgement that an **abnormal-looking P wave on ECG does not always mean true *atrial *chamber enlargement. It simply means a different-than-usual P wave appearance.

    • Other Reasons for Abnormal P Waves â€” include body habitus (tall, peaked P waves may be seen in slender individuals with a vertical axis); increased atrial pressure (ie, from heart failure) and intra-atrial conduction defects.
    • Clinical context will usually suggest whether RAA/LAA is likely to reflect true atrial â€œenlargementâ€ â€” or *something else. *
    • IF we know true atrial chamber Enlargement is likely (because of marked LVH or RVH on ECG in a patient with underlying heart disease) â€” then we may switch to the LAâ€œEâ€ or RAâ€œEâ€ designation. Otherwise â€” we generally prefer to use the terms LAâ€œAâ€ or RAâ€œAâ€.
    • NOTE: The atrial do not â€œhypertrophyâ€, in that their walls donâ€™t thicken. Instead â€” the atria enlarge (dilate).

    Â 

    08.16 â€“ FIGURE 08.16-1: ECG Criteria for RAA/LAA

    ECG Criteria for the diagnosis of RAA and LAA are summarized pictorially in Figure 08.16-1. Note that the 2 leads used to assess for atrial abnormality are lead II and lead V1.

    • We explore the physiologic rationale for these ECG criteria in Section 08.17.
    • We discuss specific ECG findings suggesting RAA and LAA in detail in Sections 08.18-through-08.20.

    Â 

    Figure 08.16-1: ECG signs of atrial abnormality/enlargement (See text).

    08.17 â€“ Physiologic Rationale for Normal P Wave Appearance**

    Physiologic rationale for the ECG signs of atrial enlargement is based on: i) anatomic location of lead V1 (the V1 electrode lies over the RA = right atrium) â€” and â€” ii) relative direction of RA and LA depolarization with respect to the SA node (Figure 08.17-1).

    • With** NSR** (Normal Sinus Rhythm) â€” the impulse begins in the SA Node â€” which lies in the upper part of the right atrium (Panel A in Fig. 08.17-1). Activation of the RA will therefore be seen as approaching lead V1 â€” whereas activation of the LA will be seen as moving away from lead V1 (red arrows in Panel B). This explains why in theory â€” the P wave in lead V1 should normally be biphasic, with an initial positive component (as the RA is depolarized) â€” followed by a negative component (as the LA is depolarized).
    • In Practice â€” the normal P wave in** lead V1** may be positive, negative or biphasic (as is shown under NSR in Fig. 08.16-1).
    • The reason the P wave is normally upright in lead II with sinus rhythm is shown in Panel C of Figure 08.17-1. Summation of RA and LA activation is seen as moving toward lead II at +60 degrees (red arrows in Panel C).

    Â 

    Figure 08.17-1: Physiologic basis for why with NSR (Normal Sinus Rhythm) â€” the P wave in lead V1 may be positive, negative or biphasic (Panel B) â€” whereas in lead II, the normal P wave will be upright (Panel C).

    08.18 â€“ A Closer Look: The P Wave with Normal Sinus Rhythm

    Appreciation of the concepts illustrated in Figure 08.17-1 facilitates an understanding of normal sinus P wave appearance in leads II and V1 â€” as well as an understanding of what happens to P wave appearance in these same leads with RAA/LAA.

    • With** NSR (Normal Sinus Rhythm)** â€” the P wave in lead II should be upright (Figure 08.18-1). However â€” the P wave may normally be upright, negative or biphasic in lead V1.
    • Realize that IF there are 2 components to the P wave in lead V1 â€” the 1st component (which will be positive) represents RA depolarization (since the sinus node is in the RA). The 2nd component (which is negative) â€” represents LA activation. It is this 2nd (negative) component that gets larger when there is LAA (Section 08.20).
    • KEY Point: The finding of a negative P wave in lead V1 is not abnormal. It does not necessarily mean the left atrium is large IF this negative component to the P wave is relatively small (Section 08.20).
    • Clinical Note: Be aware that minor deviation from correct lead placement may alter P wave appearance in lead V1. Despite best intentions â€” the clinical reality is that precordial lead misplacement is relatively common.

    Â 

    Figure 08.18-1: ECG appearance of the normal P wave in** leads II** and** V1**. Note that with sinus rhythm â€” the normal P wave in lead V1 may be upright, negative or biphasic.

    08.19 â€“ ECG Diagnosis of RAA: P Pulmonale

    RAA (Right Atrial Abnormality) â€” is diagnosed by the finding of tall Peaked and Pointed P waves in the Pulmonary leads (Figure 08.19-1). Because patients with COPD often have low diaphragms (and therefore an inferior axis) â€” we think of the inferior leads (II,III,aVF) as the â€œpulmonaryâ€ leads.

    • The P wave should be half a large box tall (=2.5mm) â€” in at least one of the inferior leads for RAA.
    • IF the P wave in one or more inferior leads looks ***â€œuncomfortable to sit onâ€ ***â€” Think RAA! = P Pulmonale.
    • Most of the time â€” Lead V1 will not be helpful in ECG diagnosis of RAA.
    • Beyond-the-Core: On occasion â€” RAA may be suggested by P wave appearance in lead V1 IF the positive component of the P wave is pointed. This is true even if this pointed positive component is not quite 2.5 mm tall.

    Â 

    Figure 08.19-1: ECG criteria for RAA (P pulmonale). Most commonly â€” ECG diagnosis of RA is made from P wave appearance in lead II (tall, peaked and pointed P wave at least 2.5 mm tall). The P wave looks, â€œuncomfortable to sit onâ€. On occasion â€” RAA may be suggested by the finding of a pointed positive component to the P wave in lead V1.

    08.20 â€“ ECG Diagnosis of LAA: P Mitrale

    LAA (Left Atrial Abnormality) â€” is diagnosed by finding an **m-**shaped (notched) and widened P wave (â‰¥0.12 second) in a “mitral” lead (*I,II,aVL *) â€” and/or a deep negative component to the P wave in lead V1 = P Mitrale (Figure 08.20-1).

    • The reason the P wave becomes wider with LAA is that the left atrium is activated after the right atrium (since the SA Node is in the RA). It is addition of this LA component to the P wave that produces the notch/extra â€˜humpâ€™ to form the â€œMâ€ in lead II.
    • The best ECG sign of LAA is the finding of a deep, negative component to the P wave in lead V1 â€” that is at least 1 little box deep or wide.
    • We generally undercall LAA â€” because of the overall poor specificity the ECG has for atrial enlargement. Remember that some negativity to the P wave in lead V1 is a normal finding! Therefore, it is best not to even contemplate an ECG diagnosis of â€œLAAâ€ â€” unless the negative component to the P wave in lead V1 is definitely at least 1 little box deep and/or wide.

    Â 

    Figure 08.20-1: ECG criteria for LAA (P mitrale) in lead II and lead V1. Look for a notched (longer) P wave in lead II â€” and a deep negative component to the P wave in lead V1 (that is at least 1 little box deep and/or wide). It is best to undercall the ECG diagnosis of LAA (See text).

    **08.21 â€“ FIGURE 08.21-1: *Is there ECG Evidence of RAA/LAA? ***

    Assess the ECG in Figure 08.21-1 for RAA and LAA. Keep in mind that this tracing was obtained from an otherwise healthy and asymptomatic 27-year old man who was seen in the office for an insurance physical.

    Figure 08.21-1: ECG obtained from a healthy 27-year old man. Is there ECG evidence for RAA/LAA? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 08.21-1: There is sinus arrhythmia. All intervals (PR/QRS/QT) are normal. The axis is vertical but still within the normal range of zero to +90 degrees. Given the near isoelectric QRS complex in lead I (which manifests no more than a minimal net positive deflection) â€” We estimate the mean QRS axis to be about +80 degrees.

    • There is no LVH â€” as the patient is less than 35 years of age (Section 08.7).
    • There is RAA (tall peaked and pointed P waves in the â€˜pulmonary leadsâ€™ â€” with the P wave in lead II â‰¥ 2.5 mm).
    • There is no LAA â€” as the P wave is not notched, and there is no negative component to the P wave in lead V1.
    • Regarding QRST Changes: There are small septal q waves in multiple leads; transition occurs between lead V2-to-V3 (which is normal); and ST-T wave changes are unremarkable.

    Â 

    Impression: This ECG is probably not abnormal â€” given that it was obtained from an otherwise healthy and asymptomatic 27-year old man. Use of the term, â€œRAAâ€ â€” allows us to indicate that the P wave is larger than is normally seen without â€œlabelingâ€ this patient as having right atrial pathology. Instead â€” it is much more likely that the vertical axis and peaked inferior P waves seen here reflect a normal variant in an otherwise healthy young adult with a vertical ECG axis and an anatomically normal right atrium.

    08.22 â€“ FIGURE 08.22-1: Is there ECG Evidence of RAA/LAA?

    The ECG in Figure 08.22-1 was obtained from an older adult with heart failure. Assess this tracing for ECG evidence of chamber enlargement.

    • What clinical diagnosis is suggested by the ECG picture shown here?

    Â 

    Figure 08.22-1: ECG obtained from an older patient with heart failure. Which cardiac chambers are enlarged? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 08.22-1: The rhythm is sinus. The PR, QRS and QT intervals are normal. There is RAD (Right Axis Deviation) â€” as diagnosed by the markedly negative net deflection of the QRS in lead I (Section 07.4).

    • There is RAA (tall peaked and pointed P waves in the â€˜pulmonary leadsâ€™ â€” with the P wave in lead II at least half a large box tall).
    • There is LAA (deep negative component to the P wave in lead V1).
    • There is LVH (very deep S waves in V1,V2 + very tall R waves in V5,V6). ST-T wave changes are consistent with LV â€œstrainâ€ and/or ischemia (Section 08.12).
    • There is also probable RVH (marked RAD + RAA).
    • PEARL: The presence of multichamber enlargement (at least 3 chambers) in a patient with heart failure is strongly suggestive of cardiomyopathy.

    Â 

    08.23 â€“ RVH/Pulmonary Disease

    Detection of right ventricular enlargement in adults by ECG criteria is often exceedingly difficult. This is because the LV (Left Ventricle) is normally so much larger and thicker than the RV (Right Ventricle) in adults â€” that it masks even moderate increases in right ventricular chamber size. As a result, many patients with RVH (Right Ventricular Hypertrophy) will not be identified â€” IF assessment for chamber enlargement is limited to obtaining an ECG (an Echo is needed to know for sure).

    • NOTE: In contrast to adults â€” ECG diagnosis of RVH is often surprisingly easy in children with congenital heart disease (because relative size of the RV compared to the LV is not nearly as different as it is in adults).

    Â 

    08.24 â€“ ECG Diagnosis of RVH: Simplified Criteria

    Development of RVH may lead to a number of ECG findings. We list these in Figure 08.24-1. None of these findings alone will accurately predict anatomic RV enlargement. Instead â€” Several criteria are needed.

    • Think of the ECG diagnosis of RVH as similar to making a **“detective” diagnosis. No single clue solves the mystery. With regard to ECG interpretation â€” No single finding in Figure 08.24-1 is diagnostic. Instead â€” determination of RVH is made by deduction (ie, *from identifying a combination of the *ECG findings *listed in *Fig. 08.24-1):

    Â 

    Figure 08.24-1: ECG criteria for RVH. A combination of at least several of these criteria is needed for accuracy (See text).

    Clinical NOTE: Pulmonary disease without frank RVH is common in longterm smokers. Progression to cor pulmonale (in which there is frank RVH) â€” represents a relatively late stage in the process. Careful search for the ECG findings in Figure 08.24-1 may provide clues to either longterm pulmonary disease and/or associated RVH:

    • Consider **Pulmonary Disease â€” IF you see 2 or more of the first 5 criteria listed in Figure 08.24-1 (especially IF the patient is a known smoker or has other known lung problems).
    • Suspect pulmonary disease plus RVH â€” IF in addition you also see a ***tall R wave in *lead V1 **(with or without ST-T wave changes of RV â€œstrainâ€).
    • By Definition â€” By the time you see clear ECG evidence of RVH in an adult â€” the extent of RVH is usually marked (the patient almost always has end-stage COPD and/or* pulmonary hypertension*).

    Â 

    08.25 â€“ ECG Diagnosis: Review of Specific RVH Criteria

    While no single finding in Figure 08.24-1 *by itself is enough to diagnose RVH â€” seeing several criteria on a single *tracing is very suggestive of RVH â€” especially when seen in a likely clinical setting (ie, COPD, longterm asthma, right-sided heart failure, pulmonary hypertension). Over the next few sections â€” We review specific ECG criteria for RVH:

    • RAD (Right Axis Deviation) â€” is highly suggestive of RVH when seen in a *likely *clinical setting and in association with *other *criteria listed in Figure 08.24-1. Few other conditions produce RAD. This is why we strongly suspect RVH is also present in the patient with cardiomyopathy whose ECG was shown in Figure 08.22-1. In the clinical context of heart failure with evidence of multi-chamber enlargement on ECG (RAA/LAA/LVH) â€” the markedly negative QRS complex in lead I of Fig. 08.22-1 (which we reproduce below in Figure 08.25-1) suggests there is also enlargement of the 4th cardiac chamber (= RVH).
    • RAA â€”** **It is usually easy to recognize the tall, peaked, pointed P waves of RAA (Section 08.19). PEARL: Only one condition produces RAA without at the same time producing RVH (= tricuspid stenosis). Therefore â€” identifying RAA on ECG is an indirect sign that RVH is very likely. This was the case for the patient with cardiomyopathy whose ECG was shown in Fig. 08.22-1 (reproduced below in Figure 08.25-1).

    Â 

    Figure 08.25-1: This ECG is reproduced from Fig. 08.22-1. The patient has a history of heart failure. The ECG shows RAA (tall, peaked P wave in lead II); LAA (deep negative component to the P in V1); and LVH with â€œstrainâ€ and/or ischemia (markedly increased QRS amplitude in precordial leads with ST-T wave changes in V3-through-V6). We strongly suspect a cardiomyopathy with enlargement of the 4th cardiac chamber (= RVH) because in addition to LAA/LVH: i) RAA is also present; and ii) there is otherwise unexplained marked RAD (See text).

    08.26 â€“ RVH: Review of Additional Criteria

    Some findings in Figure 08.24-1 are more suggestive of RVH and/or pulmonary disease than others. The findings we describe below are less specific when seen in isolation â€” but they may be diagnostic when they occur in combination (as we demonstrate in the next few sections). Remember â€” Not all findings are seen in every patient.

    • Indeterminate Axis â€” Alterations in lung volume with emphysema often lead to rightward and posterior axis deviation. As a result â€” net QRS deflection in both leads I and aVF may become negative. PEARL: IF ever you see an indeterminate axis â€” Think RVH/COPD/Obesity (Section 07.8).
    • IRBBB (rSrâ€™ in V1) â€” The presence of an râ€™ (r prime) in lead V1 suggests that *terminal *electrical activity is directed toward the right. While this ECG sign is often benign and commonly seen as an isolated finding in otherwise healthy individuals (Section 05.18) â€” it supports the diagnosis of pulmonary disease/possible RVH if seen in association with other suggestive findings.
    • **Persistent S Waves â€” R wave amplitude normally increases as one moves across the precordial leads (as electrical activity moves toward the left where the larger LV lies). R wave amplitude usually peaks (is tallest) in V4 or V5 â€” and then drops off (in V5,V6). Normally, there is not any S wave at all in V5,V6 â€” since by this time in the depolarization process all electrical activity is traveling leftward. IF more than tiny S waves are **still present in V5,V6 â€” this implies significant rightward activity is still ongoing (*Think RVH/COPD/*large body habitus). That said â€” this finding is not present in Figure 08.25-1 (although a ~5mm S wave is seen in lead V5 â€” no S wave at all is seen in lead V6).
    • ***Low Voltage ***â€” Air is not a good conductor of electricity. The large emphysematous chest of a patient with COPD dampens (reduces) voltage. Technically â€” â€œlow voltageâ€ is defined as QRS amplitude â‰¤5 mm (ie, â‰¤1 large box) in all **6 limb leads (I,II,III; aVR,aVL,aVF). That said â€” we also use â€œlow voltageâ€ as a **relative term when overall QRS amplitude subjectively appears to be reduced. When you see â€œlow voltageâ€ â€” *Think *COPD (although low voltage may also be seen in hypothyroidism; obesity; pneumothorax; pericardial effusion; or as a normal variant).

    Â 

    NOTE: Using the above definition for low voltage (ie, the QRS being â‰¤5 mm in all 6 limb leads) â€” this ECG finding is not all that common. When low voltage is seen â€” it is a nonspecific finding. That said â€” IF low voltage is noted in the presence of other criteria for RVH, this finding adds support to the diagnosis of probable pulmonary disease (especially in a patient with a history of smoking).

    08.27 â€“ Schamrothâ€™s Sign for RVH: *A Null Vector in Lead I ***

    *Beyond-the-Core: *We draw attention to an interesting, uncommon finding known as **Schamrothâ€™s Sign. This is the presence of a null vector (or very small QRS complex) in lead I that is not due to technical error/lead misplacement (Figure 08.27-1). When seen in the â€œrightâ€ clinical setting (ie, a patient with COPD/pulmonary disease) â€” then this ECG finding is highly suggestive of advanced pulmonary disease with probable RVH (especially if other findings in Figure 08.24-1 are also present).

    Figure 08.27-1: Schamrothâ€™s sign. Note the â€œnull vectorâ€ in lead I. RAA is also present (tall, peaked P wave in lead II). When seen in a patient with pulmonary disease and not due to technical error â€” Schamrothâ€™s sign suggests disease is severe and that there is probable RVH (See also Section 08.33).

    08.28 â€“ RVH: Tall R Wave in V1; RV â€œStrainâ€

    The 2 findings in Figure 08.24-1 that best distinguish between pulmonary disease with vs without associated RVH are: i) presence of a tall R wave in lead V1; and ii) presence of RV â€œstrainâ€.

    • Tall R Wave in Lead V1 â€” Lead V1 is a right-sided lead. As a result, the QRS is normally negative in lead V1 (electrical activity moves toward the larger LV and away from V1). IF the R wave is taller than the S wave in lead V1 â€” this means **rightward forces are ***increased ***(which may be an important sign of RVH). Clinically â€” by the time a tall R wave is seen in lead V1 in an adult with pulmonary disease â€” the extent of RVH is usually marked (ie, the patient is likely to have end-stage COPD and/or pulmonary hypertension). This is the case in schematic Figure 08.29-1 shown below.
    • RV â€œStrainâ€ â€” Just as LV â€œstrainâ€ is a sign of *true *LVH â€” seeing â€œstrainâ€ in one or both of the **right-sided lead areas (II,III,aVF â€” and/or â€” V1,V2,V3) strongly supports a diagnosis of RVH (Figure 08.29-1).

    Â 

    08.29 â€“ Schematic FIGURE 08.29-1: Example of RVH + RV â€œStrainâ€

    Most of the ECG criteria for RVH are present in schematic Figure 08.29-1. Note the following:

    • Marked RAD (negative net deflection in lead I; positive QRS in lead aVF).
    • RAA (tall, peaked P wave that looks â€œuncomfortable to sit onâ€ in II,III,aVF).
    • Tall R Wave in** lead V1** (Section 08.28).
    • Persistence of deep S waves in** V5,V6** (Section 08.26).
    • Fnally â€” there is “RV strain”. Typically** **â€” RV â€œstrainâ€ is seen in inferior and/or anterior leads (both of which are present here). PEARL: Inferior and/or anterior ST-T wave changes as seen in Figure 08.29-1 will often not be due to ischemia â€” but rather to RVH or pulmonary embolus. The presence of RAD; RAA; persistent precordial S waves; and tall R wave in lead V1 all suggest that the inferior and anterior ST-T wave changes seen in Fig. 08.29-1 are the result of pulmonary disease.

    Â 

    Figure 08.29-1: Schematic example of RVH + RV â€œstrainâ€. This ECG picture with virtually all criteria from Figure 08.24-1 is uncommon in adults â€” and usually indicates significant RVH/end-stage COPD and/or pulmonary hypertension.

    08.30 â€“ Schematic FIGURE 08.30-1: Example of â€œPulmonaryâ€ Disease

    Pulmonary disease (such as COPD) without frank RVH may sometimes be suggested by ECG. Specifically â€” we look for the presence of at least 2 of the first 5 findings from Figure 08.24-1. This concept is illustrated in schematic Figure 08.30-1. Note the following:

    • An indeterminate axis (negative QRS deflection in both leads I and aVF).
    • RAA (tall, peaked P wave that looks â€œuncomfortable to sit onâ€ in II,III,aVF).
    • rSrâ€™ in** lead V1** (Section 08.26).
    • Persistence of deep S waves throughout all precordial leads (Section 08.26). Transition never occurs (the R wave never becomes taller than the S wave in the precordial leads).

    Â 

    Figure 08.30-1: Schematic ECG that strongly suggests â€œpulmonaryâ€ disease. Low voltage is not seen â€” but the other 4 criteria from Figure 08.24-1 are seen (Note â€” the axis is indeterminate; there is RAA; an rSrâ€™ in V1; and persistence of precordial S waves).

    Clinical Note: There is no definitive ECG sign that â€œprovesâ€ a patient has â€œpulmonary diseaseâ€. Instead â€” We use this descriptor as a qualitative term that may help to explain a combination of ECG findings that are likely to be seen in a group of patients with longstanding/severe pulmonary disorders. As stated â€” the point at which â€œpulmonary diseaseâ€ crosses over to cor pulmonale with frank RVH is often elusive and not detectable by ECG. An Echo would be far more informative regarding true right-sided chamber size, function and pressures.

    • We suspect â€œpulmonary diseaseâ€ when a longtime smoker presents with an ECG manifesting at least 2 or 3 of the first 5 findings in Figure 08.24-1.
    • Given the presence of 4 of these first 5 findings in schematic Figure 08.30-1 â€” it is certainly possible that such a patient might have frank RVH that simply is not yet manifesting a predominant R wave in lead V1. The ECG is simply not sensitive enough to reliably pick up all cases of RVH.
    • Remember that the adult LV is about 3 times as thick as the RV. In 3 dimensions â€” LV mass may normally be up to 10 times greater than normal RV mass. Development of RVH in an adult to the point that it becomes evident on ECG (*by a predominant R wave in lead V1 *â€” *as in *Figure 08.29-1) â€” is therefore a late sign.

    Â 

    08.31 â€“ Pediatric RVH: A few Brief Thoughts â€¦

    Beyond-the-Core: Interpretation of pediatric 12-lead ECGs is a specialty unto itself (well beyond the scope of this ePub). Most providers are only infrequently called upon to interpret pediatric ECGs. We therefore limit our comments here to discussion of a few basic concepts:

    • ECG criteria for determining atrial abnormality (RAA, LAA) in children are similar to criteria that are used in adults (Sections 08.19, 08.20).
    • Very different criteria must be used for determining ventricular enlargement in pediatric patients. Depending on the age of the child being assessed â€” voltage criteria will vary greatly.
    • Detailed tables of pediatric norms are found in textbooks on this subject. Suffice it to say that QRS amplitude is often normally increased in the pediatric patient. Technical problems relating to accuracy of chest lead placement on the tiny chest of a small child when ECGs are recorded by nonpediatric providers are common. Determining whether QRS amplitude exceeds limits for age and satisfies pediatric ECG criteria for LVH is far from a simple matter. Practically Speaking â€” the child with symptoms and/or a murmur will be referred if there is any suspicion of chamber enlargement.

    Â 

    KEY Point: As opposed to the difficulty for the nonpediatric provider in determining LVH â€” suspected RVH is often far easier to surmise on ECG. In contrast to the situation just described for adults (in which LV mass is normally up to 10 times greater than RV mass) â€” RV mass is comparable to LV mass at birth, and tends to remain so for the first few years of life. As a result â€” a proportionately smaller increase in RV size is much more likely in children to produce a noticeable change in net electrical activity between the two ventricles. RVH is therefore much easier to diagnose in young children than it is in adults. Be aware of the following:

    • Some degree of RAD is common in young children.
    • The R wave may normally be taller than the S wave is deep in lead V1 up to about age 5. By the time a child is 6 years old â€” the S wave in lead V1 will usually be deeper than the R wave in this lead is tall.
    • It is common to see anterior T wave inversion on the ECG of otherwise healthy children. This ECG phenomenon is known as a juvenile T wave variant. Symmetric T wave inversion may extend to as far as lead V3 or V4 as a normal phenomenon in a young child or early adolescent. Clinical correlation is essential to avoid mistaking this normal T wave variant as a pathologic pattern (Section 01.4).
    • IF in doubt about â€œnormsâ€ â€” Refer to age-specific tables! Have a low threshold for consulting with someone having expertise in pediatric ECG interpretation.

    Â 

    Pediatric ECGs: Is RVH Likely?

    Imagine the schematic ECGs shown in Figure 08.31-1 and Figure 08.31-2 were each obtained from a 2-year old child. Is RVH likely?

    Figure 08.31-1: Schematic ECG from a young child. Although there is a predominant R wave in lead V1 â€” this may normally be seen up to 5 years of age. Lack of other findings suggests this 2 year old probably does not have RVH.

    Figure 08.31-2: Schematic ECG from a young child. RVH is suggested by a combination of findings including RAD; RAA; tall R wave in lead V1 with RV â€œstrainâ€; and persistent deep S waves in V5,V6 (See text).

    08.32 â€“ FIGURE 08.32-1: Is there RVH?

    The ECG in Figure 08.32-1 was obtained from an older adult with new-onset shortness of breath thought to be due to congestive heart failure.

    • What else do you suspect?

    Â 

    Figure 08.32-1: ECG from a patient with heart failure. Is this ECG what you would expect from a patient with left-sided heart failure? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 08.32-1: The rhythm is sinus tachycardia at ~115/minute. The QRS is narrow. As opposed to the usual picture of left-sided heart failure (in which one expects to see LVH with strain) â€” there is no sign on this ECG of LVH. Instead â€” the tracing strongly suggests severe pulmonary disease (*if not *frank RVH):

    • There is marked RAD (predominantly negative QRS complex in lead I; positive QRS in lead aVF).
    • RAA is present (tall, peaked, â€œuncomfortable-to-sit-onâ€ P wave in inferior leads that in lead II is clearly >2.5mm).
    • An **incomplete RBBB is seen (rsRâ€™ in lead V1; S waves in leads I,V6). Note that the râ€™ in lead V1 is relatively tall.
    • Deep S waves persist through to V5,V6.
    • There are *nonspecific *ST-T wave abnormalities â€” albeit not quite RV strain (and no acute changes).

    Â 

    Bottom Line: ECG Impression â€” The combination of marked RAD, definite RAA, IRBBB and persistent precordial S waves all point to a diagnosis of** RVH** for the ECG shown in Figure 08.32-1.

    • Clinical Impression: This ECG should make one rethink the premise of *left-sided *heart failure as the primary cause of this patientâ€™s new-onset shortness of breath. Instead â€” longstanding/severe pulmonary disease is likely given the combination of ECG findings. Depending on the history (and comparison with prior ECGs on this patient) â€” acute pulmonary embolism might also be considered as a possible diagnosis (See Section 08.34).
    • Beyond-the-Core: There is also LAA in Figure 08.32-1 (very deep negative component to the P wave in lead V1). Whether this reflects anatomic enlargement vs increased LA pressure is uncertain.

    Â 

    08.33 â€“ FIGURE 08.33-1: Is there RVH?

    We conclude this section on RVH with the ECG shown in Figure 08.33-1. We have previously seen this tracing (*in *Figure 02.17-1).

    • Does this ECG suggest pulmonary disease?
    • Is there RVH?

    Â 

    Figure 08.33-1: ECG reproduced from Figure 02.17-1. Is there evidence of pulmonary disease? Is RVH likely?

    Answer to Figure 08.33-1: This patient undoubtedly has severe pulmonary disease (if not frank RVH). We note the following findings:

    • The rhythm is MAT (Sections 02.16, 02.17) â€” as determined by the irregular irregularity with multiple different P wave morphologies that change from beat-to-beat. The presence of MAT is most often associated with severe pulmonary disease.
    • Several of the P wave forms that are seen in lead II are highly suggestive of RAA (tall, peaked and pointed P waves in this lead).
    • There is persistence of fairly deep S waves in lateral precordial leads.
    • Schamrothâ€™s Sign is present â€” as suggested by the very low amplitude r wave with flat ST-T wave in lead I (Section 08.27).

    Â 

    Clinical Impression: The ECG in Figure 08.33-1 was obtained from a patient known to have COPD. The combination of ECG findings noted above should provide insight that the degree of pulmonary disease is severe, if not already associated with RVH and increased pulmonary pressures.

    08.34 â€“ Acute Pulmonary Embolus

    The ECG is usually not a good tool for diagnosing **acute pulmonary embolism (acute PE). That said â€” there *are *times when an ECG may strongly suggest the diagnosis before V/Q scan or chest CT can be done. Acute PE should be considered IF:

    • IF the *clinical setting is â€œrightâ€ *(new-onset dyspnea â€” pleuritic chest pain â€” predisposing risk factors or previous history of PE or deep venous thrombosis).
    • IF the patient has **sinus tachycardia (usually seen with large PE, albeit clearly nonspecific for the diagnosis).
    • Two or more ECG signs of **acute â€œright-heartâ€ strain. These include: i) RAD; ii) RAA; iii) IRBBB or RBBB; iv) Tall R wave in lead V1; and v) Deep S waves in leads V5,V6 (Section 08.24).
    • **RV *â€œstrainâ€ ***â€” as suggested by asymmetric ST-T wave depression in inferior and/or anterior leads (ie, leads II,III,aVF and/or V1,V2,V3). Alternatively â€” there may only be nonspecific ST-T wave changes (ST flattening; slight ST depression).
    • *New-onset *A Fib (a common but nonspecific finding with acute PE).
    • History and the ECG are similar to that presented in Section 08.32.
    • Possibly with an* S1-Q3-T3 *pattern **â€¦ (Section 08.36).

    Â 

    08.35 â€“ Acute PE: Key Clinical Points

    From a clinical perspective â€” Acute PE is increasingly overdiagnosed! Many small (subsegmental) PEs unlikely to be of clinical consequence are being identified by overuse of Chest CT ordered on lower-risk patients with atypical symptoms.

    • The ECG is unlikely to identify patients with smaller PEs. Donâ€™t expect to see anything on the ECG of these patients (this may be a blessing in disguise).
    • *Overall *sensitivity of the ECG for picking up acute PE is poor. Failure to see any of the ECG signs in Section 08.34 does not rule out the possibility of acute PE IF history and clinical features suggest the diagnosis. Chest CT is needed.
    • Sensitivity of the ECG for suggesting the possibility of acute PE is better with larger (especially submassive) PEs. One should at the least see sinus tachycardia in such patients â€” often with nonspecific ST-T wave changes. Large acute PE is commonly associated with other ECG signs â€” but these may be subtle and are generally nondiagnostic.
    • Be aware of the clinical significance of RV â€œstrainâ€. The finding of anterior T wave inversion (in leads V1,V2,V3) in an adult with new-onset dyspnea or pleuritic (or atypical) chest pain will much more often be due to acute PE than to ischemic heart disease. This is especially true IF there is also inferior T wave inversion (in II,III,aVF) â€” as seen in Figure 08.35-1.

    Â 

    Figure 08.35-1: Schematic ECG illustrating a series of ECG findings that taken together are highly suggestive of acute PE (Pulmonary Embolism) â€” especially when seen in a patient with new-onset dyspnea. Note RV â€œstrainâ€ â€” in the form of asymmetric ST-T wave depression seen here in both inferior and anterior leads (II,III,aVF; and V1,V2,V3). In addition â€” there is RAD (the QRS in lead I is markedly negative) â€” RAA (tall, peaked P wave in inferior leads) â€” incomplete RBBB (rSrâ€™ in V1; S waves in I,V6) â€” and persistent precordial S waves that remain deep up to leads V5,V6.

    **08.36 â€“ FIGURE 08.36-1: Should You Look for an S1-Q3-T3?

    Over the years â€” much attention has been focused on the diagnostic utility of recognizing an S1-Q3-T3 pattern as an ECG indicator of acute PE. While important to be aware of what a â€œpositive S1-Q3-T3 patternâ€ is â€” We feel this ECG sign is highly overrated. Our reasons for stating this are given below.

    What is a Positive S1-Q3-T3 Sign?

    We define an S1-Q3-T3 pattern â€” as the presence of: i) an S wave in lead I; ii) a Q wave in lead III; and iii) T wave inversion in lead III (Figure 08.36-1):

    • In order to be valid â€” all 3 of these ECG indicators must be present! That is â€” lead III must show both a Q wave and an inverted T wave! The presence of only 2 ECG indicators does not qualify as a positive S1-Q3-T3 pattern.

    Â 

    Figure 08.36-1: S1-Q3-T3 Pattern â€” as recognized by the presence of: i) an S wave in lead I; ii) a Q wave in lead III; and iii) T wave inversion in lead III. To be valid â€” all 3 of these ECG indicators must be present.

    The S1-Q3-T3 Pattern: Pros and Cons

    By itself â€” one can not rely on a positive S1-Q3-T3 sign as an ECG indicator of acute PE. This is because even in the best of studies â€” both sensitivity and specificity of a positive S1-Q3-T3 sign for acute PE is poor. That is â€” Failure to see this sign in NO way rules out the possibility of acute PE.

    • More often than not â€” you will not see an S1-Q3-T3 sign despite even large acute PE.
    • We have seen the S1-Q3-T3 sign many times in completely healthy and asymptomatic adults! Clearly â€” these patients do not have acute PE.
    • BOTTOM Line: Recognition of a positive S1-Q3-T3 pattern may help in the diagnosis of acute PE â€” IF the positive S1-Q3-T3 pattern is present in association with other suggestive ECG signs and the â€œrightâ€ clinical history. But a positive S1-Q3-T3 is not helpful by itself â€” and absence of a positive S1-Q3-T3 on ECG rules out nothing.

    Â 

    08.37 â€“ FIGURE 08.37-1: The Cause of Anterior T Inversion?

    Imagine the ECG in Figure 08.37-1 was obtained from an adult with new-onset atypical chest discomfort and shortness of breath.

    • Given this clinical scenario â€”* How would you interpret* the symmetric T wave inversion seen in leads V1, V2, V3?

    Â 

    Figure 08.37-1: ECG obtained from a patient with atypical chest pain and new-onset dyspnea. How would you interpret the anterior T wave inversion (arrows) seen here? Note that an S1-Q3-T3 pattern is not present (there is an S1-Q3 but no T3 as highlighted by the blue-white circle).

    Answer to Figure 08.37-1: The rhythm is sinus. There is RAD (the QRS complex in lead I is predominantly negative) â€” RAA (tall, peaked and pointed P wave in lead II) â€” and fairly deep, symmetric T wave inversion is seen in leads V1,V2,V3 (arrows in Figure 08.37-1).

    • The finding of symmetric T wave inversion in a patient with chest discomfort should always prompt consideration of ischemia (which we would do in this case). That said â€” one should especially consider acute PE in this case because: i) The patient also has new-onset dyspnea; and ii) there are other signs suggestive of acute â€œRV strainâ€ on this tracing (marked RAD; RAA). As a result â€” Acute PE would be our 1st diagnosis!
    • NOTE: An S1-Q3-T3 is not present in Figure 08.37-1 â€” because the T wave is not inverted in lead III (blue-white circle seen in the lead III blow-up). That said â€” lack of an S1-Q3-T3 pattern should never be used alone to rule in or out acute PE. While possible ischemia must be considered â€” the history of new-onset dyspnea and this ECG showing anterior T wave inversion plus marked RAD and RAA makes acute PE our working diagnosis until proven otherwise.

    Â 

    08.38 â€“ FIGURE 08.38-1: Is there Acute Anterior STEMI?

    The ECG in Figure 08.38-1 was obtained from a patient who presented with syncope, shock, and acute hypoxemia. In addition to RBBB (QRS widening with an rSRâ€™ in V1 and S waves in I,V6) â€” there is ST coving in V1,V2,V3 and slight-but-definite ST elevation in leads V1,V2.

    • In view of this clinical scenario â€” Is this ECG suggestive of acute STEMI (ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction)?
    • Should you activate the cath lab based on this tracing?

    Â 

    Figure 08.38-1: ECG obtained from a patient who presented with syncope, shock and acute hypoxemia. Is this ECG suggestive of acute anterior STEMI?

    Answer to Figure 08.38-1: This ECG needs to be interpreted as the â€œsumâ€ of its parts in context with the clinical history. Remarkably absent from the history in this patient who presented with syncope, shock and acute hypoxemia â€” is any mention of chest pain. ECG findings in Figure 08.38-1 include:

    • Sinus tachycardia (rate ~ 100/minute).
    • RBBB (QRS widening to at least 0.11 second; rSRâ€™ in lead V1; wide S in lead I; subtle-but-present s wave seen in lead V6).
    • Diffuse ST-T wave changes (See below).
    • Presence of an S1-Q3-T3 pattern as a supportive ECG sign (Figure 08.38-2). Although the q wave and T inversion in lead III are admittedly subtle â€” each component of the S1-Q3-T3 pattern is present (red arrows in Fig. 08.38-2).

    Â 

    Figure 08.38-2: We have added red arrows to Fig. 08.38-1 to highlight the presence of an S1-Q3-T3 pattern. Other ECG findings suggestive of acute PE given the history include: i) Sinus tachycardia; ii) RBBB; iii) diffuse ST-T wave changes; and iv) ST elevation in lead aVR (See text).

    Clinical Impression of Figure 08.38-2: We emphasize â€” that one can not rule out the possibility of acute anterior STEMI from the ECG shown in Figure 08.32-2. That said â€” virtually all facets of the history and this ECG can be explained by one unifying diagnosis = acute PE:

    • Patients with submassive acute PE commonly present with syncope, shock and/or acute hypoxemia. IF these symptoms were the result of acute STEMI â€” We would expect far more extensive ST elevation than is seen in Figure 08.38-2.
    • In the overall clinical context of this case â€” the symmetric anterior T wave inversion with diffuse ST depression elsewhere (in inferior and lateral precordial leads) is perfectly consistent with acute RV â€œstrainâ€.
    • As expected â€” sinus tachycardia is present.
    • RBBB is another common sign of acute RV â€œstrainâ€.
    • A limited number of conditions produce ST elevation that is most marked in lead aVR â€” but minimal or nonexistent elsewhere, with possible exception of lead V1 (See Sections 09.31-through-09.40). One of these conditions is acute PE (Section 09.33). Note that there is marked ST elevation in lead aVR of Figure 08.32-2 (red blow-up box) â€” with ST elevation otherwise limited to lead V1 and no more than a trace in lead V2.
    • BOTTOM Line: Putting all clues together â€” acute PE should be assumed until proven otherwise. This patient was found to have a large saddle embolus.

    Â 

    09.0 â€“ Q-R-S-T Changes

    09.1 â€“ FIGURE 09.1-1: Assessing Q-R-S-T Changes

    The “heart” of ECG interpretation resides with assessing the tracing for QRST Changes. The purpose of this mnemonic â€” ***Q-R-S-T ****â€” is to ensure a systematic approach â€” so that nothing is left out. The most common mistake that occurs when a systematic approach is not closely followed is to allow more dramatic ST-T wave changes to consume one’s attention â€” while subtler (but equally important) findings go unnoticed. Examples of such allâ€“too-easy-to-overlook *findings include failure to recognize non-sinus rhythms; a dominant R wave in lead V1; poor R wave progression and *subtle *ST-T wave changes.

    • BOTTOM Line: *Always *use a Systematic Approach. This not only prevents overlooking important ECG findings â€” but also **saves time by streamlining and organizing your approach (Figure 09.1-1):

    Â 

    Figure 09.1-1: Systematic approach for assessing Q-R-S-T Changes (See text).

    LEAD aVR: Largely ignored in the past â€” Use of lead aVR is now increasingly appreciated as an invaluable adjunct to ECG interpretation. We fully explore this advanced concept in Sections 09.31-through-09.40. In the meantime â€” We suggest not being overly concerned about the ECG appearance in lead aVR:

    • For the most part â€” assessment of lead aVR is not essential to the basics of ECG interpretation (assuming the leads are on correctly and there is no dextrocardia).
    • Beyond-the-Core: ECG appearance in lead aVR may assist in assessing not only technical errors â€” but also narrow and wide-complex tachycardias; acute coronary syndrome from multivessel or left main disease; pericarditis; pulmonary embolism; and more (See Sections 09.31-through-09.40).

    Â 

    09.2 â€“ Septal Depolarization: Reason for Normal Septal Q Waves

    In Section 05.7 â€” We introduced the concept of normal septal activation. Normally â€” the very first part of the ventricles to depolarize (after the impulse passes through the AV node and Bundle of His) â€” is the left side of the ventricular septum. As a result â€” septal depolarization normally moves from left-to-right (red arrow pointing left-to-right in Panel A of Figure 09.2-1).

    • As a result of this initial left-to-right direction of septal depolarization â€” left-sided leads (I,aVL; V4,V5,V6) normally see initial ventricular activation as moving away â€” which is why small septal q waves are often normally seen in one or more of the lateral leads (Panel A).
    • In contrast â€” right-sided leads (V1,V2) normally view initial ventricular activation as coming toward the site on the chest where these leads lie. This explains why a small initial r wave is commonly seen in leads V1, V2 (See lead V1 in Panel A). This initial small r wave represents septal depolarization. It is lost when there is septal infarction (See Figure 09.3-1 â€” in Section 09.3).

    Â 

    Figure 09.2-1: Normal septal activation (A) vs LBBB (B). Septal activation normally begins on the left side of the septum â€” and travels left-to-right (red arrow in Panel A). As a result â€” one normally sees a small r wave in right-sided leads (V1,V2) and small, narrow q waves in one or more of the lateral leads (I,aVL; V4,V5,V6). RBBB does not change these findings (since the right bundle branch travels down the right side of the septum). In contrast â€” LBBB reverses the direction of septal activation (red arrow in Panel B). As a result â€” one should never normally see a septal q wave in a lateral lead with LBBB, unless there has been septal infarction (See text).

    What Happens with BBB?

    Since the RBB (Right Bundle Branch) travels down the right side of the septum â€” the initial left-to-right direction of normal septal depolarization does not change when there is RBBB (Section 05.7).

    • In contrast â€” with LBBB, the normal left-to-right direction of septal activation will reverse because the block with LBBB prevents the initial vector of septal activation from starting on the left (Panel B in Figure 09.2-1). As a result â€” ventricular activation with LBBB moves almost entirely from right-to-left. This explains why septal q waves should not normally be seen with LBBB in lateral leads (Sections 05.6-through-05.9).

    Â 

    09.3 â€“ Precordial Lead Appearance: What is Normal?

    In Figure 09.3-1 â€” We illustrate normal precordial lead appearance by means of a schematic cross-sectional (transverse) view of the heart within the thorax:

    • The small black arrow in Figure 09.3-1 schematically depicts the direction of normal septal depolarization (which moves from left-to-right).
    • The large red arrow depicts the general direction of LV (Left Ventricular) depolarization (which as seen in Fig. 09.3-1 is to the left and posteriorly).
    • The smaller RV (Right Ventricle) â€” predominantly sees electrical activity as moving away from the right (and toward the larger and thicker left ventricle). This explains why the QRS complex in right-sided precordial leads (V1,V2) is normally predominantly negative â€” whereas the QRS in left-sided leads (V5,V6) is generally positive.

    Â 

    Figure 09.3-1: Transverse (cross-sectional) view of the heart â€” illustrating precordial lead appearance in leads V1-through-V6. Note that transition occurs between lead V2-to-V4. There is overlap between leads viewing septal â€” anterior â€” and lateral precordial areas. Septal depolarization normally moves left-to-right (small black arrow). The major component of ventricular activation moves to the left and posteriorly (large red arrow) â€” which reflects the relative size and anatomic position of the left ventricle.

    FIGURE 09.3-1: Key Clinical Points

    • Note that there is overlap in Figure 09.3-1 between leads viewing septal â€” anterior â€” and lateral precordial lead areas. That is â€” lead V2 is both a septal and anterior lead; lead V4 is both an anterior and lateral lead.
    • Septal depolarization (*the small black arrow in *Figure 09.3-1) goes *left-to-right. *The normal small initial positive deflection (r wave) in leads V1,V2 results from septal activation coming toward these right-sided leads. With **septal infarction â€” this small initial r wave in leads V1,V2 is lost.
    • Small normal septal q waves â€” are commonly seen in one (or more) of the *lateral leads (I,aVL; V4,V5,V6). This makes sense â€” since the left-to-*right direction of **septal activation moves away from left-sided leads (*and therefore writes a *small q wave).
    • The area where the R wave becomes taller than the S wave (Transition) occurs normally in Figure 09.3-1. That is â€” the QRS is predominantly negative in lead V2 â€” it is isoelectric in V3 â€” and positive in V4 (so transition occurs between leads V2-to-V4, which is normal).

    Â 

    09.4 â€“ Basic Lead Groups: Which Leads look Where?

    It is essential to know which leads view which areas of the heart. The â€œtrained eyeâ€ keys into specific **Lead Groups (Figure 09.4-1):

    • In Sections 03 and 07 â€” we introduced derivation and anatomic correlation for the 6 limb leads in the frontal plane. This includes the 3 **inferior leads (II,III,aVF) â€” the 2 high-lateral leads (I,aVL) â€” and the most remote (right-sided) lead, which is lead aVR. We expand on these relationships in Figure 09.4-1.
    • Think of the electrical viewpoint of lead aVL as looking down at the heart from perspective of the left shoulder. Thus, lead aVL views the heartâ€™s electrical activity from higher perspective than precordial leads that are placed on the chest. Bipolar lead I at horizontal perspective (corresponding to 0 degree placement in Einthovenâ€™s triangle) â€” also views the heartâ€™s electrical activity from higher perspective than is seen from precordial leads. This is why leads I and** aVL** are designated â€œhigh lateralâ€ leads â€” to be distinguished from lower lying lateral precordial leads (V4,V5,V6).
    • In contrast â€” Think of the electrical viewpoint of lead aVF as looking straight up from the Feet (perpendicular in the frontal plane axis at +90 degrees). The other 2 inferior leads are lead II (at +60 degrees) and lead III (at +120 degrees).
    • The remaining 6 leads are the precordial leads. Anatomic localization of these 6 chest leads is best understood by reviewing the landmarks used for performing an ECG (Section 03.6) in context with the horizontal plane view just discussed in Figure 09.3-1. This should explain ***septal ***(V1,V2) â€” ***anterior ***(V2,V3,V4) â€” and lateral (V4,V5,V6) precordial lead viewpoints for these unipolar leads that view the heartâ€™s electrical activity from perspective of their placement site on the chest.

    Â 

    Figure 09.4-1: Basic Lead Groups. As suggested in Fig. 09.3-1 â€” there is overlap in the precordial lead areas (lead V2* reflects both septal and anterior events; lead V4 reflects both anterior and lateral events*).

    About Lead aVR: â€” The most remote of the 12 standard leads is lead aVR. This right-sided lead views the heartâ€™s electrical activity from the distant perspective of the right shoulder. Lead aVR is unique for providing a view that assesses the basal part of the interventricular septum. It is also unique in providing a mirror-image view of ongoing electrical activity throughout the rest of the heart.

    • Note that we do not assign a specific number of degrees to the vantage point for lead aVR (Figure 09.4-1). Instead â€” it suffices to think of this lead as providing a remote right-sided view. Lead aVR may show reciprocal changes to what occurs in other areas of the heart. Diffuse ST depression in multiple leads from subendocardial ischemia in a patient with severe coronary disease â€” may therefore manifest mirror-image ST elevation that is only seen in lead aVR (This concept discussed in detail in Section 09.40).

    Â 

    **09.5 â€“ R Wave Progression: *Where is Transition? ***

    The â€œRâ€ of our suggested Q-R-S-T memory aid â€” serves to remind us to assess each tracing for R Wave Progression. A typical sequence of R wave progression across the 6 precordial leads is illustrated in Figure 09.5-1, which is a close-up view taken from the lower part of Figure 09.3-1.

    • Normally the R wave becomes progressively taller as one moves across the precordial leads. The R wave often (but not always) â€œtops outâ€ in lead V5 â€” and then drops off in amplitude by lead V6. These relationships are shown in Figure 09.5-1.
    • The easiest way to quickly describe evolution of the QRS waveform from a predominantly negative complex in V1,V2 â€” to a predominantly positive complex in more lateral precordial leads â€” is by commenting on the point of â€œTransitionâ€, which indicates the leads between which the QRS becomes more positive than negative. Transition normally occurs between lead V2-to-V3 â€” or between V3-to-V4. In Figure 09.5-1 â€” Transition occurs between leads V2-to-V4 (since the QRS is predominantly negative in V2 â€” isoelectric in V3 â€” and clearly positive by V4).

    Â 

    Figure 09.5-1: Close-up of the cross-sectional view shown in Figure 09.3-1 â€” in which progression of QRS complexes in the precordial leads is shown. Note the small r wave in lead V1 and that there are small septal q waves in leads V5,V6. R wave amplitude â€œtops outâ€ in V5; Transition is normal (occurs between leads V2-to-V4).

    Where is Transition?

    Determining the point of transition is easy. It is a highly reproducible determination â€” and not subject to inter-interpreter variability (Figure 09.5-2). In contrast â€” there is great variation in the way different interpreters evaluate an ECG for the adequacy of R Wave Progression (Section 09.7).

    • Transition is said to be Normal â€” IF it occurs between leads V2-to-V4 (Panel B in Figure 09.5-2). Regardless of r wave amplitude in the first few precordial leads â€” the R wave becomes taller than the S wave is deep by lead V3 or V4. In Panel B â€” transition occurs between leads V3-to-V4.
    • Transition is said to be Early â€” IF the R wave becomes taller than the S wave is deep by lead V2. This is the case in Panel A â€” in which transition occurs between leads V1-to-V2.
    • Transition is said to be Late â€” IF the point at which the R wave becomes taller than the S wave is deep is delayed to after lead V4. This is the case in Panel C â€” in which transition occurs between leads V4-to-V5.

    Â 

    Figure 09.5-2: Transition in the precordial leads. Normal transition occurs between leads V2-to-V4 (Panel B) â€” vs Early (A) or Late (C) transition.

    KEY Clinical Points: There is no doubt about where transition occurs for each of the 3 precordial lead sequences shown in Figure 09.5-2. Subjectivity does not enter into the definition.

    • NOTE: The point of transition is a descriptive finding. The clinical significance of normal, early or late transition â€” will depend on other ECG parameters (as will be discussed shortly).
    • Our purpose for routinely including assessment of R wave progression and the point of transition in our Systematic Approach (= the â€œRâ€ of Q-R-S-T Changes) â€” is not to overlook the finding of a disproportionately tall R wave in lead V1. Careful assessment of precordial lead morphology should also pick up: i) any râ€™ that might be present in lead V1; and ii) any Q waves or loss of r wave that might occur in precordial leads (Section 09.8).

    Â 

    09.6 â€“ Old Terminology: R Wave Progression â€“ CW, CCW Rotation**

    ECG description of precordial lead QRS appearance has evolved over time. In the past â€” the term â€œR Wave Progressionâ€ was universally used to convey progressive increase (or lack thereof) of QRS amplitude as one successively views the precordial leads.

    • R Wave Progression was said to be â€œnormalâ€ â€” IF the R wave gradually and progressively became taller as one moved across the precordial leads (at least until leads V4,V5).
    • PRWP (Poor R Wave Progression) was said to be present â€” IF the R wave in lead V1 through to leads V3-V4 either did not become taller, or only increased slowly in size.
    • Abnormalities in the way the R wave did or did not progress were described by rotation â€œdirectionâ€.** CCW** (CounterClockWise)** rotation** was said to exist in the transverse plane â€” IF the zone of transition occurred before lead V3 â€” vs CW (ClockWise)** rotation** IF transition occurred after lead V4.

    Â 

    Old vs New Terminology: Use of the ECG designations of â€œclockwiseâ€ and â€œcounterclockwiseâ€ rotation is outdated. These terms are no longer actively used. We find these terms confusing â€” because they are based on the unexpected premise of an observer standing at the feet of the patient looking upward to envision precordial lead progression of R wave amplitude. We suggest you ignore the terms â€œclockwiseâ€ and â€œcounterclockwiseâ€ rotation, which do not contribute to meaningful ECG interpretation.

    • In contrast â€” We have kept the term â€œR Wave Progressionâ€ (RWP) in our ECG vocabulary, because this term remains ingrained in the minds of many ECG interpreters.
    • Clinical Perspective: It is better to determine precordial lead â€œTransitionâ€ than to worry about R wave â€œprogressionâ€. The point of transition much more reproducibly describes what occurs in the transverse plane (Section 09.5).

    Â 

    09.7 â€“ FIGURE 09.7-1: Poor R Wave Progression

    Given continued reference by clinicians to â€œR wave progressionâ€ as a component of ECG interpretation â€” it is essential to appreciate what is meant by the term, â€œPRWPâ€.

    • PRWP (Poor R Wave Progression) â€” is said to exist IF the R wave does not progressively increase as one moves across the precordial leads. A number of conditions may be associated with PRWP. We list these in Figure 09.7-1. The problem is that many of the entities on this list are clinical â€œoppositesâ€ (ie, RVH vs LVH; normal variant vs myocardial infarction). Clinical utility of a term that fails to distinguish between opposites is limited.
    • Clinical Perspective: The term â€œPRWPâ€ is clearly suboptimal. That said, despite its shortcomings â€” the designation â€œPRWPâ€ remains in active use. Specific indication of which precordial leads manifest Q waves (or QS complexes) â€” and noting the area of transition is far better. Nevertheless â€” Youâ€™ll want to be aware of the entities commonly associated with PRWP (Figure 09.7-1):

    Â 

    Figure 09.7-1: Common causes of â€œPRWPâ€ â€” which is said to exist if the R wave does not become progressively taller as one moves across the precordial leads (See text).

    09.8 â€“ FIGURE 09.8-1: Anterior MI vs Lead Placement Error?

    Technical mishaps and lead placement errors were reviewed in Section 03. Awareness of these technical pitfalls is especially relevant in assessing precordial lead R wave progression. For example â€” Examine the precordial lead sequence shown in Panel A of Figure 09.8-1.

    • Does the precordial lead sequence in Panel A make sense? If not â€” What might be the cause of the problem?
    • HINT: Be sure to look not only at R wave progression â€” but also at T wave progression in the precordial leads shown in Panel A.

    Â 

    Figure 09.8-1: Precordial lead R wave progression in Panel A does not make sense â€” because there is abrupt loss and return of** r wave** between V1-to-V3. Note also what happen to T wave morphology as one moves from V1-to-V2-to-V3 in Panel A (See text).

    Answer to Figure 09.8-1: When R wave progression is â€œnormalâ€ â€” there is gradual increase in R wave amplitude as one moves across successive precordial leads. This is not seen in Panel A of Figure 09.8-1:

    • A relatively tall initial R wave is seen in lead V1.
    • There is loss of R wave amplitude between lead V1-to-V2.
    • R wave amplitude in Panel A returns by lead V3.
    • Although possible that abrupt loss and return of** r wave** in Panel A could be the result of isolated anterior infarction â€” it is far more likely to represent an error in lead placement. Loss and return of R wave amplitude is usually not nearly so abrupt when due to infarction.
    • Further support of lead placement error is forthcoming from assessment of changes in T wave morphology. T wave progression from lead V1-to-V3 in Panel A also does not make sense. Normally â€” the T wave may be negative, flat (isoelectric), or upright in lead V1. The T wave should not go from positive in lead V1 â€” to negative in lead V2 â€” to positive once more in lead V3 as it does in Panel A.
    • Putting It All Together: The precordial lead sequence in Panel A would make much more sense IF lead V2 was really lead V1 â€” and lead V1 was really lead V2. This technical lead placement error is in fact the cause of the unusual (and unrealistic) R wave and T wave progression seen in Panel A. Correct lead placement is shown in Panel B. R wave and T wave progression is now normal â€” with transition between lead V3-to-V4.
    • PEARL: Another reason for routinely including assessment of transition, R wave progression and precordial lead appearance in our Systematic Approach (the â€œRâ€ in Q-R-S-T Changes) â€” is to avoid overlooking technical lead placement errors like the one in Figure 09.8-1.

    Â 

    09.9 â€“ FIGURE 09.9-1: What is the Cause of PRWP?

    As we have emphasized â€” the designation PRWP (Poor R Wave Progression) lacks specificity. That is â€” many conditions may account for relatively low anterior r wave amplitude (Figure 09.7-1). The purpose of Section 09.9 and Section 09.10 is to illustrate how integration of the overall ECG picture facilitates determining which of the entities listed in Figure 09.7-1 is likely to be operative.

    • The schematic precordial lead sequences in both Panel A and Panel B of Figure 09.9-1 qualify as manifesting â€œPRWPâ€. Contemplate WHY we label Panel A as suggestive of COPD â€” and Panel B as suggestive of lead placement error.

    Â 

    Figure 09.9-1: PRWP due to COPD vs placement error (See text).

    Answer to Figure 09.9-1: PRWP is clearly present in the schematic 12-lead ECG shown in Panel A. No more than a tiny initial r wave is seen in leads V1,V2 â€” and R wave amplitude remains small through to lead V6. Transition never occurs (ie,* the R wave never becomes taller than the S wave is deep*).

    • The reason the schematic ECG in Panel A is strongly suggestive of COPD â€” is that several additional ECG signs of pulmonary disease are present. These include:** i)** RAD (Right Axis Deviation); ii) RAA (Right Atrial Abnormality); and iii) persistent precordial S waves that are still deep in V5,V6 (See Section 08.30 for Review of ECG findings with pulmonary disease).
    • NOTE:* Despite* â€œPRWPâ€ for the precordial lead sequence in Panel A â€” anterior infarction is far*** less likely*** because: i) an r wave (albeit a small r wave) is present in all precordial leads; and ii) the overall ECG picture in Panel A strongly suggests COPD.
    • In contrast to Panel A â€” the 6 precordial leads in Panel B strongly suggest lead placement error. Abrupt loss and return of r wave from V1-to-V3 is not a logical sequence for normal R wave progression â€” especially given rapid development of a predominant R wave by lead V4. Confirmation of technical error should be easy to establish by verifying chest lead placement and then repeating the ECG.

    Â 

    09.10 â€“ FIGURE 09.10-1: QS in V1,V2 vs Anterior MI?

    Two final examples of PRWP are shown in Panels B and C of Figure 09.10-1. For comparison â€” we begin with an example of normal R wave progression in Panel A.

    • Why do we label Panel B as suggestive of anterior MI?
    • Is the precordial lead sequence in Panel C also indicative of septal and/or anterior infarction? If so â€” How likely is it that prior infarction has occurred?

    Â 

    Figure 09.10-1: Normal RWP (R Wave Progression) is seen in Panel A. This is in comparison with precordial lead sequences suggestive of anterior MI (Panel B) vs an indeterminate pattern showing a QS complex in leads V1,V2 but not in V3 (Panel C).

    Answer to Figure 09.10-1: With normal R wave progression (Panel A) â€” there is progressive increase in R wave amplitude across successive precordial leads until transition occurs. In Panel A â€” the R wave â€œtops outâ€ in lead V5 and transition occurs between V3-to-V4.

    • Normally â€” the QRS complex in lead V1 is predominantly negative, because ventricular depolarization is traveling away from this right-sided lead. There may (or may not) normally be a small upright initial r wave in lead V1. Thus, the fact that a QS (entirely negative) complex is seen in lead V1 of Panel A is completely consistent with normal ventricular depolarization.
    • Although tiny â€” a small r wave (positive initial deflection) is seen by lead V2 of Panel A.
    • In contrast, in Panel C â€” a QS pattern is seen in both lead V1 and V2. This may or may not be a â€œnormalâ€ finding. Instead, it could indicate: i) a technical lead placement error; or ii) septal infarction. Since there may not be any reliable way to distinguish between normal variant vs lead placement error vs prior septal infarction â€” We simply acknowledge,*** â€œQS in V1,V2; Suggest clinical correlationâ€*** in our interpretation.
    • Statistically â€” the odds are far greater (approximately 4-to-1) that either normal variant or lead placement error *rather than *septal infarction are the reason for a QS complex in V1,V2 but not V3 (as seen in Panel C).
    • It is only when no r wave at all is seen in V1,V2 and V3 that prior anterior (or anteroseptal) infarction becomes more likely (Panel B).
    • Additional support that the precordial lead sequence in Panel B indicates prior anteroseptal infarction â€” is the finding of a small-but-definite q wave in lead V4 but not in leads V5,V6. If the initial negative deflection in lead V4 was a septal q wave â€” We would also expect to see similar small septal q waves in leads V5,V6.
    • NOTE-1: The above comments regarding clinical implications of a QS complex in leads V1,V2,V3 hold true only when the QRS complex is narrow. QRS widening due to LBBB commonly produces QS complexes in anterior leads that are simply the result of the conduction defection and are not indicative of anterior infarction (Section 05.8).
    • NOTE-2: There are 2 other potential reasons for PRWP with a narrow QRS complex that are not the result of prior infarction. These are: i) LVH; and ii) LAHB. Usually at least some r wave will be seen by lead V3 with these other conditions â€” though not always. Bottom Line: It is sometimes extremely difficult to know with certainty the cause of PRWP when R waves in leads V1,V2,V3 are either very small or absent. Clinical correlation is essential.

    Â 

    Beyond-the-Core: It is insightful to appreciate the physiologic reason why R wave progression is often â€œpoorâ€ in the presence of LVH *and/or *LAHB.

    • LVH (Left Ventricular Hypertrophy) â€” produces an increase in leftward and posterior forces. When marked â€” these leftward and posterior forces may totally predominate over initial rightward and anterior forces seen in leads V1,V2,V3. The result is reduction in r wave amplitude in anterior leads. At times â€” there may even be elimination of any r wave at all in V1,V2,V3.
    • LAHB (Left Anterior HemiBlock) â€” The bundle of conduction fibers in the LAH (Left Anterior Hemifascicle) lies slightly in front of (anterior to) fibers in the LPH (Left Posterior Hemifascicle). As a result â€” block in the LAH (as occurs with LAHB) results in an initial posterior direction for electrical activity that is first conducted over the intact LPH. The result may once again be reduction in r wave amplitude in the anterior leads.

    Â 

    09.11 â€“ FIGURE 09.11-1: PRWP from LVH vs Anterior MI?

    Examine the 2 precordial lead sequences shown in Figure 09.11-1. PRWP with delayed transition (between V4-to-V5) is seen in both Panel A and Panel B.

    • What is the difference between these 2 precordial lead sequences?
    • Is anterior infarction likely in either case?
    • Does LVH explain all ECG findings?
    • Beyond-the-Core: Comment on the ST elevation seen in leads V2,V3 (short red horizontal lines in leads V2,V3 in Panel B).

    Â 

    Figure 09.11-1: LVH with PRWP. Red arrows and circles highlight the difference in R wave progression between Panel A and Panel B. Is there evidence of anterior infarction in one or both cases? Does LVH explain all ECG findings? (See text).

    Answer to Figure 09.11-1: QRS amplitude is markedly increased in both Panel A and Panel B â€” easily satisfying criteria for LVH (deepest S in V1,V2 + tallest R in V5,V6 >35mm). In addition â€” ST-T wave changes of LV â€œstrainâ€ are seen in lead V6.

    • Both precordial lead sequences in Figure 09.11-1 manifest a QS complex in leads V1,V2 (red arrows). The difference â€” is that a QS complex is also present in lead V3 of Panel B (red arrow) â€” whereas a small initial positive deflection (r wave) is seen in lead V3 of Panel A (red circle).
    • As emphasized in Section 09.10 â€” the ECG picture in Panel A (QS in V1,V2 but not in lead V3) is far more likely not to be due anterior infarction. We would therefore write the following as our interpretation: â€œLVH and strain; QS in V1,V2 of uncertain significance; Suggest clinical correlationâ€.
    • In contrast â€” the ECG picture in Panel B (QS in V1,V2 and in lead V3) makes it more likely that anterior infarction has occurred. That said â€” QRS amplitude is so greatly increased, that loss of r waves in V1,V2,V3 could be the result of marked LVH. We simply can not know for sure on the basis of this single ECG tracing. We would therefore write the following as our interpretation: â€œLVH and strain; QS in V1,V2 and V3; possible prior anterior infarction; Strongly suggest clinical correlationâ€.

    Â 

    Final Point: A subtle-but-real additional finding in Figure 09.11-1 is the presence of at least 2mm of ST elevation in leads V2,V3 in both Panel A and Panel B (short red horizontal lines in Panel B).

    • This ST elevation should be noted. That said â€” We strongly suspect this ST elevation is not indicative of acute injury because: i) Shape of the ST elevation is concave up = â€œsmileyâ€ vs ST coving that is far more predictive of acute injury; and ii) the ECG picture in the anterior leads is the reciprocal (mirror-image) of what is seen in lead V6. This mirror-image picture of concave-up ST elevation in one or more anterior leads is often seen simply as a reflection of LVH in patients without acute infarction.

    Â 

    BOTTOM Line: R wave progression is a descriptive finding. There are many potential causes of PRWP (which we listed in Figure 09.7-1). Some of these causes are benign. Some are not. Clinical correlation in context with the overall ECG picture is needed to determine likely clinical implications when PRWP is noted.

    **09.12 â€“ FIGURE 09.12-1: *Normal Q Waves; Normal T Inversion ***

    Among the most challenging tasks for the ECG interpreter â€” is deciding what is â€œnormalâ€ vs â€œabnormalâ€. Our purpose in devising Figure 09.12-1 â€” is to facilitate remembering when the finding of even a large Q wave or deep T wave inversion may be normal.

    • 5 of the** leads** on a standard 12-lead ECG (= leads III-aVR-aVL-aVF-V1) â€” may normally display even moderate-to-large Q waves and/or T wave inversion** in healthy adults who do not have heart disease.
    • Thinking of a â€œreverse Zâ€ (*Ã  la *Zorro) â€” may help to recall which leads these are (Figure 09.12-1).

    Â
